We put a temporary fix in place until the other issues are resolved.
We made a workaround until the other things get fixed.

cards.note:
**[109]**

[Workaround] is often paired with verbs like [implement], [put in place], or [make].

[Gets fixed] is a good example of the 'get-passive', which is common in technical speech. [Is fixed] is also correct.

A common error is using 'be' incorrectly: ~until the rest be fixed~. The correct forms are [is fixed] or [gets fixed].

(User question: 'rest' vs. 'resto') Yes, [the rest] is the correct translation for 'el resto' (meaning 'what is left over'). It is different from the verb [to rest] (descansar).

cards.sideA: En mi flujo de trabajo tambien debo hacer esas cosas

sideB.text: In my workflow, I also have to do those things.
Doing those things is also part of my workflow.
My workflow also includes doing those things.

cards.note:
**[109]**

[Workflow] is a single compound noun that refers to the sequence of steps in a process.

[Part of my workflow] is a very natural way to phrase this.

A common error is the literal translation ~in my flow of work~. The correct term is the single word [workflow].

cards.sideA: ¿Quieres que te hable acerca de mi flujo de trabajo?

sideB.text: Do you want me to talk about my workflow?
Would you like me to tell you about my workflow?
Should I walk you through my workflow?
Do you want me to tell you about my workflow?

cards.note:
**[109]**

The structure for '¿Quieres que...?' is [Do you want me to...].

[To walk someone through] something is an excellent phrasal verb **[16]** that means to explain a process step-by-step.

A very common error is a literal translation: ~Do you want that I talk about...~. This is incorrect in English.

~Do you want I talk to you about my workflow?~ (Incorrect structure: You cannot say 'Do you want I talk'. The correct pattern is 'Do you want *me* to talk'.)

cards.sideA: Tengo una carga de trabajo bastante alta esta semana

sideB.text: I have a pretty heavy workload this week.
My workload is quite high this week.
I'm dealing with a heavy workload this week.

cards.note:
**[109]**

[Workload] is the correct term for the amount of work.

The most common adjective to describe a large workload is [heavy]. [High] is also acceptable.

Common errors are literal translations like ~charge of work~ or using awkward adjectives like ~big workload~. The correct collocation is [heavy workload].

~I have a strong workload...~ (Incorrect collocation: We describe a workload as 'heavy' or 'high', not 'strong'.)

cards.sideA: Necesito definir mejor mi espacio de trabajo

sideB.text: I need to define my workspace better.
I need to organize my workspace more clearly.
I need to set up my workspace more effectively.

cards.note:
**[109]**

[Workspace] is a single word that can refer to your physical desk area or your digital environment.

Verbs like [define], [organize], or [set up] work well here.

A common error is the literal translation ~space of work~. The correct compound noun is [workspace].

~I need to define better my workspace.~ (Incorrect order: In English, the adverb 'better' usually goes after the object 'my workspace' or before the verb 'better define'. It should be 'I need to define my workspace better'.)

cards.sideA: Gracias!, me alegraste el dia con ese comentario.

sideB.text: Thanks! That comment really made my day.
Thank you, you just made my day with that comment.
Thanks! That comment brightened up my day.
That's so kind of you, you've really made my day.
Thanks, you made my day with that comment.

cards.note:
The most common and natural idiom is [to make my day].

A good synonym is [to brighten up my day].

A common error is a literal translation, which is incorrect: ~You alegried my day~ or ~You happied my day~. Another unnatural phrasing is ~That comment put me happy for the day~.

~Thanks, you made my day with that commentary.~ (This is grammatically correct, but 'commentary' is the wrong word choice. A 'comment' is a single remark. A 'commentary' is a longer analysis or series of comments. The correct word here is 'comment'.)

cards.sideA: Estamos priorizando los mas graves primero

sideB.text: We are prioritizing the most severe ones first.
We're tackling the most critical issues first.
We are prioritizing the most serious ones first.
Our priority is handling the most severe issues first.

cards.note:
The adjective 'grave' (Spanish) translates to [severe], [critical], or [serious] in this context.

The phrasal verb [to tackle] is a common synonym for 'to handle' or 'to address' a problem.

A common error is using the false friend 'grave': ~We are prioritizing the most graves first~. Another is misplacing 'first': ~We are prioritizing the most severe ones at first~ (this means 'in the beginning', which changes the meaning).

~We are prioritizing the serious ones first.~ (This is grammatically correct, but it changes the meaning. The Spanish 'los más graves' requires the superlative 'the **most** serious ones'.)


~...the more serious ones~ is a comparative form used for two items. Since you are referring to a group (los más graves), use the superlative [the most serious ones].

cards.sideA: Estamos priorizando los mas urgentes primero.

sideB.text: We are prioritizing the most urgent ones first.
We're handling the most urgent issues first.
We're focusing on the most time-sensitive ones first.
The most urgent items are being prioritized.
We are prioritizing the most important ones first.

cards.note:
[Most urgent] is the correct translation. [Time-sensitive] is an excellent synonym in a business or tech context.

A common error is redundancy: ~We are prioritizing the most more urgent ones first~. 'Most' already forms the superlative.

cards.sideA: Tenemos una lista y un mapa anidados

sideB.text: We have a nested list and map.
We have a list and a map that are nested.
We're using a nested list and map structure.
The data structure is a nested map and list.

cards.note:
The correct technical term is [nested]. It is used as an adjective before the nouns.

A common error is to misspell the term or use a literal, less precise translation: ~We have a list and map nestered~ or ~We have a list inside a map~ (while the second is understandable, [nested] is the specific term).

cards.sideA: El mapa y la lista estan anidados

sideB.text: The map and the list are nested.
The map and list are nested inside each other.
The list is nested within the map.
You'll find the map and the list are nested.

cards.note:
This uses the passive structure [are nested] (to be + past participle).

If you know the relationship, you can be more specific: [The list is nested within the map].

A common error is using the wrong verb form: ~The map and the list are nesting~ (this is active voice and implies they are doing the action themselves, which is incorrect).

cards.sideA: De donde viene? (cosa, concepto, dato)

sideB.text: Where does this come from?
Where does it come from?
Where is this coming from?
What's the source of this?
What's the origin of this data?

cards.note:
**[176]**

When asking about the origin of data or a concept, [Where does this come from?] is perfect.

[What's the source of this?] or [What's the origin...] are more formal ways to ask the same thing.

A common error is to forget the auxiliary verb 'does' or use incorrect word order: ~Where this comes from?~. The correct structure is `Where + [auxiliary] + [subject] + [verb]?`

cards.sideA: ok necesitamos verlo (revisar)

sideB.text: Okay, we need to check this.
Okay, we need to look into this.
Okay, we need to check it.
Okay, we need to review this.
Alright, we need to check this out.

cards.note:
[Check] is a perfect word. [Check this out] is a common phrasal verb.

Use [check] for a quick verification.
Use [look into] to imply a deeper investigation of a problem.
Use [review] for a more formal examination.

A common error is using 'see': ~We need to see this~. This usually just means 'visually look at it', not 'investigate' or 'verify'.

cards.sideA: Totalmente lo entiendo

sideB.text: I totally get it.
I completely understand.
I totally get what you mean.
Makes perfect sense.
Got it. 100 percent.

cards.note:
[I totally get it] is 100% valid, natural, and common.

[To get] is often used as a more informal synonym for [to understand].

[Makes perfect sense] is another natural way to show agreement and understanding.

A common error is mixing auxiliaries: ~I am get it~ or ~I am getting it~ (which implies you are in the *process* of understanding, not that you *already* understand).

cards.sideA: Esos problemas podrían tomar mucho tiempo.

sideB.text: Those issues could take a long time.
Those problems might take a lot of time.
Fixing those issues could be very time-consuming.
That could take a while to sort out.
Those problems could take quite a bit of time.
Those issues could take a bit more time.
Those issues could take more time.

cards.note:
The modal verb [could] expresses possibility. [Might] is also a perfect synonym here.

[Time-consuming] is a great adjective that means 'taking a lot of time'.

A common error is using 'very' with 'time': ~take very time~. The correct phrase is [take a long time] or [take a lot of time].

~Those issues could take a longer~ is incorrect because 'longer' is a comparative adjective that needs a noun like 'time' or should be used as an adverb [take longer].

cards.sideA: Ese toma mucho tiempo.

sideB.text: That one takes a long time.
That takes a lot of time.
That's very time-consuming.
That one is very time-consuming.
That process takes a while.
That takes a long time.
That takes too long.

cards.note:
Use the third-person singular [takes] because the subject 'That one' is singular.

[A while] is a common, natural idiom for 'a long time'.

A common error is omitting the '-s': ~That one take a long time~. Another is using the continuous tense incorrectly: ~That is taking a long time~ (this is only correct if it is happening *right now*).

~That takes much time.~ (This is unnatural. In positive statements, 'a lot of time' is preferred over 'much time'. You would use 'much time' in questions like 'Does it take much time?')

cards.sideA: Hemos priorizado otros más importantes.

sideB.text: We've prioritized other, more important ones.
We have prioritized more important ones.
We're focusing on the more critical ones first.
We've given priority to more important items.
We've prioritized more important ones.

cards.note:
The Present Perfect [We have prioritized] or [We've prioritized] is the correct tense for a recent past action with present relevance.

[To give priority to] is a good alternative to the verb [to prioritize].

A common error is using 'more' incorrectly: ~We have prioritized the more importants~. The adjective 'important' comes *before* the noun [ones] or [items].

~...others more important~ (Incorrect word order: The adjective 'more important' should come before the pronoun 'ones' or 'items', e.g., 'We've prioritized more important ones'.)

cards.sideA: Ok, las imágenes están saliendo cortadas, hay que ajustarlas.

sideB.text: Okay, the images are getting cut off. We need to adjust them.
Okay, the images are being cropped. They need to be adjusted.
Right, the images are cut off. We have to fix them.
The images are not displaying fully. We need to make an adjustment.
Okay, the images are cutting off. We need to adjust them.
Okay, the images are being cut off. We need to adjust them.

cards.note:
[To get cut off] is a perfect phrasal verb for this. [To be cropped] also works.

[Hay que] can be translated as [We need to] or [We have to].

A common error is a literal translation: ~The images are coming out cut~. The correct idiom is [are getting cut off].

cards.sideA: Ok, las imágenes no se están escalando bien, hay que ajustarlas mejor.

sideB.text: Okay, the images aren't scaling properly. We need to adjust them better.
The images are not scaling correctly. We need to fine-tune them.
The images aren't resizing well. They need a better adjustment.
Okay, the image scaling is off. We need to fix it.

cards.note:
[To scale] is the correct technical verb. [To resize] is a good synonym.

[Properly] and [correctly] are adverbs that mean 'in the right way'.

[To fine-tune] means 'to make small, precise adjustments'.

~The images are not scaling good~ is a common error. Use the adverb [well] or [properly], not the adjective [good].

cards.sideA: Creo que discutimos este tema en una reunión anterior.

sideB.text: I think we discussed this topic in a previous meeting.
I believe we talked about this in a prior meeting.
I'm pretty sure we already covered this topic.
Didn't we already go over this in a past meeting?

cards.note:
The verb [discuss] does not take a preposition. A very common error is ~We discussed about this topic~. The correct form is [We discussed this topic].

[Previous] and [prior] are synonyms for 'anterior'.

[To cover] or [to go over] a topic are common phrasal verbs for 'discuss'.

cards.sideA: Sí, lo habíamos discutido anteriormente.

sideB.text: Yes, we had discussed that previously.
Yep, we had already talked about that.
That's right, we'd already covered that.
Yes, we discussed that before.

cards.note:
The Spanish 'habíamos discutido' (Past Perfect) is used because it happened *before* another past event (e.g., before *now* or before *the previous meeting*). In English, you can use the Past Perfect [we had discussed] or the simple [we discussed... before].

Remember the rule: [We discussed that], not ~We discussed about that~.

cards.sideA: Yo noté que había algo raro.

sideB.text: I noticed there was something strange.
I noticed something was off.
I could tell something was wrong.
I noticed something weird was going on.
I saw that there was something odd.
I noticed something strange.

cards.note:
[Something was off] is a very common and natural idiom for 'había algo raro'.

[Strange], [weird], and [odd] are all good synonyms for 'raro'.

A common error is ~I noticed that was something strange~. The word [there] is necessary: [I noticed (that) there was...].

Both [I noticed there was something strange] and the more direct [I noticed something strange] are correct.

cards.sideA: Yo no vi a quién se lo envió.

sideB.text: I didn't see who he sent it to.
I didn't see who she sent it to.
I didn't see who they sent it to.
I didn't catch who it was sent to.

cards.note:
The Spanish 'se' is ambiguous (he/she/they). All translations are correct. [They] is a good neutral option.

The structure is [who] + [subject] + [verb] + [object] + [to].

A common error is inverting the question form inside the statement: ~I didn't see who did he send it to~. This is incorrect. Use the statement order: [who he sent it to].

~I didn't see who he sent it.~ (Incorrect. This is incomplete. When 'send' is used to talk about the recipient, it needs the preposition 'to'. The correct sentence is 'I didn't see who he sent it **to**'.)

cards.sideA: Pero no vi a quién.

sideB.text: But I didn't see who.
But I didn't see who to.
But I didn't catch who.
I just didn't see who he sent it to.

cards.note:
The simplest form is [I didn't see who].

Adding the preposition [to] at the end ([I didn't see who to]) is also common and grammatically correct, as it implies 'I didn't see *to whom* it was sent'.

[To catch] is a good synonym for 'to see' or 'to notice' in this context.

cards.sideA: Hoy no, pero mañana sí.

sideB.text: Not today, but I will tomorrow.
I can't today, but I will tomorrow.
Not today, but tomorrow I will.

cards.note:
**[112]**

This is **Case 1 (Contrast) /112/**. To show an affirmative contrast ('...pero mañana sí'), English repeats the auxiliary verb [will].

(I [won't] today, but I [will] tomorrow.)

A common error is the literal translation ~...but tomorrow yes.~, which is incorrect.

cards.sideA: Él no vino, pero yo sí.

sideB.text: He didn't come, but I did.
He didn't, but I did.
He didn't attend, but I did.

cards.note:
**[112]**

This is **Case 1 (Contrast) /112/**. The negative 'He didn't...' uses the auxiliary [did]. To create the '...pero yo sí' contrast, you must use the positive auxiliary [did].

A common error is ~...but I yes.~ or ~...but I yes came.~

~He didn't come, but I did it~ is incorrect because 'it' implies a direct object. In ellipsis for contrast, you should only use the auxiliary [did] without adding 'it'.

cards.sideA: Yo no puedo, pero él sí.

sideB.text: I can't, but he can.
I can't do it, but he can.
I am not able to, but he is.

cards.note:
**[112]**

This is **Case 1 (Contrast) /112/**. The negative 'I can't...' uses the auxiliary [can]. To create the '...pero él sí' contrast, you must use the positive auxiliary [can].

If the first clause uses 'be' ('am not able'), the second uses 'be' ('he is'). You must match the auxiliary verb.

cards.sideA: Mañana sí lo haré.

sideB.text: I will definitely do it tomorrow.
I will certainly do it tomorrow.
I'll do it for sure tomorrow.
I really will do it tomorrow.

cards.note:
**[112]**

This is **Case 2 (Emphasis) /112/**. 'Sí' is not for contrast, but for confirmation. English uses an adverb like [definitely], [certainly], or [really] to add this emphasis.

A common error is the literal translation ~I will yes do it tomorrow.~

cards.sideA: Además, no son errores que comprometan producción.

sideB.text: Besides, they aren't errors that compromise production.
Also, they are not issues that will affect production.
Besides, they aren't production-blocking errors.
Also, they won't compromise the production environment.

cards.note:
**[83]**

The verb [to compromise] (comprometer) is correct. [To affect] (afectar) is also a good synonym.

[Production-blocking] is a very common technical term for an error that 'compromete producción'.

~commit~ is a false friend. You [commit] code, but you [compromise] stability.

~Besides, they aren't errors to compromise production.~ (Incorrect structure. You cannot use the infinitive 'to compromise' here. You must use a relative clause: 'errors **that** compromise production' or 'errors **compromising** production'.)

cards.sideA: Además, no son graves.

sideB.text: Besides, they aren't severe.
Also, they aren't serious.
Besides, they're not critical.
Also, they're not that serious.

cards.note:
**[83]**

The Spanish adjective 'grave' (in this context) translates to [severe], [serious], or [critical].

A common error is to use the false friend 'grave' (which in English refers to a tomb). The phrase ~they are not grave~ is unnatural and incorrect.

cards.sideA: Acabo de enviartelo por mensaje interno

sideB.text: I just DM'd it to you.
I just sent it to you in a private message.
I just pinged it to you.
I just slacked it to you.

cards.note:
[DM'd] (Direct Message) is very common on social media.

[To ping] (informal) or [to slack] (specific to Slack) are very common in a work environment for tools like Slack or Teams.

cards.sideA: Si, acabo de enviartelo por correo electronico

sideB.text: Yep, I've just emailed it to you.
Yeah, I just sent it to you by email.
Yes, I just sent it to your inbox.

cards.note:
The verb [to email] is the most direct and natural form.

[I've just emailed...] (Present Perfect) emphasizes the recent completion of the action.

[Inbox] is a common synonym for 'email account'.

cards.sideA: Ninguna de ellas

sideB.text: Neither of them.
None of them.
Not a single one.

cards.note:
This is a critical distinction:

Use [Neither of them] when referring to **only two** options.

Use [None of them] when referring to **three or more** options.

[Not a single one] is for strong emphasis and works for any number (two or more).

cards.sideA: Un poco de ambas

sideB.text: A little bit of both.
A bit of both.
It's a mix of the two.

cards.note:
The word [both] (ambas) explicitly implies there are **only two** things being discussed.

[A little bit of both] and [A bit of both] are the most common and interchangeable phrases.

cards.sideA: ¿Debo usar el simbolo arroba? (@)

sideB.text: Should I use the at sign?
Do I need to use the at sign here?
Should I use the at symbol?

cards.note:
**[113]**

The correct English name for the '@' symbol is the [at sign].

When reading an email address (e.g., 'user@mail.com'), you just say [at]: 'user at mail dot com'.

cards.sideA: Ahora para finalizar usa punto y coma (;)

sideB.text: Now, use a semicolon to finish.
Now, use a semicolon at the end.
End it with a semicolon.
Now, to finish, use a semicolon.

cards.note:
**[113]**

The ';' symbol is called a [semicolon].

Be careful not to confuse it with the [colon] ( : ), which is 'dos puntos'.

cards.sideA: No se si debes usar dos puntos, o punto y coma (: ;)

sideB.text: I don't know if you should use a colon or a semicolon.
I'm not sure if you need a colon or a semicolon here.

cards.note:
**[113]**

This card contrasts the two symbols:

[Colon] = : (dos puntos)
[Semicolon] = ; (punto y coma)

cards.sideA: ¿Debería usar llaves en esta parte? ({})

sideB.text: Should I use braces in this part?
Do I need to use curly brackets here?

cards.note:
**[113]**

The '{ }' symbols are most commonly called [braces] or [curly brackets] in programming.

cards.sideA: Ahora encierralo con paréntesis ( ( ) )

sideB.text: Now, put it in parentheses.
Now, enclose it in parentheses.

cards.note:
**[113]**

The '( )' symbols are called [parentheses].

The verb [to enclose] (encerrar) is a more formal alternative to [to put it in].

cards.sideA: Encierra eso con corchetes ( [ ] )

sideB.text: Enclose that in brackets.
Put that inside square brackets.

cards.note:
**[113]**

The '[ ]' symbols are called [brackets] or [square brackets] to distinguish them from [braces] { }.

cards.sideA: ¿Necesito usar guion bajo en esta parte? (_)

sideB.text: Do I need to use an underscore in this part?
Should I use an underscore here?

cards.note:
**[113]**

The '_' symbol is called an [underscore].

This is different from a [hyphen] (-) or a [dash] (—).

cards.sideA: Debes usar 2 barras ( / )

sideB.text: You need to use two slashes.
You should use two forward slashes.

cards.note:
**[113]**

The '/' symbol is a [slash] or [forward slash].

This is the opposite of a [backslash] (\).

cards.sideA: Puedes usar comillas dobles o comillas simples ( " ' )

sideB.text: You can use double quotes or single quotes.
You can use either double quotes or single quotes.

cards.note:
**[113]**

[Double quotes] = "..."
[Single quotes] = '...'

cards.sideA: ¿Debo usar comillas simples, o dobles? ( ' " )

sideB.text: Should I use single quotes or double quotes?
Do I need to use single quotes or double quotes?

cards.note:
**[113]**

[single quotes] (') and [double quotes] (".

cards.sideA: ¿Te queda poco? (tiempo/finalizando una tarea)

sideB.text: Are you almost done?
Are you nearly finished?
Do you only have a little left?
How much do you have left?
How many do you have left?

cards.note:
The most common translations ask for a Yes/No confirmation about a *task*: [Are you almost done?] or [Are you nearly finished?]

If asking about *quantity*, [Do you only have a little left?] is a common Yes/No check.

[How much/many do you have left?] are also valid, used when you assume the amount is small and want to know the *exact* small quantity remaining.

cards.sideA: ¿Te queda mucho? (cantidad)

sideB.text: How much do you have left?
How many do you have left?
Do you have a lot left?
Do you still have a long way to go?
Are you almost done?

cards.note:
This card shows the two main ways to ask:

1. Ask for *specific quantity*: [How much do you have left?] (for uncountables like time/work) or [How many do you have left?] (for countables like tasks/items).

2. Ask for *Yes/No confirmation*: [Do you have a lot left?]

[Do you still have a long way to go?] is a common idiom for large projects or tasks.

cards.sideA: Esa es la forma en que lo hacen los demás. (For People)

sideB.text: That's how everyone else does it.
That's the way everyone else does it.
That's just what everybody else does.
That's the standard way the others do it.
That's the way people do it.

cards.note:
The phrase 'los demás' translates to [everyone else] or [the others].

[How everyone else does it] is a very common structure.

A common error is a literal translation like ~That is the form that the others do it~. 'Form' is a false friend; the correct word is [way] or [how].

~That's the way how people do it.~ (Incorrect redundancy: You should use 'That's the way people do it' or 'That's how people do it', but never 'the way how' together.)

cards.sideA: Esa es la manera que usa el resto. / Eso es lo que todos los demas estan usando (For Things)

sideB.text: That's what everything else is using.
That's the method all the others use.
It's the standard that the rest [of the software] follows.
That's how the other [programs/tools] do it.

cards.note:
'El resto' (referring to things) translates to [the rest] or [all the others].

In a technical context, you can be more specific: [That's the standard the rest follow].

~That's the manner that the rest use~. 'Manner' is too formal; [way], [how], or [method] are more natural.

cards.sideA: Lo dejamos así simplemente 'por una cosa de tiempo'.

sideB.text: We left it like that simply because of time.
We left it as-is just because of a lack of time.
We had to leave it that way due to time constraints.
It was left like that just for time reasons.

cards.note:
'Por (una) cosa de tiempo' is an idiom. It translates to [because of time], [due to time constraints], or [for time reasons].

[As-is] is a common idiom meaning 'in its current condition' (tal como está).

A literal translation is unnatural: ~We left it like that only for a thing of time~.

cards.sideA: Estábamos cortos de tiempo, así que lo dejamos así.

sideB.text: We were short on time, so we left it like that.
It was just a matter of time, so we left it as-is.
We left it like that for now, just to save time.
Due to time, we left it like that.

cards.note:
[We were short on time] is a very natural way to express this.

[It was just a matter of time] is another common idiom.

~For time, we left it like that~ is an incorrect literal translation. Use [Due to time] or [Because of time].

cards.sideA: Esa función es diferente a la anterior.

sideB.text: That function is different from the previous one.
That function is different than the previous one.
This function isn't the same as the previous one.
That function differs from the previous one.

cards.note:
**[176]**

Both [different from] and [different than] are widely used. 'Different from' is traditionally considered more formal, but 'different than' is very common, especially in American English.

A common error is using the wrong preposition: ~That function is different to the previous one~ (more common in British English, but 'from'/'than' are preferred in AmE/tech) or ~...different at...~.

cards.sideA: ¿Eso que dices es diferente a lo anterior?

sideB.text: Is what you're saying different from the last point?
Is that different from what was said before?
Are you saying something different than before?
Is your point different from the previous one?

cards.note:
'Lo anterior' can refer to 'the last point', 'what was said before', or 'the previous one'.

Remember to use [different from] or [different than].

A common structural error is ~Is that you are saying different...?~. The correct structure is [Is what you're saying different...?]

cards.sideA: Yo no toqué eso.

sideB.text: I didn't touch that.
I didn't touch it.
It wasn't me who touched that.
I haven't touched that.

cards.note:
The simple past [I didn't touch that] is the most direct translation.

[It wasn't me who...] is used for strong emphasis or to correct an accusation.

[I haven't touched that] (Present Perfect) can also be used, implying 'I have not touched it at any point leading up to now'.

A common error is using the wrong negative structure: ~I no touched that~ or ~I didn't touched that~ (after 'didn't', use the base verb [touch]).

cards.sideA: Para ser honesto, no se mas sobre la compañía.

sideB.text: To be honest, I don't know much more about the company.
Honestly, I don't know anything else about the company.
To tell you the truth, I don't have any more info on the company.

cards.note:
[To be honest] and [Honestly] are the standard idioms for 'Para ser honesto/La verdad'.

Note the difference: 'No sé más' usually means [I don't know anything else] or [I don't know much more], not ~I don't know plus~.


~...I don't know more...~ sounds unnatural. Use [I don't know anything else] or [I don't know much more] to express the end of your knowledge.

cards.sideA: Asi que puedo tomar otro trabajo en la noche facilmente.

sideB.text: So I can easily pick up another job at night.
So I can take on another evening job easily.
That means I can easily get another job at night.

cards.note:
The phrasal verbs [pick up] or [take on] a job are very natural for casual or secondary employment.

Adverbs like [easily] often go before the main verb: [I can easily pick up...].

cards.sideA: Es esencial que documenten los pasos de Reproducción del defecto.

sideB.text: It is essential that they document the Steps to Reproduce the defect.
It's crucial to document the reproduction steps for the bug.
They essentially need to document how to reproduce the defect.

cards.note:
[Steps to Reproduce] is the standard technical term in QA tickets. ~Steps of reproduction~ is less common.

The structure [It is essential that they document...] is formal and correct.

cards.sideA: Es necesario que compartan los pasos de Reproducción del defecto.

sideB.text: It is necessary that they share the Steps to Reproduce the defect.
It's necessary for them to share the reproduction steps.
They need to share the steps to reproduce the bug.

cards.note:
You can use the structure [It is necessary for them to share...] or the simpler [They need to share...].

Avoid ~It is necessary that they shares~ (incorrect verb conjugation).

cards.sideA: Necesito preguntar: "¿Como reproducir el problema?"

sideB.text: I need to ask: 'How to reproduce the issue?'
I need to ask how to reproduce the problem.
I have to ask: 'How do you reproduce the bug?'

cards.note:
If asking directly, use the full question structure: [How do you reproduce...?].

If using the short form (headline style) in a ticket or list, [How to reproduce the issue] is acceptable.

cards.sideA: Es necesario depurar para encontrar la causa raiz del problema.

sideB.text: Debugging is necessary to find the root cause of the problem.
We need to debug to find the root cause.
It's necessary to debug to locate the root cause.

cards.note:
[Root cause] is the specific technical term for 'causa raíz'.

[Debugging] (gerund) acts as the subject. Alternatively, use [We need to debug].

cards.sideA: No sentía que estaba progresando en ese rol.

sideB.text: I didn't feel I was really progressing in that role.
I felt stuck, like the role wasn't letting me grow.
I didn't feel like I was moving forward in that position.
I didn't feel that I was really progressing in that role.

cards.note:
[Progressing] and [moving forward] are good translations for 'progresando'.

[I felt stuck] (me sentía estancado) is a very common idiom to express the lack of progress.

cards.sideA: Los errores cosméticos—como problemas de espaciado o colores, son de baja prioridad.

sideB.text: Cosmetic bugs—like spacing or color issues—are low priority.
Cosmetic errors, such as spacing or colors, are low priority.
Visual bugs like spacing or color problems are considered low priority.

cards.note:
[Cosmetic bugs] or [Cosmetic issues] refer to things that look wrong but work correctly.

[Low priority] is the standard classification. ~Low importance~ is less technical.

cards.sideA: Un bloqueo de producción—como problemas en el carro, son de alta prioridad.

sideB.text: A production blocker—like cart issues—is high priority.
A production blocker, such as an issue with the cart, is a high priority.
Production blockers like cart problems are top priority.

cards.note:
[Blocker] is a noun in IT meaning a bug that stops testing or usage.

[High priority] or [Top priority] are standard terms.

cards.sideA: Un bloqueo de alta prioridad en producción—se debe escalar inmediatamente.

sideB.text: A high priority production blocker must be escalated immediately.
We need to escalate high-priority production blockers immediately.
Any high-priority blocker in production has to be escalated right away.

cards.note:
[To escalate] means to pass the issue to a higher level of authority or technical support.

[Immediately] or [right away] emphasizes urgency.

cards.sideA: Un error cosmético de UI—se puede agendar y solucionar con más calma.

sideB.text: A cosmetic UI error can be scheduled and fixed with less urgency.
We can schedule cosmetic UI bugs to be fixed later.
Cosmetic UI issues can be prioritized for later.

cards.note:
[To schedule] in this context means to put it in the backlog for a future sprint.

[With less urgency] or [later] translates 'con más calma' in a professional context.

cards.sideA: Debo priorizar si es un error cosmético o un bloqueo de producción.

sideB.text: I have to prioritize if it's a cosmetic bug or a production blocker.
I need to determine if it's a cosmetic issue or a blocker.
I must prioritize based on whether it's cosmetic or a production blocker.

cards.note:
[Prioritize] means to decide the order of importance.

Using [whether... or...] is slightly more formal and precise than [if... or...], but both are used.

cards.sideA: Si un cliente me dice sobre un error...

sideB.text: If a client tells me about an issue...
If a client reports a bug...
If a client lets me know about an error...

cards.note:
[Reports a bug] is standard industry terminology.

~If a client says me~ is incorrect. You [tell someone] or [say to someone].

cards.sideA: Si un usuario normal todavía puede hacer lo que necesita, es cosmético.

sideB.text: If a normal user can still get what they need done, it's cosmetic.
If a standard user can still perform their tasks, it's a cosmetic issue.
It's cosmetic if a regular user can still do what they need to do.

cards.note:
[Get what they need done] is a very natural way to express 'hacer lo que necesitan'.

[Standard user] or [Regular user] are good translations for 'usuario normal'.

cards.sideA: Si un usuario normal no puede hacer lo que necesita, es un bloqueo.

sideB.text: If a normal user can't get what they need done, it's a blocker.
If a regular user is unable to complete their task, it's a blocker.
It's a blocker if a standard user can't do what they need.
If a normal user can't do what they need, it's a blocker.

cards.note:
In this context, [a blocker] acts as a noun (un bloqueo).

~Is a locking~ is unnatural; use [Blocker].

cards.sideA: Como estaba diciendo, como es solo un error cosmético, necesitamos...

sideB.text: As I was saying, since it's just a cosmetic bug, we need to...
As I mentioned, because this is only a cosmetic error, we need to...
Like I said, as it's just cosmetic, we need to...

cards.note:
[As I was saying] is excellent for resuming a point after an interruption.

Avoid using 'how' for cause. ~How is a cosmetic bug...~ is incorrect. Use [Since], [As], or [Because].

cards.sideA: Como es un bloqueo en producción, necesitamos...

sideB.text: Since it's a production blocker, we need to...
Because it's a production blocker, we need to...
As this is a blocker in production, we must...

cards.note:
Use [Since] or [Because] to explain the reason.

[In production] refers to the live environment.

cards.sideA: Ese es un fallo funcional—no bloquea a nadie, pero los números no cuadran.

sideB.text: That's a functional glitch—it's not blocking anyone, but the numbers are off.
That's a functional bug; it doesn't block users, but the numbers don't add up.
It's a functional issue—nobody is blocked, but the figures are incorrect.

cards.note:
[Glitch] is often used for minor, transient, or strange errors.

[The numbers are off] is a very common idiom meaning calculations are incorrect.

[Don't add up] also means the math is wrong or the situation doesn't make sense.

~the numbers don't fit~ is unnatural because 'fit' refers to physical size. For calculations, use [don't add up] or [are off].

cards.sideA: Como es un fallo funcional, es de media prioridad.

sideB.text: Since it's a functional glitch, it's medium priority.
Because it's a functional error, it's medium priority.
As it is a functional bug, we'll treat it as medium priority.

cards.note:
[Medium priority] is the standard classification between Low and High.

Use [Since] or [Because] to link the cause (functional glitch) to the effect (priority).

cards.sideA: Debo contener al cliente en Japón y Corea.

sideB.text: I must manage the client in Japan and Korea.
I need to keep the client in Japan and Korea contained.
My role involves managing expectations for clients in Japan and Korea.
I need to contain the client in Japan and Korea.

cards.note:
To [contain] a client in an IT context often means to manage their anxiety or keep a situation under control. [Manage expectations] is also a very professional alternative.

~I must to contain~ is incorrect. Modal verbs like [must] are followed directly by the verb.

~...client from Japan...~ (Preposition: 'En Japón' translates to 'in Japan' (location). 'From Japan' implies origin.)

cards.sideA: Debo ser el puente entre Japón, Corea y usted en EE. UU.

sideB.text: I must be the bridge between Japan, Korea, and you in the USA.
I need to act as the liaison between Japan, Korea, and your team in the US.
My job is to serve as the link between Japan, Korea, and the US side.

cards.note:
[Liaison] is a high-level professional term for 'puente' or 'enlace' in business communication.

Preposition: [Between] is used when connecting distinct entities (Japan, Korea, and USA).

cards.sideA: Lo primero es definir la prioridad: baja, media o alta.

sideB.text: The first step is to define the priority: low, medium, or high.
First, I need to determine the priority level: low, medium, or high.
The first thing to do is assess the severity and set the priority: low, medium, or high.

cards.note:
[First step] or [First thing] are natural ways to start a process description.

[Assess the severity] is a strong technical phrase often used before assigning a priority.

cards.sideA: Le pediría al cliente que abra un ticket.

sideB.text: I would ask the client to open a ticket.
I'd request the client to submit a support ticket.
I would tell the client to log a ticket for the issue.
I would have the client open a ticket.

cards.note:
Standard verbs for tickets: [Open], [Submit], [Log], or [Raise].

Structure: [Ask someone TO DO something]. ~Ask that the client opens~ is possible but less common in spoken English.

~I would ask to the client...~ (Incorrect grammar: We say 'ask someone', not 'ask to someone'. Correct: 'ask the client'.)

cards.sideA: Si veo que el problema es grave, le pediría más información.

sideB.text: If I see that the problem is serious, I would ask for more information.
If I notice it's a critical issue, I'd request further details.
If the issue appears severe, I would ask for more context.
If I see that the problem is serious, I would ask for further information.

cards.note:
Conditionals: [If I see... I would ask] (Mixed conditional often used in interviews to describe hypothetical reactions to real situations).

Vocabulary: [Critical] or [Severe] are excellent synonyms for 'grave' in IT.

~...ask further information~ (Grammar: The verb 'ask' requires the preposition 'for' when requesting something: 'ask for information'.)

cards.sideA: Le pediría más información para tener un resumen más completo del problema.

sideB.text: I would ask for more information to have a more complete summary of the problem.
I'd request more details to get a full picture of the issue.
I would ask for further info to ensure I have a comprehensive overview of the situation.
I would ask for more information to have a much more complete summary of the issue.

cards.note:
[To get a full picture] is a great idiom for understanding the whole situation.

[Comprehensive overview] sounds very professional in an interview setting.

~...summary much more complete...~ (Word order: Adjectives usually come before the noun, e.g., 'a much more complete summary'.)

cards.sideA: Luego le diría al cliente que me contactaré con el DBA o el encargado de redes.

sideB.text: Then I would tell the client that I will contact the DBA or the Network manager.
After that, I'd inform the client that I'm reaching out to the DBA or the Network lead.
Then I'd let the client know I'll get in touch with the DBA or the Networking team.

cards.note:
Phrasal Verb: [Reach out to] or [Get in touch with] are very natural alternatives to [Contact].

Structure: [Tell the client THAT...]. Avoid ~Tell to the client~.

cards.sideA: Tengo que definir el área, por ejemplo, si es de redes o DBA.

sideB.text: I have to define the area, for example, if it is Networks or DBA.
I need to identify the domain, for instance, whether it's a Network or Database issue.
I must determine the responsible team, like Networking or the DBA group.

cards.note:
[Identify the domain] or [Determine the responsible team] shows analytical skills.

DBA stands for [Database Administrator].

cards.sideA: También puedo verificar si el problema es específico de ellos o es general.

sideB.text: I can also verify if the problem is specific to them or if it is general.
I can also check if it's an isolated issue or a widespread one.
I would also investigate whether the issue is local to them or affecting everyone.
I can also verify if the problem is specific to them or it is for everyone.

cards.note:
IT Vocabulary: [Isolated] (specific to one user/area) vs. [Widespread] (affecting many).

Use [Check] or [Investigate] as synonyms for verify.

~...specific for them...~ (Collocation: When describing exclusivity or limitation, use 'specific to'.)

cards.sideA: También puedo verificar si el problema es para Japón o general para todos.

sideB.text: I can also verify if the problem is for Japan or general for everyone.
I can also check if the issue is region-specific to Japan or global.
I need to confirm if it's just affecting Japan or if it's a global outage.

cards.note:
[Region-specific] is a precise technical term.

[Global outage] implies the system is down for everyone.

~...problem is from Japan...~ (Preposition error: Use 'in Japan' for location. 'From' implies origin.)

cards.sideA: Luego de recibir la respuesta del DBA, puedo comunicarme con el cliente.

sideB.text: After receiving the response from the DBA, I can communicate with the client.
Once I hear back from the DBA, I can get back to the client.
Upon getting a reply from the DBA, I'll update the client.
After receiving the answer from the DBA, I can communicate with the client.

cards.note:
**[176]**

Phrasal Verbs: [Hear back from] (receive a reply) and [Get back to] (respond to someone) are essential for fluent communication.

[Update the client] is more active and professional than just 'communicate'.

cards.sideA: Luego de recibir la respuesta del encargado de redes, puedo darle una respuesta al cliente.

sideB.text: After receiving the response from the Network manager, I can give an answer to the client.
Once the Network lead responds, I can provide the client with an update.
After getting the info from the Network team, I can relay the answer to the client.
After receiving the response from the Network Team, I can provide an answer to the client.

cards.note:
[Relay the answer] means to pass information from one person to another.

[Provide an update] is standard customer service language.

cards.sideA: Nuestro principal medio de comunicación será Microsoft Teams.

sideB.text: Our main means of communication will be Microsoft Teams.
Our primary communication channel will be Microsoft Teams.
We will primarily use Microsoft Teams to communicate.
Our main tool of communication will be Microsoft Teams.

cards.note:
[Primary communication channel] sounds very professional.

Use [Will be] for established future plans.

cards.sideA: Nuestro principal medio de comunicación será por chat o llamadas por Teams.

sideB.text: Our main means of communication will be via chat or Teams calls.
We'll communicate mainly through Teams chat or calls.
Our primary contact methods will be Teams chat and calls.
We will mainly use Microsoft Teams for communication.
Our main tool of communication will be Microsoft Teams.

cards.note:
[Via] is a useful preposition meaning 'by way of' (e.g., via chat, via email).

[Through] is also commonly used (e.g., through Teams).

~Our main tool... will be by Microsoft team~ (Correction: 1. The app is called 'Teams' (plural). 2. Don't say 'the tool will be by'. Say: 'Our main tool is Teams' or 'We use Teams'.)

~...tool... will be on/by Microsoft Teams~ (Grammar: A tool is not 'by' the software. We communicate 'on' or 'via' Teams, but the tool *is* Teams.)

cards.sideA: Para ser honesto, no se mas sobre la compañía.

sideB.text: To be honest, I don't know much more about the company.
Honestly, I don't know anything else about the company.
To tell you the truth, I don't have any more info on the company.

cards.note:
[To be honest] and [Honestly] are the standard idioms for 'Para ser honesto/La verdad'.

Note the difference: 'No sé más' usually means [I don't know anything else] or [I don't know much more], not ~I don't know plus~.

~To be honest, I don't know more about the company.~ (Incomplete phrasing: Use 'anything else' or 'much more' to express lack of further information.)

cards.sideA: Asi que puedo tomar otro trabajo en la noche facilmente.

sideB.text: So I can easily pick up another job at night.
So I can take on another evening job easily.
That means I can easily get another job at night.
So, I can take another job at night easily.

cards.note:
The phrasal verbs [pick up] or [take on] a job are very natural for casual or secondary employment.

Adverbs like [easily] often go before the main verb: [I can easily pick up...].

cards.sideA: Es esencial que documenten los pasos de Reproducción del defecto.

sideB.text: It is essential that they document the Steps to Reproduce the defect.
It's crucial to document the reproduction steps for the bug.
They essentially need to document how to reproduce the defect.

cards.note:
[Steps to Reproduce] is the standard technical term in QA tickets. ~Steps of reproduction~ is less common.

The structure [It is essential that they document...] is formal and correct.

cards.sideA: Es necesario que compartan los pasos de Reproducción del defecto.

sideB.text: It is necessary that they share the Steps to Reproduce the defect.
It's necessary for them to share the reproduction steps.
They need to share the steps to reproduce the bug.

cards.note:
You can use the structure [It is necessary for them to share...] or the simpler [They need to share...].

Avoid ~It is necessary that they shares~ (incorrect verb conjugation).

cards.sideA: Necesito preguntar: "¿Como reproducir el problema?"

sideB.text: I need to ask: 'How to reproduce the issue?'
I need to ask how to reproduce the problem.
I have to ask: 'How do you reproduce the bug?'

cards.note:
If asking directly, use the full question structure: [How do you reproduce...?].

If using the short form (headline style) in a ticket or list, [How to reproduce the issue] is acceptable.

cards.sideA: Es necesario depurar para encontrar la causa raiz del problema.

sideB.text: Debugging is necessary to find the root cause of the problem.
We need to debug to find the root cause.
It's necessary to debug to locate the root cause.

cards.note:
[Root cause] is the specific technical term for 'causa raíz'.

[Debugging] (gerund) acts as the subject. Alternatively, use [We need to debug].

cards.sideA: No sentía que estaba progresando en ese rol.

sideB.text: I didn't feel I was really progressing in that role.
I felt stuck, like the role wasn't letting me grow.
I didn't feel like I was moving forward in that position.
I felt like I wasn't really progressing in that role.
I didn't feel like I was progressing at all in that role.
I felt stagnant in that role.

cards.note:
[Progressing] and [moving forward] are good translations for 'progresando'.

[I felt stuck] (me sentía estancado) is a very common idiom to express the lack of progress.

cards.sideA: Los errores cosméticos—como problemas de espaciado o colores, son de baja prioridad.

sideB.text: Cosmetic bugs—like spacing or color issues—are low priority.
Cosmetic errors, such as spacing or colors, are low priority.
Visual bugs like spacing or color problems are considered low priority.

cards.note:
[Cosmetic bugs] or [Cosmetic issues] refer to things that look wrong but work correctly.

[Low priority] is the standard classification. ~Low importance~ is less technical.

~...space or color bugs...~ (Vocabulary: In UI/Design, use 'spacing' to refer to the distance between elements. 'Space' usually refers to the outer void or available room.)

cards.sideA: Un bloqueo de producción—como problemas en el carro, son de alta prioridad.

sideB.text: A production blocker—like cart issues—is high priority.
A production blocker, such as an issue with the cart, is a high priority.
Production blockers like cart problems are top priority.

cards.note:
[Blocker] is a noun in IT meaning a bug that stops testing or usage.

[High priority] or [Top priority] are standard terms.

cards.sideA: Un bloqueo de alta prioridad en producción—se debe escalar inmediatamente.

sideB.text: A high priority production blocker must be escalated immediately.
We need to escalate high-priority production blockers immediately.
Any high-priority blocker in production has to be escalated right away.

cards.note:
[To escalate] means to pass the issue to a higher level of authority or technical support.

[Immediately] or [right away] emphasizes urgency.

cards.sideA: Un error cosmético de UI—se puede agendar y solucionar con más calma.

sideB.text: A cosmetic UI error can be scheduled and fixed with less urgency.
We can schedule cosmetic UI bugs to be fixed later.
Cosmetic UI issues can be prioritized for later.

cards.note:
[To schedule] in this context means to put it in the backlog for a future sprint.

[With less urgency] or [later] translates 'con más calma' in a professional context.

~A cosmetic issue of UI~ (Word Order: Use 'UI issue' or 'UI error'. In English, nouns often act as adjectives before the main noun.)

cards.sideA: Debo priorizar si es un error cosmético o un bloqueo de producción.

sideB.text: I have to prioritize if it's a cosmetic bug or a production blocker.
I need to determine if it's a cosmetic issue or a blocker.
I must prioritize based on whether it's cosmetic or a production blocker.

cards.note:
[Prioritize] means to decide the order of importance.

Using [whether... or...] is slightly more formal and precise than [if... or...], but both are used.

cards.sideA: Si un cliente me dice sobre un error...

sideB.text: If a client tells me about an issue...
If a client reports a bug...
If a client lets me know about an error...

cards.note:
[Reports a bug] is standard industry terminology.

~If a client says me~ is incorrect. You [tell someone] or [say to someone].

cards.sideA: Si un usuario normal todavía puede hacer lo que necesita, es cosmético.

sideB.text: If a normal user can still get what they need done, it's cosmetic.
If a standard user can still perform their tasks, it's a cosmetic issue.
It's cosmetic if a regular user can still do what they need to do.
If a normal user can still do what they need, it's cosmetic.

cards.note:
[Get what they need done] is a very natural way to express 'hacer lo que necesitan'.

[Standard user] or [Regular user] are good translations for 'usuario normal'.

cards.sideA: Si un usuario normal no puede hacer lo que necesita, es un bloqueo.

sideB.text: If a normal user can't get what they need done, it's a blocker.
If a regular user is unable to complete their task, it's a blocker.
It's a blocker if a standard user can't do what they need.
If a normal user can't do what they need, it's a blocker.

cards.note:
In this context, [a blocker] acts as a noun (un bloqueo).

~Is a locking~ is unnatural; use [Blocker].

cards.sideA: Como estaba diciendo, como es solo un error cosmético, necesitamos...

sideB.text: As I was saying, since it's just a cosmetic bug, we need to...
As I mentioned, because this is only a cosmetic error, we need to...
Like I said, as it's just cosmetic, we need to...

cards.note:
[As I was saying] is excellent for resuming a point after an interruption.

Avoid using 'how' for cause. ~How is a cosmetic bug...~ is incorrect. Use [Since], [As], or [Because].

~...how it is just...~ (False Friend: 'How' is not used for causation here. Use 'since', 'as', or 'because' to translate 'como' in this context.)

cards.sideA: Como es un bloqueo en producción, necesitamos...

sideB.text: Since it's a production blocker, we need to...
Because it's a production blocker, we need to...
As this is a blocker in production, we must...
Because this is blocking production, we need to...

cards.note:
Use [Since] or [Because] to explain the reason.

[In production] refers to the live environment.

~Since it's a blocker production...~ (Incorrect word order: Use 'production blocker' or 'blocker in production'. Adjectives usually go before nouns.)

cards.sideA: Ese es un fallo funcional—no bloquea a nadie, pero los números no cuadran.

sideB.text: That's a functional glitch—it's not blocking anyone, but the numbers are off.
That's a functional bug; it doesn't block users, but the numbers don't add up.
It's a functional issue—nobody is blocked, but the figures are incorrect.
That's a functional glitch—it doesn't block anyone, but the numbers are off.
It's a functional glitch; no one is blocked, but there is a discrepancy in the numbers.

cards.note:
[Glitch] is often used for minor, transient, or strange errors.

[The numbers are off] is a very common idiom meaning calculations are incorrect.

[Don't add up] also means the math is wrong or the situation doesn't make sense.


~...the numbers don't fit~ is incorrect because 'fit' refers to physical size or space. Use [don't add up] or [are off] for calculations.

cards.sideA: Como es un fallo funcional, es de media prioridad.

sideB.text: Since it's a functional glitch, it's medium priority.
Because it's a functional error, it's medium priority.
As it is a functional bug, we'll treat it as medium priority.
Since it's a functional glitch, the priority is medium.
Given that it is a functional glitch, we will classify it as medium priority.

cards.note:
[Medium priority] is the standard classification between Low and High.

Use [Since] or [Because] to link the cause (functional glitch) to the effect (priority).

cards.sideA: El flujo de usuario que desencadena el problema.

sideB.text: The user flow that triggers the issue.
The user journey that causes the problem.
The sequence of actions that sets off the bug.

cards.note:
[User flow] or [User journey] are standard terms for the path a user takes in the application.

[Triggers] is the specific technical verb for causing a piece of code or event to run. ~The flow that starts the problem~ is less precise.

cards.sideA: Necesito saber el exacto flujo del usuario para desencadenar el problema.

sideB.text: I need to know the exact user flow to trigger the issue.
I need to understand the precise steps the user took to cause the problem.
I require the exact user path that sets off the error.

cards.note:
Use [Exact] or [Precise] to emphasize the need for detail in debugging.

Structure: [To trigger the issue] indicates the purpose/result of the flow.

cards.sideA: Necesito saber cómo reproducir o desencadenar el problema.

sideB.text: I need to know how to reproduce or trigger the issue.
I need to figure out how to replicate or set off the problem.
I must know how to recreate or trigger the bug.

cards.note:
[Reproduce] and [Replicate] are the most common verbs in QA to describe copying the error conditions.

[Set off] is a good phrasal verb synonym for [Trigger].

cards.sideA: Entiendo que en este rol debo ser muy proactivo.

sideB.text: I understand that I must be quite proactive in this role.
I realize that I need to be very proactive in this position.
I understand that high proactivity is required in this role.
I understand that I need to be really proactive in this role.

cards.note:
[Quite] usually means 'very' or 'considerably' in this context.

[Proactive] (taking initiative) is a key soft skill keyword for senior roles.

cards.sideA: Mientras tanto, empiezo a replicar los pasos exactos en mi propia máquina.

sideB.text: So, meanwhile I start replicating the exact steps on my own machine.
In the meantime, I'll begin reproducing the exact steps on my local machine.
Meanwhile, I am starting to replicate the specific steps on my computer.

cards.note:
[Meanwhile] or [In the meantime] connects two simultaneous actions (the user talking/waiting and you testing).

[Local machine] or [My own machine] refers to your development environment.

cards.sideA: Hola, gracias, lo estoy comprobando/revisando ahora mismo.

sideB.text: Hi, thanks—checking right now.
Hello, thanks. I'm looking into it right now.
Hi, thank you. I am checking on that immediately.
Hi, thanks— I'm checking it right now.

cards.note:
[Looking into it] is a professional phrasal verb meaning to investigate.

In chat contexts (Teams/Slack), omitting the subject [I am] (e.g., 'Checking right now') is acceptable and common.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes compartir tu flujo de usuario?

sideB.text: Can you share your user flow?
Could you please share the user flow you followed?
Would you mind sharing your user path?

cards.note:
[Could you] or [Would you mind] makes the request more polite than just 'Can you'.

[User flow] is the standard term for the sequence of steps.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes describir exactamente lo que hiciste?

sideB.text: Can you describe exactly what you did?
Could you explain the exact actions you took?
Can you detail precisely what you did?

cards.note:
[Actions you took] is a formal way to say 'what you did'.

~Can you describe me~ is incorrect. You describe [something] TO [someone], or just describe [something].

cards.sideA: Lo intentaré ahora mismo y veré si obtengo el mismo problema/error.

sideB.text: I'll try it right now and see if I get the same issue.
I'm going to attempt it immediately to see if I encounter the same error.
I will try that now and check if I face the same problem.

cards.note:
[Encounter an error] or [Face a problem] are good alternatives to 'get'.

[I'll try it] (Future with Will) is used for decisions made at the moment of speaking.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes darme exactamente los pasos que hiciste para llegar ahí?

sideB.text: Can you give me the exact steps you took to get there?
Could you provide the specific steps you followed to reach that point?
Can you tell me the exact steps you took to arrive at that state?
Can you give me the exact steps to get there?

cards.note:
[Steps you took] is the colocation for 'pasos que hiciste'. ~Steps you made~ is unnatural.

[To get there] refers to arriving at the error state.

~...steps that you did...~ (Collocation: We 'take' or 'follow' steps, we do not 'do' them.)

~...steps you got to get there...~ (Vocabulary: We 'take' steps, we do not 'get' them. 'Got to get' is also repetitive.)

cards.sideA: Estoy siguiendo los pasos justo ahora.

sideB.text: I'm following along right now.
I'm following the steps right now.
I am going through the steps at this very moment.
I'm executing the steps right now.

cards.note:
[Following along] implies you are doing the action in parallel with the description or the other person.

[Going through the steps] is a common phrasal verb for executing a procedure.

~I'm following along the steps...~ (Phrasing: 'Follow along' is usually intransitive. Say 'I'm following the steps' or just 'I'm following along'.)

cards.sideA: El stock real de los productos está en los almacenes físicos.

sideB.text: The real product stock is located in the physical warehouses.
Physical on-hand quantity is stored within the Inventory Organizations.
The actual inventory is managed at the warehouse level.
The real product stock is in the warehouses.

cards.note:
In Oracle EBS terminology, 'warehouses' are often referred to as [Inventory Organizations].

[On-hand quantity] is the technical term for 'stock real' or 'existencias'.

cards.sideA: Las definiciones de los productos, como el SKU y la unidad de medida, se encuentran en una tabla maestra.

sideB.text: Product definitions, such as SKU and UOM, are found in a master table.
Item attributes like SKU and UOM are defined in the Master Item Organization table.
The Master Layer holds the product DNA, including SKU and UOM details.
Product definitions, such as SKU and UOM, are in a master table.

cards.note:
[UOM] stands for Unit of Measure (Unit, Box, Kg, etc.).

[SKU] (Stock Keeping Unit) is the standard term for the product code.

cards.sideA: Las definiciones de los productos (su ADN) y su stock están en tablas distintas.

sideB.text: Product definitions (their DNA) and their stock levels are stored in separate tables.
We separate the item master data from the physical on-hand quantities into different tables.
The Master Item table defines the product, while a different table tracks the physical inventory.
Product definitions (their DNA) and their stock are in different tables.
Product definitions and inventory levels reside in distinct tables.

cards.note:
[Master Data] (definitions) vs [Transactional Data] (stock levels) is a key concept in database design.

[Stored in] is the standard preposition for data in tables.

cards.sideA: El stock de los productos está en los almacenes y cada provincia tiene uno diferente.

sideB.text: Product stock is in the warehouses, and each province has its own specific inventory.
Inventory is managed in warehouses, with different Inventory Organizations for each province.
Stock availability is physical and varies because each province points to a different warehouse.
Product stock is in the warehouses, and each province has a different one.

cards.note:
[Points to] is a useful phrasal verb when describing software configuration or database relationships.

[Varies] means 'is different' or 'changes'.

cards.sideA: El carrito es solo una cotización del momento, y la orden de venta en sí, ya es diferente.

sideB.text: The shopping cart is just a temporary Quote, whereas the Sales Order is a separate, finalized entity.
The active cart acts as a snapshot Quote in ASO, which is distinct from the actual Sales Order in OM.
A cart is technically a draft Quote, while the confirmed transaction becomes a Sales Order.

cards.note:
In Oracle, a [Quote] is a proposal of prices, while a [Sales Order] is a confirmed contract.

[Whereas] is an excellent linking word to show contrast between two distinct things (Cart vs Order).

cards.sideA: Oracle EBS es el sistema central (backend) que gestiona todos los datos de negocio.

sideB.text: Oracle EBS is the core backend system that manages all business data.
Oracle EBS acts as the central engine handling business logic, including Inventory and Order Management.
All critical business data, from stock levels to sales orders, is centrally managed by the Oracle EBS backend.

cards.note:
[Core backend system] or [Central engine] are strong terms to describe the importance of the ERP.

[Handling business logic] is a precise way to describe what the backend does.

cards.sideA: iStore es el módulo de comercio electrónico que permite a los usuarios navegar por el catálogo y realizar pedidos.

sideB.text: iStore is the e-commerce module that allows users to browse the catalog and place orders via the web.
The iStore module provides the web interface for customers to browse the catalog and submit orders.
Users interact with the product catalog and place web orders through the Oracle iStore module.

cards.note:
[Browse] is the standard verb for looking through a website or catalog.

[Place orders] or [Submit orders] is the correct collocation. ~Make orders~ is less professional.

cards.sideA: En Oracle, el 'carrito de compras' es técnicamente una Cotización gestionada por el módulo ASO.

sideB.text: In Oracle, the 'shopping cart' is technically a Quote managed by the ASO module.
What the user sees as a 'shopping cart' is stored as a Quote record within the ASO module.
The ASO module handles the shopping cart functionality by treating it as an active Quote.

cards.note:
[Technically] is used to introduce the specific internal implementation details.

ASO stands for [Advanced Sales Online] (or Oracle Quoting).

cards.sideA: Al hacer checkout, la Cotización (ASO) se convierte en una Orden de Venta real en el módulo de Order Management.

sideB.text: Upon checkout, the Quote (ASO) is converted into an actual Sales Order in the Order Management (OM) module.
The checkout process triggers the conversion of the ASO Quote into a confirmed Sales Order in OM.
Data moves from the ASO module to the Order Management (OM) module when the Quote becomes a Booked Order.
When checking out, the Quote becomes an actual Sales Order.
Upon completing checkout, the Quote turns into a Sales Order.
The Quote becomes a Sales Order at checkout.
Checkout turns the Quote into a Sales Order.
After checkout, the Quote converts to a Sales Order.

cards.note:
[Upon checkout] is a formal way to say 'when doing checkout'.

[Triggers the conversion] describes the automatic process started by the user's action.

~Doing checkout...~ (Unnatural grammar: Use 'When checking out' or 'Upon checkout'.)

cards.sideA: Tomo la retroalimentación como una oportunidad para mejorar.

sideB.text: I take feedback as a chance to get better.
I view feedback as an opportunity to improve.
I see feedback as a way to grow professionally.
I take feedback as an opportunity to grow.

cards.note:
[Chance] is slightly more casual than [Opportunity], but both are excellent here.

[To get better] is the most natural translation for 'mejorar' in a personal context.

cards.sideA: Deberían contratarme porque soy proactivo y aprendo rápido.

sideB.text: You should hire me because I'm proactive and I learn fast.
I'm a strong candidate because I take initiative and pick things up quickly.
You should hire me because of my proactivity and quick learning curve.

cards.note:
[Pick things up] is a very common native phrasal verb for 'learning new things'.

[Take initiative] is a synonym for being proactive.

cards.sideA: No los decepcionaré.

sideB.text: I won't let you down.
I won't disappoint you.
I will not let the team down.

cards.note:
[Let someone down] is the most natural English idiom for 'decepcionar a alguien'.

[Disappoint] is correct but can sound a bit stiff in spoken conversation.

cards.sideA: El historial de pedidos mostraba precios del carrito, no los precios finales.

sideB.text: The order history was showing cart prices, not final prices.
The order history displayed Quote prices instead of the booked Order prices.
The history page was incorrectly pulling prices from the cart rather than the final order.
The order history showed cart prices, not final prices.

cards.note:
[Instead of] (en lugar de) helps clarify the discrepancy.

[Pulling prices from] means the system was retrieving data from that specific source.

cards.sideA: Arreglé la query para que extraiga datos de Order Management.

sideB.text: I fixed the query so it pulls from Order Management.
I corrected the SQL to fetch data from the Order Management tables.
I adjusted the query to retrieve information from OM.
I fixed the query to get data from Order Management.
I fixed the query to retrieve data from Order Management.
I fixed the query to extract data from Order Management.

cards.note:
**[176]**

Verbs for data: [Pull], [Fetch], [Retrieve], or [Extract].

[Fixed] implies repairing code that was broken or incorrect.

cards.sideA: Necesito entender el problema completamente.

sideB.text: I need to understand the problem completely.
I need to fully grasp the issue.
I need to get a complete understanding of the problem.
I need to fully understand the problem.

cards.note:
[Grasp] is a strong verb meaning to understand a complex concept fully.

[Issue] is often used interchangeably with 'problem' in IT.

cards.sideA: Si necesito más información, como pasos o capturas, le pregunto a quien reportó por Teams de inmediato.

sideB.text: If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the reporter on Teams right away.
If I require further details, such as reproduction steps, I contact the reporter immediately via Teams.
When I need more context, like screenshots, I reach out to the reporter on Teams instantly.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the one who reported it on Teams.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask who reported it on Teams.

cards.note:
[Reporter] refers to the person who created the ticket/bug report.

[Right away] or [Instantly] emphasizes your responsiveness.

~I ask to who reported it...~ (Incorrect grammar: You 'ask someone', you do not 'ask to someone'.)

~...I ask to the one who reported it...~ (Same error: The verb [ask] takes a direct object. Correct: 'I ask the one...' or 'I ask the person...')

cards.sideA: Intento replicarlo yo mismo, o si me supera, lo escalo.

sideB.text: I try to replicate it myself, or if it's out of my depth, I escalate it.
I attempt to reproduce it, but if it's beyond my knowledge, I escalate.
I try to replicate it, and if it's too complex, I pass it up the chain.
I try to replicate it by myself, or if it is too much for me, I escalate it.
I try to replicate it myself, or if it's out of my scope, I escalate it.

cards.note:
[Out of my depth] is a great idiom meaning the situation is beyond your current capability or knowledge.

[Escalate] is the professional term for sending a ticket to a higher support tier.

~ ... or if it is to much for me... ~ (Incorrect spelling: 'to much' should be 'too much'.)

cards.sideA: Uso System.out.println para depurar en el log del servidor (Java).

sideB.text: I use System.out.println for debugging in the server log.
I use print statements to debug backend issues in the server logs.
For server-side debugging, I rely on System.out.println.

cards.note:
This refers to [Backend] debugging in Java contexts.

[Server log] (like Catalan/Tomcat logs) is where these messages appear.

cards.sideA: Uso out.println para depurar en el navegador web (JSP).

sideB.text: I use out.println for debugging directly in the web browser.
For JSP debugging, I use out.println to see values in the browser.
I utilize out.println to debug frontend logic in the browser.

cards.note: This refers to [JSP] (JavaServer Pages) where `out` is an implicit object usually rendering to the [Frontend].

cards.sideA: PL/SQL en EBS era mucho más profundo de lo que había visto; solo sabía lo básico de la universidad.

sideB.text: PL/SQL with EBS was way deeper than I'd seen—I only knew basics from school.
The PL/SQL in EBS was much more complex than what I learned in college.
EBS PL/SQL went far beyond the basic knowledge I had from school.
PL/SQL with EBS was much deeper than I thought — I only knew the basics from school.
I was only familiar with the basics from university.

cards.note:
[Way deeper] is a common colloquial way to say 'much more complex/profound'.

~...than I saw...~ (Grammar: Use [than I had seen] (past perfect) to refer to the time before you started working with EBS.)

~...I only knew basics from school.~ (Grammar: You need the definite article 'the' before 'basics'. Correct: 'I only knew the basics'.)

cards.sideA: Yo diría: 'Gracias, revisando ahora. Te aviso en cuanto tenga novedades'.

sideB.text: I'd say: 'Thanks—checking now. I'll let you know as soon as I have an update.'
I would reply: 'Thanks, looking into it. I'll keep you posted.'
My response would be: 'Thanks. Checking now. I'll get back to you shortly.'
I'd say: 'Thanks—checking now. I'll let you know as soon as I get any updates.'

cards.note:
[I'll keep you posted] is an excellent idiom for 'te mantendré informado'.

[As soon as I have an update] is standard professional phrasing.

~I'll let you know as soon as I get news.~ (Unnatural phrasing: In a professional context, use 'have an update' or 'hear back'. 'Get news' sounds like you are waiting for a broadcast.)

cards.sideA: Soy proactivo, persistente y aprendo rápido nuevas tecnologías.

sideB.text: I am proactive, persistent, and quick to learn new tech.
I'm proactive, persistent, and I pick up new technologies fast.
I have a proactive and persistent mindset, and I learn new tech quickly.

cards.note:
[Quick to learn] or [Fast learner] are key phrases for interviews.

[Persistent] means you don't give up easily on difficult problems.

cards.sideA: Mi inglés sigue mejorando, y en reuniones grandes tiendo a quedarme callado.

sideB.text: My English is still improving, and in big meetings I tend to stay quiet.
I'm still working on my English, so I tend to be quieter in large meetings.
My English is a work in progress, and I tend to listen more than speak in big groups.
My English keeps improving, and in big meetings I tend to stay quiet.

cards.note:
[Tend to] describes a habit or inclination.

[Work in progress] is a positive way to say something is not yet perfect but is improving.

cards.sideA: La especificación del paquete no se ha actualizado correctamente.

sideB.text: The package specification hasn't been updated correctly.
The package spec failed to update properly.
There was an issue updating the package specification.

cards.note:
In PL/SQL, a package has a [Specification] (header) and a [Body].

[Spec] is the common short form.

cards.sideA: El campo del registro no se ha actualizado correctamente.

sideB.text: The record field has not been updated correctly.
The field in the record didn't update as expected.
The record field failed to update properly.

cards.note:
[As expected] is standard terminology in bug reports to describe the desired behavior versus the actual behavior.

~The registered field...~ (Incorrect meaning: 'Registered field' implies the field itself is registered. Use 'The record field' or 'The field in the record'.)

cards.sideA: Eso es todo por mi parte, gracias.

sideB.text: That's all for me, thanks.
That's everything from my side, thank you.
That's all on my end, thanks.

cards.note:
Use [On my end] or [From my side] to refer to your part of the conversation or task.

~That's all on my side, thanks.~ (Unnatural phrasing: The correct idioms are 'from my side' or 'on my end'.)

cards.sideA: No por mi parte, gracias. (Respuesta a '¿Alguna pregunta?')

sideB.text: No on my end, thank you.
None from me, thanks.
Nothing from my side, thank you.
Not on my end.

cards.note:
Standard polite responses when asked "Do you have any questions?" in a meeting.

~No on my side.~ (Unnatural: Use 'None on my side' or 'Nothing on my side'. 'No' implies a vote.)

cards.sideA: No, creo que cubrimos todo.

sideB.text: No, I think we've covered everything.
No, I believe we went over everything.
No, I think that covers it all.

cards.note:
[Covered everything] means all topics have been discussed.

[Went over] is a phrasal verb meaning 'reviewed' or 'discussed'.

cards.sideA: Nada más por ahora. Gracias.

sideB.text: Nothing else for now. Thanks.
That's all for the moment. Thank you.
Nothing more at this time. Thanks.

cards.note: [For now] implies that you are satisfied at this specific moment.

cards.sideA: Ellos no dejaron documentación al respecto.

sideB.text: They didn't leave any documentation regarding this.
They left no documentation about it.
There is no documentation left on this matter.
They didn't leave any documentation about it.
They didn't leave documentation about it.
They left behind no documentation regarding the matter.

cards.note:
[Regarding] is a professional alternative to 'about'.

~Regarding to this~ is incorrect. Never use 'to' after 'regarding'.

cards.sideA: ¿No sé si ya lo testeaste?

sideB.text: I don't know if you have tested it yet.
I'm not sure if you've already tested it.
I don't know whether you have tested it or not.
I don't know if you tested it.

cards.note:
This is an indirect question. Use standard sentence order [if you have tested], not question order ~if have you tested~.

Use [Yet] for negative/question contexts (ya/todavía) at the end of the sentence.

~I don't know if you tested yet?~ (Grammar: When using 'yet', it is better to use the present perfect 'have you tested yet'. If using simple past, you should include the object 'it', as in 'tested it'.)

cards.sideA: Además, explícame algo.

sideB.text: Besides, explain something to me.
Also, please explain one thing to me.
Furthermore, explain something to me.

cards.note:
**[114]**

Here, [Besides] acts as a connector meaning 'In addition' or 'Also'. It is followed by a comma.

~Besides, explain to me something.~ (Incorrect word order: In English, the object comes before the recipient. Say 'Explain something to me'.)

cards.sideA: Además, necesito saber otras cosas.

sideB.text: Besides, I need to know other things.
In addition, I need to know a few other things.
Also, there are other things I need to know.

cards.note:
**[114]**

[Besides] with an 'S' adds information. Think of the 'S' as a 'Plus' sign (+).

cards.sideA: Al lado del cuadrado.

sideB.text: Beside the square.
Next to the square.
Located by the side of the square.
At the side of the square.

cards.note:
**[114]**

[Beside] (no 'S') refers to physical location.

~Besides the square~ would mean 'In addition to the square' (incorrect context).

cards.sideA: Al lado del rectángulo.

sideB.text: Beside the rectangle.
Next to the rectangle.
Positioned beside the rectangle.

cards.note:
**[114]**

Use [Beside] or [Next to] for location.

cards.sideA: Tengo las bases para aprender otra cosa rápido.

sideB.text: I have the foundation to learn anything else quickly.
I have the basics down, so I can pick up other things fast.
I possess the core skills to learn new things rapidly.
I have the basics, so I can learn other things fast.

cards.note:
[Foundation] or [Basics] refers to the fundamental knowledge.

[Pick up] is a great phrasal verb for learning a new skill quickly.

cards.sideA: Teniendo las bases, es más fácil aprender el resto.

sideB.text: Having the basics, it is easier to learn the rest.
Once you have the foundation, learning the rest is easier.
With the core concepts in place, picking up the rest is simple.
Having the foundation, it is easier to learn the rest.

cards.note:
Structure: [Having the basics] (Gerund phrase) or [Once you have...] are good ways to start this sentence.

[The rest] refers to the remaining technologies or concepts.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el comportamiento esperado aquí?

sideB.text: What is the expected behavior here?
How is this supposed to work?
What should happen in this scenario?

cards.note:
**[3]**

*[50]**

[Expected behavior] is a standard QA and Dev term used in bug reports and requirements.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el objetivo principal de esta mejora?

sideB.text: What is the main goal of this enhancement?
What are we trying to achieve with this improvement?
What is the primary objective of this upgrade?

cards.note:
**[3]**

*[50]**

[Enhancement] is the professional term for a 'mejora' or new feature in software, distinct from a 'bug fix'.
