cards.sideA: ¿Qué problema estamos intentando solucionar con esto?

sideB.text: What problem are we trying to solve with this?
What issue does this address?
What is the specific problem we are aiming to fix?

cards.note:
[Address] is a professional verb meaning 'to deal with' or 'to solve' an issue.

Structure: [Trying to solve] is followed by the object (the problem).

~Which problems...~ (Number mismatch: The Spanish source is singular ('problema'), so use the singular 'problem'.)

cards.sideA: Primero, pediría los requerimientos para entender el comportamiento esperado.

sideB.text: First, I would ask for requirements to understand the expected behavior.
First, I'd request the requirements to grasp how it should work.
The first step is to ask for the requirements to clarify the expected outcome.

cards.note:
[Ask for] means 'pedir'.

~Ask requirements~ is incorrect. You must use the preposition: [Ask FOR requirements].

cards.sideA: Luego envío los requerimientos al equipo de desarrollo; actúo como puente para cualquier pregunta.

sideB.text: Then I send the requirements to the dev team; I act as the bridge for any questions.
Next, I pass the requirements to the developers and serve as a liaison for queries.
After that, I forward the requirements to the dev team and handle any questions they might have.

cards.note: [Act as the bridge] or [Serve as a liaison] are excellent phrases for Functional Analyst/Product Owner roles.

cards.sideA: He estado en reuniones con representantes de ventas.

sideB.text: I've been in meetings with sales reps.
I have attended meetings with sales representatives.
I've participated in meetings with the sales team.

cards.note:
[Sales reps] is the common short form for 'Sales Representatives'.

Preposition: [In meetings]. ~On meetings~ is usually incorrect for physical/virtual attendance.

cards.sideA: Últimamente, he estado en reuniones con los representantes de ventas.

sideB.text: Lately, I've been in meetings with the sales reps.
Recently, I've been attending meetings with sales representatives.
I've been sitting in on meetings with the sales team lately.

cards.note:
Use [Lately] or [Recently] with the Present Perfect ([I have been]).

[Sitting in on] implies you are attending to listen or support.

cards.sideA: Necesito pedirle los requerimientos al cliente.

sideB.text: I need to ask the client for the requirements.
I have to request the requirements from the client.
I need to get the requirements from the client.

cards.note:
**[176]**

Structure: [Ask someone FOR something].

~Ask the requirements to the client~ is incorrect grammar.

~I need to ask for the requirements to the client~ (Incorrect structure: Use 'ask the client for' or 'ask for ... from the client'.)

cards.sideA: Necesito recopilar/reunir los requerimientos del cliente.

sideB.text: I need to gather the requirements from the client.
I need to collect the requirements from the client.
I have to gather the necessary requirements from the customer.

cards.note:
**[176]**

[Gather requirements] is the most professional collocation for 'reunir requerimientos' in IT.

cards.sideA: Luego, agendaría una reunión para revisar los requerimientos y confirmar mi entendimiento.

sideB.text: Then, I would schedule a meeting to review requirements and confirm my understanding.
Next, I'd set up a meeting to go over the requirements and verify I understood correctly.
After that, I'd book a meeting to review the requirements and validate my understanding.

cards.note:
[Confirm my understanding] is a polite way to ensure you aren't making assumptions.

[Set up] is a common phrasal verb for [Schedule].

cards.sideA: A continuación, me reúno con el cliente para validar requerimientos y expectativas.

sideB.text: Next, I meet with the client to validate requirements and expectations.
Then, I have a meeting with the client to confirm requirements and expectations.
Subsequently, I meet the client to verify the requirements and manage expectations.

cards.note:
[Validate] and [Verify] are key QA/Analyst verbs.

[Manage expectations] is often implied when we talk about validating them.

cards.sideA: No tengo ningún problema con eso.

sideB.text: I have no problem with that.
That's not a problem for me.
I don't have any issues with that.

cards.note:
Use [I have no problem] or [I don't have a problem].

~I no got no problem~ is slang/incorrect (Double negative + improper use of 'got'). Avoid using it in professional interviews.

cards.sideA: Lo he estado haciendo últimamente.

sideB.text: I've been doing it lately.
I have been doing that recently.
That is something I've been working on lately.

cards.note: Use the **Present Perfect Continuous** [have been doing] for actions that started in the past and continue recently.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes sacar esa lógica de ahí?

sideB.text: Can you take that logic out of there?
Can you extract that logic from there?
Could you move that logic out of that section?

cards.note:
[Take out] or [Extract] are good verbs for refactoring code.

[Logic] refers to business rules or algorithms in the code.

~Can you take that logic out from there?~ (Redundant preposition: Use 'out of there'.)

~Can you take out that logic of there?~ (Incorrect preposition: Use 'out of'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes sacar esa validación de ahí?

sideB.text: Can you take that validation out of there?
Can you remove that validation from there?
Could you extract that validation logic?
Can you take out that validation from there?

cards.note:
[Validation] refers to checks (e.g., checking if stock > 0).

In code reviews, we often ask to [Remove] or [Extract] code to keep things clean.

~...take out that validation of there?~ (Grammar: Use 'from there' to indicate source/location. 'Of' is incorrect here.)

cards.sideA: Ella es una empleada interna.

sideB.text: She is an internal employee.
She is a staff employee.
She works internally for the company.

cards.note: [Internal employee] or [Staff employee] contrasts with 'Contractor' or 'External consultant'.

cards.sideA: Los empleados internos obtienen beneficios completos.

sideB.text: Internal employees get full benefits.
Staff employees receive full benefits.
Full-time internal staff get the complete benefits package.

cards.note:
[Benefits] refers to insurance, vacations, etc.

[Get] is common in speech; [Receive] is more formal.

cards.sideA: El empleado de soporte arregló el problema.

sideB.text: The support employee fixed the issue.
The support staff member resolved the problem.
The person from support fixed the bug.

cards.note:
[Fixed] (reparó) or [Resolved] (resolvió) are the standard verbs.

[Support employee] or just [Support] is common.

cards.sideA: Le pedimos ayuda al empleado de soporte.

sideB.text: We asked the support employee for help.
We requested assistance from the support staff.
We reached out to the support employee for help.

cards.note:
Structure: [Ask someone FOR help].

[Reach out to] is a professional way to say 'contactar' or 'pedir ayuda'.

~We asked for help to the support employee~ (Grammar: Incorrect structure. Correct forms: 'Ask [someone] for help' or 'Ask for help FROM [someone]'. Never 'ask for help to'.)

cards.sideA: Haciendo un chequeo rápido, ahora veo que el problema ha sido solucionado.

sideB.text: Doing a quick check, I now see that the problem has been solved.
After a quick check, I see the issue is fixed.
Checking quickly, I can see the problem is resolved now.

cards.note:
[Doing a quick check] is a present participle phrase explaining *how* you know the info.

[Has been solved] (Passive Voice) emphasizes the result.

~Making a quick check...~ (Collocation: We 'do', 'perform', or 'run' a check. We do not 'make' a check.)

cards.sideA: Veo que el campo aún no se actualiza.

sideB.text: I see that the field is not updating yet.
I notice the field hasn't updated yet.
It seems the field isn't updating.
I see that the field is not updated yet.

cards.note:
[Field] refers to the UI input or Database column.

Use [Not updating] (Continuous) to describe the current state.

~I style see that the field is not updated~ (Typo/Grammar: 'Style' is incorrect here. Likely meant 'still', but the phrasing 'is not updated' implies a static state rather than a pending process.)

cards.sideA: Ahora chequeé de nuevo, y ahora sí veo la última versión.

sideB.text: I checked again, and now I do see the latest version.
I just checked again, and I can see the latest version now.
After checking again, the latest version is visible.
I checked it again, and now I see the latest version.

cards.note:
Using [I do see] adds emphasis (affirmative), meaning 'Yes, really, I see it now'.

~...now I see the last version~ (Imprecise: Use 'latest version' for the most recent update. 'Last' implies the final one ever.)

~...now I do see the last version~ (Rejected: 'Last' implies finality. In software, always use 'latest' for the newest version.)

cards.sideA: No tengo el conocimiento suficiente sobre ese tema.

sideB.text: I do not have sufficient knowledge on that topic.
I don't have enough knowledge about that subject.
I lack sufficient knowledge regarding that topic.

cards.note:
[Sufficient] is a formal synonym for [Enough].

[Topic] or [Subject] are interchangeable here.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos preguntarle a John sobre esto.

sideB.text: We need to ask John about this.
We should ask John about this.
We need to inquire with John regarding this.

cards.note:
Simple structure: [Ask someone about something].

~Ask to John~ is incorrect. Never use 'to' after 'ask' when referring to the person.

cards.sideA: No tengo los permisos para hacer eso.

sideB.text: I do not have the permissions to do that.
I do not have the necessary access rights for that.
I am not authorized to do that.
I don't have the permission to perform that action.

cards.note:
In IT, use [Permissions] or [Access rights] (permisos del sistema).

[Responsibility] (responsabilidad) refers to your job duties. If the system blocks you, it's a [Permission] issue.

cards.sideA: ¿Podrían avisarme cuando desplieguen el paquete 'purple'?

sideB.text: Could you guys let me know when you deploy the purple package?
Could you notify me when the purple package is deployed?
Please let me know once the purple package deployment is done.

cards.note:
Use [Let me know] as a friendly, standard way to say 'avisar'.

[Deploy] is the standard verb for releasing software.

~...deploy the package in purple~ (Incorrect phrasing: 'Purple' is the name of the package, so it functions as an adjective: [Purple package]. 'In purple' suggests physical color.)

cards.sideA: Nunca lo he hecho, de hecho no tengo las responsabilidades.

sideB.text: I've never done that; actually, I don't have the responsibilities.
I have never done it; in fact, I do not hold those responsibilities.
I haven't done that before; as a matter of fact, I am not responsible for that.

cards.note:
Use [Actually] or [In fact] to introduce a contrast.

[Hold responsibilities] is a formal way to say you possess certain duties, but here we negate it.

cards.sideA: ¿Podrían avisarme por favor?

sideB.text: Could you let me know, please?
Could you please notify me?
Please keep me posted.
Would you mind letting me know?

cards.note:
[Let me know] is the most common phrasal verb.

[Keep me posted] is an idiomatic way to say 'mantente informándome'.

cards.sideA: No está funcionando aún.

sideB.text: It is not working yet.
It isn't working yet.
It's not up and running yet.
The system is still not functioning.
It is still not working.

cards.note: Place [Yet] at the end of negative sentences to indicate 'todavía/aún'.

cards.sideA: ¡Ya está funcionando!

sideB.text: It is working now!
It's up and running!
It works now!
The system is operational now!
It is already working!

cards.note:
[Up and running] is a professional idiom meaning a system is active and functioning correctly.

Use [Already] to emphasize something happened sooner than expected, while [Now] simply marks the current status.

cards.sideA: Ok, voy a compartir mi pantalla ahora.

sideB.text: Ok, I'm going to share my screen now.
Ok, let me share my screen now.
Alright, I'll share my screen right now.

cards.note:
[I'm going to] indicates an immediate future action.

[Let me share] is polite and authoritative in meetings.

cards.sideA: Estoy compartiendo mi pantalla ahora mismo.

sideB.text: I am sharing my screen right now.
I'm sharing my screen right now.
I am currently sharing my display.

cards.note: Use the Present Continuous [am sharing] for actions happening at this exact moment.

cards.sideA: Es como si el servicio estuviera intermitente.

sideB.text: It's as if the service were intermittent.
It seems like the service is intermittent.
It looks like the service is experiencing intermittency.
It feels like the service is acting up intermittently.
It's like the service is intermittent.

cards.note:
[It seems like] is a softer, common way to diagnose issues.

[It's as if... were] uses the Subjunctive mood (formal/hypothetical).

cards.sideA: ¿El servicio está intermitente o no?

sideB.text: Is the service intermittent or not?
Is the service experiencing downtime or not?
Is the connection cutting out or not?

cards.note:
[Intermittent] means stopping and starting at intervals.

[Downtime] refers to periods when the system is unavailable.

cards.sideA: Así podría hacerlo de una vez.

sideB.text: So I could do it at once.
That way, I could do it right away.
This allows me to get it done immediately.

cards.note:
[Right away] and [At once] both mean immediately.

[That way] (así/de esa forma) connects the result to the previous action.

cards.sideA: ¡Vamos a hacerlo de una vez!

sideB.text: Let's do it at once!
Let's do it right away!
Let's get it done now!
Let's handle this immediately.

cards.note: [Let's] is the standard way to propose an immediate action to a team.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos alguna prueba antes de actuar.

sideB.text: We need some proof before acting.
We need some evidence before we take action.
We require proof before proceeding.
We need verification before doing anything.

cards.note:
[Proof] is conclusive (facts).

[Evidence] supports a conclusion.

[Take action] is a professional synonym for 'act'.

~We need a proof...~ (Grammar: 'Proof' is an uncountable noun here; do not use 'a'. Use 'some proof' or just 'proof'.)

cards.sideA: No directamente uno a uno.

sideB.text: Not directly one-on-one.
It wasn't a direct one-on-one interaction.
It isn't directly a one-on-one meeting.

cards.note:
[One-on-one] (often written 1:1) refers to a meeting between two people.

~Not directly one by one~ ('One by one' means sequentially, like a queue. 'One on one' means interaction between two parties.)

cards.sideA: Aún no está llegando el campo.

sideB.text: The field isn't coming through yet.
The field is not being received yet.
We aren't getting that field yet.
It's not getting the field yet.

cards.note:
[Coming through] is a very common phrasal verb when discussing data streams or API responses.

Use [field] for JSON keys or database columns.

~It's not arriving the field yet~ ('Arrive' is an intransitive verb; you cannot 'arrive something'. Use [getting] or [receiving] instead.)


~It's not getting fetched the field~ is grammatically incorrect. You can say [The field is not being fetched] or [It is not fetching the field].

cards.sideA: Aún no se ha actualizado.

sideB.text: It hasn't updated yet.
It hasn't been updated yet.
The update hasn't gone through yet.
It's not updated yet.

cards.note:
Use the Present Perfect [hasn't updated] for actions expecting completion.

[Gone through] implies the process was triggered but didn't finish.

cards.sideA: ¿Desde qué día te ocurre eso?

sideB.text: Since what day has this been happening to you?
How long has this been happening?
When did this start happening?
Since what day has this happened to you?

cards.note:
[How long] is the most natural way to ask about duration in English.

[Since what day] is grammatically correct but sounds more formal or specific to a ticket report.

~Since what day did that happen to you?~ (Incorrect Grammar: [Since] usually requires the Present Perfect tense because it connects past to present. Use [When] with simple past.)

cards.sideA: Estamos teniendo problemas con el proxy.

sideB.text: We are having issues with the proxy.
We're experiencing problems with the proxy server.
We are facing some trouble with the proxy.
We are having trouble with the proxy.

cards.note:
[Experiencing] is a professional verb for status reports.

[Issues] is slightly softer and more common in tech than 'problems'.

cards.sideA: Hemos tenido algunos problemas con la intermitencia del backend.

sideB.text: We've had some issues with backend intermittency.
We've been experiencing intermittent backend issues.
We have encountered some flakiness in the backend.
We've been facing some intermittent issues with the backend.
We've been facing some issues with intermittency in the backend.

cards.note:
[Flakiness] or [Flaky] is a very common developer term for something that works sometimes but fails others (intermittent).

Structure: [We've had] (Present Perfect) connects past issues to the present moment.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos validar al usuario, de lo contrario, obtenemos el error 400.

sideB.text: We need to validate the user; otherwise, we get a 400 error.
User validation is required, or else we'll receive a 400 error.
We must validate the user to avoid getting a 400 error.
We need to validate the user; otherwise, it returns a 400 error.

cards.note:
Use [Otherwise] to connect a requirement with its negative consequence.

The HTTP 400 status is standardly referred to as a [Bad Request] or just [400 error].

cards.sideA: Se requiere probar bajo diferentes condiciones.

sideB.text: It is required to test under different conditions.
Testing under various conditions is required.
We need to test this under different scenarios.
It requires testing across different conditions.

cards.note:
**[157]**

[Under different conditions] is the standard collocation for testing environments.

Using the passive voice [It is required] makes the statement more objective and formal than 'We need to'.

cards.sideA: No he tenido noticias sobre ese tema.

sideB.text: I haven't heard anything about that topic.
I haven't had any updates on that matter.
I haven't received any news regarding that issue.
I haven't heard back about that subject.

cards.note:
[updates] is the most professional word for 'noticias' in a project context.

[Matter] or [Issue] are often preferred over 'topic' for business problems.

~I haven't had news~ (While possible, it's more common to say 'I haven't heard anything' or 'I haven't had any updates'.)

cards.sideA: No quise cambiarle el estado.

sideB.text: I didn't want to change its status.
I chose not to change the status.
I preferred not to change the state.
I didn't want to alter the status.

cards.note:
[I didn't want to] expresses a lack of desire or intent.

[Status] is used for lifecycle stages (Open, Closed, Pending), while [State] is often used for technical conditions (Active, Inactive, Boolean).

If you meant it was an accident, you would say 'I didn't mean to change...'.

cards.sideA: Eso ocurrió el día antes de ayer.

sideB.text: That happened the day before yesterday.
That occurred two days ago.
It happened the day before yesterday.
That took place the day before yesterday.

cards.note:
[The day before yesterday] is the literal and correct translation.

In casual conversation, [Two days ago] is frequently used for brevity.

cards.sideA: Ok, por mí está bien.

sideB.text: OK, that's fine by me.
OK, that works for me.
OK, I'm good with that.
OK, that is fine with me.

cards.note:
[Works for me] is extremely common in business scheduling and agreements.

[Fine by me] is slightly more casual but acceptable in team chats.

cards.sideA: Esa es la forma que debería funcionar.

sideB.text: That is the way it should work.
That's how it is supposed to work.
That is how it should function.
That is the way it's intended to work.

cards.note:
[Supposed to] implies that there is a design or expectation behind the function.

[How it should work] is more natural than 'The way that it should work'.

cards.sideA: Aún estamos esperando la respuesta sobre el reverse proxy.

sideB.text: We are still waiting for the response regarding the reverse proxy.
We're still awaiting an answer about the reverse proxy.
We are still waiting to hear back about the reverse proxy.
We are still waiting on the reverse proxy response.

cards.note:
[Awaiting] is a transitive verb (no 'for') and sounds more formal than 'waiting for'.

[Hear back] is a common phrasal verb meaning to receive a reply.

cards.sideA: Es el orquestador.

sideB.text: It is the orchestrator.
It's the orchestrator.
That is the orchestrator.

cards.note: In microservices or container architecture (like Kubernetes), the [Orchestrator] manages deployment and scaling.

cards.sideA: Una cosa que he notado es que no funciona.

sideB.text: One thing I've noticed is that it doesn't work.
One thing I noticed is that it is not working.
Something I've observed is that it fails to work.
One thing I have noticed is that it isn't functioning.

cards.note:
[Noticed] implies you saw it while doing something else.

[Observed] implies you were watching specifically for it (more formal).

cards.sideA: Una cosa que he notado, es que no funciona del todo bien.

sideB.text: One thing I've noticed is that it doesn't work quite right.
One thing I noticed is that it's not working entirely well.
One thing I've noticed is that it doesn't work perfectly.
One thing I noticed is that it isn't working completely right.
One thing I've noticed is that it doesn't work well.

cards.note:
[Not... quite right] is a very natural way to describe a partial failure or buggy behavior.

[Not... entirely well] is slightly more formal.

cards.sideA: Nos enviamos varios correos electrónicos de ida y vuelta.

sideB.text: We sent several emails back and forth.
We exchanged several emails back and forth.
We had some back and forth emails.
We went back and forth over email several times.

cards.note:
[Back and forth] is the standard idiom for reciprocal movement or communication (ida y vuelta).

[Exchanged] is a more professional verb than 'sent to each other'.

cards.sideA: Hemos realizado varias pruebas de ida y vuelta.

sideB.text: We have performed several back-and-forth tests.
We have conducted several back-and-forth tests.
We've done some back-and-forth testing.
We ran multiple back-and-forth tests.

cards.note:
When used as an adjective before a noun (like 'tests'), [back-and-forth] is often hyphenated.

[Conducted] and [Performed] are formal alternatives to 'done' or 'made' in a testing context.

cards.sideA: No sabemos donde establecer el enrutamiento.

sideB.text: We don't know where to set the routing.
We aren't sure where to establish the routing.
We don't know where to define the routing.
We don't know where to set the route.

cards.note:
[Routing] refers to the process of selecting a path for traffic in a network, whereas a [Route] is the specific path itself.

~We don't know where put the routing~ (Grammar: 'Put' is too generic here. Use technical verbs like [set], [establish], or [configure].)

cards.sideA: No tengo acceso al servidor Linux.

sideB.text: I do not have access to the Linux server.
I don't have access to the Linux server.
I lack access to the Linux server.

cards.note:
[Access] is usually an uncountable noun in this context.

~I don't have an access~ (Grammar: Do not use 'an' with abstract access. You just 'have access'.)

cards.sideA: Nunca he trabajado directamente en el servidor Linux.

sideB.text: I have never worked directly on the Linux server.
I've never worked directly on the Linux server.
I have never done direct work on the Linux server.

cards.note:
Use the preposition [on] when talking about working with servers or platforms.

~In the server~ (While understandable, [on the server] is the standard collocation for software environments.)

cards.sideA: Creo que esos comandos deben usarse en el servidor Linux.

sideB.text: I believe those commands must be used on the Linux server.
I think those commands need to be run on the Linux server.
I believe those commands should be executed on the Linux server.

cards.note:
[Run] and [Execute] are the most common verbs for processing commands.

[Must] implies a strong necessity or requirement.

cards.sideA: Déjame ver el hilo que tengo con Sean.

sideB.text: Let me see the thread I have with Sean.
Let me check the thread I have with Sean.
Let me look at the thread I have with Sean.

cards.note:
A [Thread] refers to a connected series of messages (email, Slack, etc.).

[Check] is a very professional verb for 'ver/revisar' in this context.

cards.sideA: Tenemos el error 404 cuando enviamos la petición al endpoint.

sideB.text: We get a 404 error when we send the request to the endpoint.
We are getting a 404 error when sending the request to the endpoint.
We encounter a 404 error when we hit the endpoint.
We have a 404 error when we send a request to the endpoint.

cards.note:
[Hit] is common technical slang for sending a request to an endpoint.

[Endpoint] is the specific URL where an API service can be accessed.

~We have an error 404...~ (Phrasing: In English, we usually say [a 404 error] or just [Error 404]. The article 'an' does not fit before 'error' when the code follows immediately in this structure.)

cards.sideA: Hay una diferencia en las convenciones de nombres.

sideB.text: There is a difference in the naming conventions.
There's a discrepancy in the naming conventions.
The naming conventions are different.
There is a difference between the naming conventions.

cards.note:
[Naming convention] is the standard term for rules like CamelCase, snake_case, etc.

[Discrepancy] implies a difference that shouldn't exist or causes issues.

~...name conventions~ (Standard term: The correct technical term is [Naming conventions].)

cards.sideA: Tenemos por un lado camel case, y por otro, snake case.

sideB.text: On one hand we have camel case, and on the other, snake case.
We have camel case on one side, and snake case on the other.
There is camel case on one hand, and snake case on the other.

cards.note:
Use [On one hand... and on the other] to contrast two distinct situations.

[Camel case]: `myVariable`
[Snake case]: `my_variable`

~We have on one side camel case...~ (Word order: It is more natural to say 'We have camel case on one side'.)

~...on one side... on the other hand~ (Idiom consistency: Use [On one hand ... on the other hand] OR [On one side ... on the other side]. Do not mix them.)

cards.sideA: Tenemos una palabra adicional en el endpoint.

sideB.text: We have an additional word in the endpoint.
There is an extra word in the endpoint.
We've got an extra word in the endpoint path.

cards.note: [Additional] and [Extra] are generally interchangeable here.

cards.sideA: Tenemos expuesto esto, pero se mapea de otra forma.

sideB.text: We have this exposed, but it maps differently.
We have this exposed, but it is mapped in a different way.
This is exposed, but the mapping is done differently.
We have this exposed, but it gets mapped differently.
We have this exposed, but it gets mapped in another way.

cards.note:
To [Expose] an API/Service means to make it available for connection.

To [Map] means to connect or associate one data point/path with another.

cards.sideA: Debe haber una capa intermedia en donde se mapea esto.

sideB.text: There must be a middleware layer where this is mapped.
There has to be an intermediate layer where this mapping happens.
There must be a middle layer where this gets mapped.
There must be a middleware layer where this gets mapped.

cards.note:
[Middleware] is software that acts as a bridge between an operating system or database and applications.

Use [There must be] when you are deducing a fact.

cards.sideA: Debe haber una capa intermedia donde ocurre una traducción de nombres.

sideB.text: There must be a middleware layer where name translation occurs.
There has to be a middleware layer where a name translation takes place.
There must be an intermediate layer where names are translated.
There must be a middleware layer where the name translation happens.
There must be a middleware layer where the names get translated.

cards.note:
In this context, [Translation] refers to transforming data formats or naming conventions (e.g., from CamelCase to SnakeCase).

~...where it happens the name translation~ (Word order: The subject [name translation] should come before the verb [happens], or simply use 'where name translation occurs'.)

~...where naming translation happens~ (Style: [Name translation] or [translation of names] is preferred over 'naming translation'.)

cards.sideA: Existe una configuración de mapeo desconocida para nosotros.

sideB.text: There is a mapping configuration unknown to us.
There is a mapping configuration we are not aware of.
A mapping config exists that we don't know about.
There is a map configuration unknown to us.

cards.note:
[Unknown to us] is a formal way to say 'we don't know it'.

[We are not aware of] is professional and very common in meetings.

~There is a unknown...~ (Grammar: Use [an] before vowel sounds like 'unknown'.)

~...configuration to us~ (Word order: Adjectives modifying the noun should be close. Better: 'A mapping configuration [unknown to us]'.)

~Exist a...~ (Grammar: Sentences expressing existence usually start with [There is] or [There exists]. Also, 'configuration' is singular, so the verb would be 'Exists' if used alone.)

cards.sideA: Como no se está mapeando, el servidor no puede enrutar la solicitud.

sideB.text: Since it is not being mapped, the server cannot route the request.
Because it isn't being mapped, the server can't route the request.
As it is not mapped, the server is unable to route the request.
Since it is not mapped, the server cannot route the request.

cards.note:
[Since] and [As] are strong alternatives to 'Because' when explaining technical causes.

[Route] (verb) means to send data to a specific destination.

~...can not enroute...~ (Incorrect vocabulary: [En route] is an adverb meaning 'on the way'. The verb is [Route].)

~...server cannot routing...~ (Grammar: Modals like 'cannot' are followed by the base verb form, not the -ing form. It should be [cannot route].)

~Since it is not mapping...~ (Grammar/Voice: The original implies a passive state 'se está mapeando'. Use passive voice [is not being mapped] rather than active.)

cards.sideA: El endpoint no se está enrutando correctamente.

sideB.text: The endpoint is not being routed correctly.
The endpoint isn't routing properly.
The endpoint is not routing as it should.

cards.note:
[Properly] is a frequent synonym for [Correctly].

Use passive voice [is not being routed] when the system acts on the endpoint.

cards.sideA: El mapeo permite tener searchKeyword…

sideB.text: The mapping allows having searchKeyword...
The mapping enables searchKeyword...
The mapping allows for searchKeyword...

cards.note:
[Allows] or [Enables] are standard verbs to describe what a feature permits.

~The mapping permit~ (Grammar: 'Permit' is more formal/legal; [Allow] is better for software logic.)

~The map allows...~ (Precision: [Mapping] refers to the process or relationship. [Map] usually refers to the specific data structure.)

~The mapping allows to have...~ (Grammar: The verb [allow] cannot be followed directly by an infinitive unless there is an object. Use [allows having] or [allows us to have].)

cards.sideA: El Proxy Inverso es un servicio intermediario.

sideB.text: The Reverse Proxy is an intermediary service.
The Reverse Proxy acts as an intermediary service.
The Reverse Proxy serves as an intermediary.
The Reverse Proxy is a Middleware service.

cards.note:
A [Reverse Proxy] sits in front of one or more web servers, intercepting requests from clients.

~...is a middle service~ (Vocabulary: The standard terms are [intermediary] or [middleware]. 'Middle service' is not used in this technical context.)

cards.sideA: El Proxy Inverso se sitúa entre la red pública y la privada.

sideB.text: The Reverse Proxy sits between the public network and the private network.
The Reverse Proxy is located between the public and private networks.
The Reverse Proxy stands between the public network and the internal network.
The Reverse Proxy is between the public internet and the intranet.

cards.note:
[Sits] is a very common technical idiom to describe where a component resides in an architecture.

~...private internet~ (Terminology: The correct term for a private internal network is [Intranet] or [Private Network].)

cards.sideA: Es solo un Manejo de Errores.

sideB.text: It is just Error Handling.
It's simply Error Handling.
It is only Error Handling.

cards.note: [Error Handling] is a specific term for the procedures coded to manage faults.

cards.sideA: Es una validación de Entrada.

sideB.text: It is Input Validation.
It is an Input Validation.
It represents Input Validation.

cards.note: [Input Validation] ensures that properly formed data is entering the workflow.

cards.sideA: Es como una validación de Entrada o Manejo de Errores.

sideB.text: It is like Input Validation or Error Handling.
It's similar to Input Validation or Error Handling.
It acts like Input Validation or Error Handling.

cards.note: [Like] is used to compare the nature or behavior of the code.

cards.sideA: Extrae el texto antes del doble punto.

sideB.text: Extract the text before the colon.
Pull the text occurring before the colon.
Get the text that comes before the colon.

cards.note:
[Colon] (:) is the punctuation mark.

~Double point~ (Incorrect: This is a literal translation of 'dos puntos'. The English term is [Colon].)

cards.sideA: Extrae el número después del doble punto.

sideB.text: Extract the number after the colon.
Get the number following the colon.
Pull the number located after the colon.

cards.note: [Extract] typically implies using a substring method or Regex to isolate data.

cards.sideA: Compatibilidad con versiones anteriores.

sideB.text: Backward Compatibility.
Backwards Compatibility.
Compatibility with previous versions.
Compatibility with old versions.

cards.note:
[Backward Compatibility] is the ability of a system to work with inputs generated by older versions of itself.

~Compatibility with backward versions~ (Vocabulary: Versions are not 'backward'. Use [previous versions], [older versions], or the standard term [backward compatibility].)

cards.sideA: Se delega al orquestador interno.

sideB.text: It is delegated to the internal orchestrator.
It's delegated to the internal orchestrator.
The task is delegated to the internal orchestrator.

cards.note:
[To delegate] means to assign responsibility or authority.

[Orchestrator] is a system that manages and coordinates automated tasks/services.

~It is delegated with...~ (Incorrect preposition: You delegate a task [to] a system or person.)

cards.sideA: Aquí nos estamos inicializando.

sideB.text: We are initializing here.
The session is being initialized here.
We are performing initialization here.

cards.note: [Initialize] means to set variables, counters, or states to a starting value.

cards.sideA: Nos inicializamos para prevenir errores de sesión.

sideB.text: We initialize to prevent session errors.
We are initializing to avoid session errors.
We initialize to prevent errors in the session.

cards.note: [Prevent] means to stop something from happening before it occurs.

cards.sideA: La inicialización asegura la identidad del usuario en la sesión.

sideB.text: Initialization ensures the user's identity in the session.
Initialization sets the user context.
Initialization secures the user identity within the session.

cards.note:
[Ensures] means to make certain that something happens.

[User context] is a common way to refer to all the data defining the current user.

~Initialization allows the user's identity...~ (Vocabulary: [Allow] means to permit. [Ensure] or [Secure] is better for making sure an identity is firmly established.)

cards.sideA: La inicialización habilita la visibilidad de los datos según el usuario.

sideB.text: Initialization enables data visibility according to the user.
Initialization allows data visibility based on the user.
Initialization turns on data visibility depending on the user.
Initializing enables data visibility according to the user.
Initializing enables data visibility depending on the user.
Initializing enables the visibility of the data depending on the user.
Initialization enables the visibility of the data depending on the user.

cards.note:
[Enable] is a key technical verb meaning to activate or make possible.

[According to] or [Based on] are correct ways to express dependency.

~...depending to the user~ (Grammar: The correct preposition is [depending on].)

cards.sideA: La URL debe incluir el protocolo, dominio y ruta.

sideB.text: The URL must include the protocol, domain, and path.
The URL needs to contain the protocol, domain, and path.
We must include the protocol, domain, and path in the URL.

cards.sideA: La URL es la dirección completa para localizar el recurso.

sideB.text: The URL is the complete address to locate the resource.
The URL is the full address used to locate the resource.
A URL serves as the complete address for locating a resource.

cards.note:
**[122]**

[URL] stands for Uniform Resource Locator.

~...to localize...~ (Vocabulary: [Locate] means to find a place. [Localize] usually means to adapt software for a specific region/language.)


~...complete direction...~ is incorrect. In English, [address] is used for locations (physical or digital), while [direction] refers to instructions or the path to follow.

cards.sideA: El Endpoint es la última parte de la URL.

sideB.text: The endpoint is the last part of the URL.
The endpoint is located at the end of the URL.
The final segment of the URL is the endpoint.

cards.note:
**[122]**

The [Endpoint] typically identifies the specific resource or action.

cards.sideA: El Endpoint es el recurso específico que la URL apunta.

sideB.text: The endpoint is the specific resource the URL points to.
The endpoint represents the specific resource targeted by the URL.
The endpoint is the specific resource the URL is pointing at.
The endpoint is the specific resource the URL aims at.

cards.note:
**[122]**

[Points to] is the standard phrasal verb for direction/reference in tech. [Aims at] is also a valid alternative.

~...resource to aim the URL~ (Incorrect phrasing: You [aim at] a target. Better: 'The resource at which the URL is aimed'.)

~...resource to address the URL~ (Incorrect relation: The URL addresses the resource, not the other way around.)

~...resource that aim at the URL~ (Logic/Grammar: The URL points to the resource, not vice versa. Also, 'resource' is singular, so the verb would need to be 'aims'.)

~...resource where the URL points to~ (Grammar: Use [which] or [that] when ending with a preposition like 'to'. [Where] implies a location and does not take 'to'.)

cards.sideA: Endpoint y URL a menudo se usan de forma intercambiable, pero no son lo mismo.

sideB.text: Endpoint and URL are often used interchangeably, but they are not the same.
People often use Endpoint and URL interchangeably, but they aren't the same.
Endpoint and URL are frequently used interchangeably, yet they differ.
Endpoint and URL are often used in an interchangeable way, but they are not the same.

cards.note:
**[122]**

[Interchangeably] means switching one for the other.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos la ruta, dominio y protocolo de la URL.

sideB.text: We need the URL's path, domain, and protocol.
We require the path, domain, and protocol of the URL.
We need the URL protocol, domain, and path.
We need the path, domain and protocol of the URL.

cards.sideA: El endpoint está incluido en la ruta de la URL.

sideB.text: The endpoint is included in the URL path.
The URL path includes the endpoint.
The endpoint is part of the URL path.

cards.note:
**[122]**

Technically, the endpoint is often the final segment of the path.

~In the URL path is included the endpoint~ (Syntax error: English word order is Subject + Verb. Better: 'The endpoint is included in the URL path'.)

cards.sideA: Son usados intercambiablemente.

sideB.text: They are used interchangeably.
They are used in an interchangeable way.
They are used as synonyms.

cards.note: [Interchangeably] is an adverb meaning that one thing can be used in place of another without changing the result.

cards.sideA: Ahora se extrae la subcadena de...

sideB.text: Now the substring is extracted from...
Now the substring from... is extracted.
Now we extract the substring from...

cards.note:
A [Substring] is a contiguous sequence of characters within a string.

Passive voice ([is extracted]) focuses on the action, not the actor.

cards.sideA: Ahora extraemos la subcadena de...

sideB.text: Now we extract the substring of...
Now we pull the substring from...
Now we get the substring from...

cards.note:
Active voice ([we extract]) is direct and commonly used in code walkthroughs.

[Pull] is a common casual synonym for extracting data.

cards.sideA: Luego parseamos a P_QUOTE_LINE_ID y extraemos su...

sideB.text: Then we parse P_QUOTE_LINE_ID and extract its...
Next, we parse P_QUOTE_LINE_ID and extract its...
Then we parse P_QUOTE_LINE_ID to extract its...

cards.note: To [Parse] means to analyze a string of symbols (or data) to extract specific information.

cards.sideA: Ahora tomamos al delimitador...

sideB.text: Now we take the delimiter...
Now we pick the delimiter...
Now we select the delimiter...

cards.note: A [Delimiter] is a character used to specify the boundary between separate, independent regions (like a comma in CSV).

cards.sideA: Ahora encontramos la posición del delimitador...

sideB.text: Now we find the position of the delimiter...
Now we locate the delimiter's position...
Now we find where the delimiter is located...

cards.note:
In programming, [Position] or [Index] refers to the numeric location of a character within a string.

~...the delimeter position~ (Spelling: The correct spelling is [delimiter], with an 'i'.)

cards.sideA: Estamos limpiando, o reseteando la variable local.

sideB.text: We are clearing, or resetting the local variable.
We are cleaning, or resetting the local variable.
We are wiping, or resetting the local variable.

cards.note:
[Clear] is the most standard term for removing data from a variable or structure.

~We are cleaning~ (While understood, [Cleaning] usually implies sanitizing input, whereas [Clearing] implies making it empty.)

cards.sideA: Prevenir errores de contaminación de datos.

sideB.text: To prevent data contamination errors.
To avoid data contamination errors.
In order to prevent data pollution errors.

cards.note:
[Data contamination] occurs when data from one context leaks into another.

[Prevent] is proactive (stop it before it starts).

cards.sideA: El header tiene el quien, cuando, y cuanto.

sideB.text: The header has the who, when, and how much.
The header contains the who, the when, and the how much.
The header holds the who, when, and how much.

cards.note: In a Master-Detail relationship, the [Header] contains the general information common to all lines.

cards.sideA: Solo hay 1 header por transacción, pero puede tener muchas lineas.

sideB.text: There is only 1 header per transaction, but it can have many lines.
There is only one header per transaction, but it may contain multiple lines.
A transaction has only one header, but multiple lines.

cards.note:
This describes a [One-to-Many] relationship.

~...header for transaction~ (Grammar: Missing article. It should be [header for a transaction] or [header for the transaction]. [Per transaction] is also excellent.)

cards.sideA: Las 'Lineas' son la lista de productos del Header o Boleta.

sideB.text: The 'Lines' are the list of products of the Header or Invoice.
The 'Lines' represent the product list for the Header or Invoice.
The 'Lines' constitute the list of items in the Header or Invoice.
The 'Lines' are the list of products of the Header or receipt.

cards.note: [Boleta] is often translated as [Invoice] or [Receipt] depending on the context. In generic ERP terms, [Invoice] is safer.

cards.sideA: Las 'Lineas' tienen el item, cantidad, precio unitario.

sideB.text: The 'Lines' have the item, quantity, and unit price.
The 'Lines' contain the item, the quantity, and the unit price.
The 'Lines' include the item, quantity, and unit price.

cards.note: [Unit price] is the price for a single item, before quantity multiplication.

cards.sideA: Las 'Lineas' tienen cada una un numero unico.

sideB.text: The 'Lines' each have a unique number.
Each 'Line' has a unique number.
The 'Lines' possess a unique ID each.

cards.note:
[Each] emphasizes individual possession of the property (unique number).

~...have each one...~ (Grammar: Standard phrasing is [each have] or [have ... each]. 'Each one' is unnecessary here.)

~The 'Lines' have a unique ID~ (Precision: This phrasing is ambiguous and could imply the group shares one ID. The source says 'cada una', requiring the word [each] to specify individual IDs.)

cards.sideA: El carro es una cotización.

sideB.text: The CART is a quotation.
The cart represents a quote.
The shopping cart acts as a quotation.
The CART is a quote.

cards.note: In e-commerce logic, a [Quote] or [Quotation] is a draft order with prices, often represented by the active [Cart].

cards.sideA: La orden es un compromiso de venta y envío.

sideB.text: The ORDER is a commitment to sell and ship.
The order represents a commitment to sell and ship.
The order is a pledge to sell and ship.

cards.note:
[Commitment] in business logic means the stock is reserved and the intent to transact is finalized.

~...commitment of selling and shipment~ (Grammar: The standard structure is [commitment to + verb], e.g., [commitment to sell]. [Commitment of selling] is not standard usage.)

cards.sideA: La factura es la solicitud formal de pago.

sideB.text: The INVOICE is the formal request for payment.
The invoice is the official payment request.
The invoice serves as a formal demand for payment.

cards.note:
[Invoice] is the document issued by the seller to the buyer.

~The invoice is the formal request of payment~ (Preposition: The standard business collocation is request [for] payment, not [of].)

~The INVOICE is the formal form of payment~ (Meaning: An [Invoice] is a request for money. A [Form of payment] refers to the method used to pay, such as cash, credit card, or check.)

cards.sideA: El proceso de generar la factura toma tiempo.

sideB.text: The process of generating the invoice takes time.
Generating the invoice is a time-consuming process.
It takes time to generate the invoice.
The invoice process takes time.
The process to generate the invoice takes time.

cards.note: [Takes time] is the standard idiom for duration.

cards.sideA: La Orden autoriza el despacho.

sideB.text: The Order authorizes shipment.
The Order authorizes the dispatch.
The Order clears the shipment.
The Order authorizes the delivery.

cards.note: [Dispatch] and [Shipment] are used interchangeably for the act of sending goods.

cards.sideA: La Factura registra la cuenta por cobrar.

sideB.text: The Invoice records the accounts receivable.
The Invoice logs the accounts receivable.
The Invoice registers the debt.
The Invoice registers the accounts receivable.

cards.note:
[Accounts Receivable] (AR) is the money owed to a company by its debtors.

~The Invoice records the account for charging~ (Terminology: [Account for charging] is not standard accounting terminology. Use [Accounts Receivable].)

~The invoice records the payable account~ (Meaning: [Accounts Payable] refers to money you owe to others. Since you issued the invoice, it is a receivable for you, not a payable.)

cards.sideA: La Factura se crea después del envío.

sideB.text: The Invoice is created after shipment.
The Invoice is generated post-shipment.
The Invoice is made after shipping.
The Invoice gets created after shipment.
The Invoice is created after shipping.

cards.note:
[Post-shipment] is a concise technical way to say 'after shipment'.

~...after ship~ (Grammar: [After] is a preposition here and requires a noun or gerund like [shipment] or [shipping]. 'Ship' is the base verb.)

cards.sideA: Toma mucho tiempo en recargarse.

sideB.text: It takes a long time to reload.
It takes a while to reload.
Reloading takes a lot of time.
It takes a long time to recover.
It takes too long to reload.

cards.note:
Use [It takes...] to talk about the duration of an action.

~...to recharge~ (Context: In software/web contexts, 'recargarse' is [reload]. [Recharge] is typically used for batteries or energy.)

~It takes a long of time~ (Grammar: You can say [a long time] or [a lot of time], but not ~a long of time~.)

cards.sideA: Toma mucho tiempo en volver a funciona bien, a veces 1 o 2 dias completos.

sideB.text: It takes a long time to work well again, sometimes 1 or 2 full days.
It takes a long time to return to normal functioning, sometimes 1 or 2 whole days.
It takes a while to operate correctly again, sometimes 1 or 2 full days.

cards.note:
[Full days] or [Whole days] emphasizes the completeness of the duration.

~...come back to work well...~ (Phrasing: Systems [start working again] or [come back online]. 'Come back to work' implies a person returning to their job.)

~It takes too long to work again~ (Translation/Nuance: [Mucho tiempo] translates to 'a long time'. [Too long] implies it is excessive ('Demasiado'). Also, [to work well again] or [operate correctly] is more precise than just 'work again'.)

~It takes a long time to come back well...~ (Collocation: While a system can [come back] (online), we do not say it 'comes back well'. Better phrasing is [work well again] or [function properly].)

cards.sideA: Toma mucho tiempo en volver.

sideB.text: It takes a long time to come back.
It takes a long time to return.
It takes a long time to get back.

cards.note:
[Come back] is a phrasal verb synonym for [Return].

~It takes time to come back~ (Meaning: The source says 'mucho tiempo' which means [a long time]. 'It takes time' generally means it requires patience, without specifying it is long.)

~It takes too long to come back~ (Nuance: The source uses 'mucho' [a long time], which is an objective quantity. 'Demasiado' [too long] implies an excessive or negative amount.)

cards.sideA: La Responsabilidad define los roles especificos de un usuario.

sideB.text: The Responsibility defines the specific roles of a user.
The Responsibility defines a user's specific roles.
The Responsibility determines the specific user roles.

cards.note: In ERP systems (like Oracle), a [Responsibility] is a collection of menus, functions, and reports available to a user.

cards.sideA: La Responsabilidad define los permisos especificos de un usuario.

sideB.text: The Responsibility defines a user's specific permissions.
The Responsibility sets the specific permissions for a user.
The Responsibility outlines a user's specific permissions.
The Responsibility defines the specific permissions for a user.
The Responsibility defines the specific permissions of a user.

cards.note: [Permissions] or [Privileges] control what a user is allowed to do within the system.

cards.sideA: El número único identifica a la persona en la base de datos.

sideB.text: The unique number identifies the person in the database.
The unique ID identifies the individual in the DB.
The unique number is used to identify the person in the database.

cards.note: This usually refers to a [Primary Key] or [Unique Identifier].

cards.sideA: El inicio de sesión necesitas el quien, el que, y donde.

sideB.text: The login needs the who, the what, and the where.
Logging in requires the who, what, and where.
The sign-in requires the who, the what, and the where.
The login session needs the who, the what, and the where.

cards.note: [Login] or [Sign-in] is the process of authenticating.

cards.sideA: Tenemos 2 guion bajo, y una palabra adicional.

sideB.text: We have 2 underscores, and an additional word.
We have two underscores plus an extra word.
There are two underscores and an added word.

cards.note: [Underscore] (_) is the character used in snake_case.

cards.sideA: Tenemos diferentes sintaxis.

sideB.text: We have different syntaxes.
We have varying syntaxes.
There are different syntaxes.

cards.note: The plural of [Syntax] is [Syntaxes].

cards.sideA: La sintaxis camel case usa minusculas y mayusculas.

sideB.text: Camel case syntax uses lowercase and uppercase.
The camel case syntax utilizes lowercase and uppercase letters.
Camel case syntax mixes lower and upper case.

cards.note:
[CamelCase] (or camelCase) capitalizes the first letter of each new word within the compound.

~The sintax of...~ (Spelling: The correct spelling is [syntax] with a 'y'.)

cards.sideA: La sintaxis snake case usa guion bajo.

sideB.text: Snake case syntax uses underscores.
The snake case syntax employs underscores.
Snake case relies on underscores.

cards.note: [snake_case] separates words with underscores.

cards.sideA: Usar mayusculas y minusculas es camel case.

sideB.text: Using uppercase and lowercase is camel case.
Using caps and lower case constitutes camel case.
The use of upper and lower case is called camel case.

cards.note: [Caps] is a common short form for [Capital letters] or [Uppercase].

cards.sideA: Todo en minuscula con guiones bajo es snake case.

sideB.text: Everything in lowercase with underscores is snake case.
All lowercase with underscores is snake case.
Using all lowercase joined by underscores is snake case.

cards.note: [Lowercase] refers to the small letters (a, b, c).

cards.sideA: Curl es una herramienta de línea de comandos.

sideB.text: Curl is a command-line tool.
Curl is a command-line utility.
Curl is a tool for the command line.

cards.note:
[CLI] stands for Command Line Interface.

~...tool of command-line~ (Grammar/Phrasing: In English, nouns often act as adjectives before the main noun. Use [command-line tool] instead of using 'of'.)

cards.sideA: El comando curl es ideal para probar APIs sin necesidad de una interfaz gráfica.

sideB.text: The curl command is ideal for testing APIs without a graphical interface.
The curl command is perfect for testing APIs without a GUI.
Curl is great for testing APIs without needing a graphical UI.
The curl command is ideal to test APIs without a user interface.

cards.note:
[GUI] (Graphical User Interface) is the visual component of software.

~...without a grafical interface~ (Spelling: The correct spelling is [graphical], with 'ph' instead of 'f'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué se supone que hacen?

sideB.text: What are they supposed to do?
What is their supposed function?
What are they meant to do?

cards.note:
[Be supposed to] implies an expectation, duty, or intended function.

~What do they suppose to do?~ (Grammar: The expression is [be supposed to]. It requires the auxiliary verb 'to be', e.g., [What are they supposed to do?].)

cards.sideA: Una vez que resolvamos el problema de la API, podremos crear un nuevo release.

sideB.text: Once we resolve the API issue, we can create a new release.
When the new API problem is resolved, we will be able to create a new release.
As soon as we fix the API problem, we can make a new release.
Once we solve the API issue, we can create a new release.

cards.note:
[Once] indicates that one event must strictly finish before the other starts.

[Release] is the standard term for a software deployment package.

cards.sideA: Dame un día para investigar y me pondré en contacto contigo.

sideB.text: Give me a day to dig around and I will get back to you.
Give me a day to investigate and I'll contact you.
Allow me a day to look into it and I will get back to you.
Give me a day to dig around and I will be in touch with you.

cards.note:
[Dig around] is a casual phrasal verb often used for investigating code or logs.

[Get back to you] is the standard business idiom for following up on a topic.

~...to look around...~ (Usage: [Look around] usually implies browsing or surveying a physical space. Use [look into] or [dig around] to investigate a problem.)

cards.sideA: El servidor Linux aloja el Oracle WebLogic Server.

sideB.text: The Linux server hosts the Oracle WebLogic Server.
The Oracle WebLogic Server is hosted on the Linux server.
The Linux server houses the Oracle WebLogic Server.

cards.note: To [Host] means to store and serve an application or service.

cards.sideA: Él me dijo que no venga.

sideB.text: He told me not to come.
He said not to come.
He told me I shouldn't come.

cards.note:
**Reported Speech Command**: Subject + told + object + [not to + verb].

~He said me...~ (Grammar: You cannot say 'said me'. Use [He told me] or [He said to me].)

cards.sideA: Él me dijo que venga.

sideB.text: He told me to come.
He asked me to come.
He said to come.

cards.note: **Reported Speech Command**: Subject + told + object + [to + verb].

cards.sideA: Este es el resultado esperado.

sideB.text: This is the expected result.
This is the anticipated outcome.
This is the result we were expecting.
This is the expected behavior.

cards.note: [Expected result] is standard QA terminology for defining pass conditions in test cases.

cards.sideA: Esto tomará harto tiempo.

sideB.text: This will take a long time.
This is going to take a lot of time.
This will take quite a while.

cards.note: [Quite a while] is a common idiom for a significant duration.

cards.sideA: Esto tomará poco tiempo.

sideB.text: This will take little time.
This won't take long.
This will be quick.

cards.note:
[Won't take long] is the most natural conversational way to say something is quick.

~This will take a little bit of time~ (Nuance: [A little bit of time] often implies a delay or 'some amount' of time, whereas 'poco tiempo' emphasizes quickness or [little time].)

cards.sideA: Estoy realmente agradecido por todo.

sideB.text: I am really grateful for everything.
I'm truly thankful for everything.
I really appreciate everything.

cards.note: [Grateful] describes the feeling, while [Appreciate] is the verb often used in professional contexts.

cards.sideA: La pelota está en la cancha de Shyam ahora.

sideB.text: The ball is in Shyam's court now.
It's in Shyam's court now.
The ball is on Shyam's side now.

cards.note:
**[175]**

Idiom: [The ball is in X's court] means it is that person's turn to take action or make a decision.

~The ball is in the court of Shyam~ (Idiom Structure: This idiom strictly requires the possessive form: [Shyam's court], not 'court of...'.)

cards.sideA: La UI de Oracle EBS tiene varias secciones, como SOA y ISG.

sideB.text: The Oracle EBS UI has several sections, such as SOA and ISG.
The Oracle EBS user interface contains various sections, like SOA and ISG.
The Oracle EBS UI features multiple sections, for instance SOA and ISG.

cards.note:
[UI] stands for User Interface.

[Such as] and [Like] are the standard ways to introduce examples.

cards.sideA: Lo que sé hasta ahora, es que...

sideB.text: What I know so far, is that...
All I know at this point, is that...
What I am aware of so far, is that...
What I know until now, is that...

cards.note: [So far] means 'up until the present moment' or 'to this extent'.

cards.sideA: No era capaz de hacerlo al comienzo.

sideB.text: I wasn't able to do it at the beginning.
I couldn't do it at the start.
I was unable to do it initially.
I wasn't able to do it at first.
I wasn't able to do it at the start.

cards.note:
[Was not able to] specifies capability in the past.

~I wasn't be able to...~ (Grammar Error: You cannot combine [wasn't] + [be]. Use: [I wasn't able to].)

cards.sideA: No estoy conectado a la VPN aún.

sideB.text: I am not connected to the VPN yet.
I haven't connected to the VPN yet.
I'm not on the VPN yet.

cards.note:
[Yet] at the end of a negative sentence implies you expect the action to happen soon.

~...connected in/on the VPN~ (Grammar: The correct preposition is [connected to]. You can be [on] the network, but you connect [to] the VPN.)

cards.sideA: No estoy seguro para qué es el documento.

sideB.text: I am not sure what the document is for.
I'm unsure of the document's purpose.
I am not certain what the use of the document is.

cards.note:
Structure: [What] + [Subject] + [Verb] + [Preposition] (e.g., What it is for).

~I am not sure what is the document for~ (Word Order: In indirect questions, the subject comes before the verb: [what the document is].)

~I am not sure for what is the document~ (Syntax: The preposition [for] usually goes at the end of the clause in natural English.)

cards.sideA: No me han dado los permisos para correr comandos en el server de Linux.

sideB.text: I haven't been given permissions to run commands on the Linux server.
I have not received authorization to execute commands on the Linux server.
I don't have the permissions to run commands on the Linux server.
They haven't given me the permissions to run commands on the Linux server.

cards.note: Passive voice ([I haven't been given]) shifts focus to your lack of access rather than who failed to give it.

cards.sideA: No sé a qué programa esa interfaz gráfica pertenece.

sideB.text: I don't know which program that GUI belongs to.
I do not know to which program that graphical interface belongs.
I'm not sure which program owns that GUI.

cards.note:
[Belongs to] indicates possession or association.

~...which program belongs to that GUI~ (Logic: The program is the 'owner' or container. The correct logic is [Which program that GUI belongs to].)

cards.sideA: No sé para qué es este comando.

sideB.text: I don't know what this command is for.
I don't know the purpose of this command.
I am unsure what this command does.

cards.note:
Idiomatic Question: 'What is this for?'

~I don't know for what this command is~ (Phrasing: The standard structure places the preposition at the end: [What this command is for].)

cards.sideA: Oracle Integration Repository es parte de ISG.

sideB.text: Oracle Integration Repository is part of ISG.
The Oracle Integration Repository belongs to ISG.
Oracle Integration Repository is a component of ISG.

cards.note: [ISG] typically stands for Integrated SOA Gateway in Oracle environments.

cards.sideA: Publicar el paquete de la Base de Datos como un servicio Web (REST API).

sideB.text: Publish the Database package as a Web Service.
Expose the Database package as a REST API.
Deploy the DB package as a Web Service.
Make the Database package available as a REST API.
Publish the DB package as a web-based service.
Set up the Database package as a RESTful service.

cards.note: [Expose] is a very common technical synonym for making an endpoint available for consumption.

cards.sideA: Sean le envió un correo a Sebastian.

sideB.text: Sean sent an email to Sebastian.
Sean emailed Sebastian.
Sean sent a mail to Sebastian.

cards.note: [To email] is a verb itself. 'Sean emailed Sebastian' is concise and professional.

cards.sideA: Shyam, Sean y John estarán en la reunión.

sideB.text: Shyam, Sean, and John will be in the meeting.
Shyam, Sean, and John are going to attend the meeting.
Shyam, Sean, and John will be present at the meeting.

cards.note: Use [Will] or [Going to] for future plans.

cards.sideA: Tengo unas cuantas capturas de pantalla y apuntes.

sideB.text: I have a few screenshots and notes.
I've got a couple of screenshots and notes.
I have some screenshots and jot-downs.
I have a couple of screenshots and notes.

cards.note:
[A few] implies a small number, but enough to be useful.

[Screenshots] are images taken of the display content.

cards.sideA: Ustedes han sido muy pacientes.

sideB.text: You have been very patient.
You guys have been really patient.
You've been extremely patient.

cards.note: [Have been] (Present Perfect) connects the past action of waiting with the present moment.

cards.sideA: ...Y tendremos alrededor de 6 nuevos arreglos.

sideB.text: ...And we will have around 6 new fixes.
...And we'll have about 6 new fixes.
...And we are going to have approximately 6 new fixes.

cards.note:
[Fixes] is the noun used for code corrections or patches.

[Around] or [About] indicates an estimation.

cards.sideA: ...Y estamos esperando poder testearla en producción.

sideB.text: ...And we are waiting to be able to test it in production.
...And we are hoping to test it in production.
...And we await the ability to test it in production.
...And we are expecting to test it in production.

cards.note:
[To be able to] is the necessary form when 'can' is needed after another verb (like waiting).

~...waiting for can test...~ (Grammar error: You cannot say 'for can'. Use [to be able to].)

cards.sideA: Estamos trabajando en la quinta versión.

sideB.text: We are working on the fifth version.
We're currently working on version five.
We are working on the 5th version.

cards.note:
**[123]**

[Fifth] (5th) is an ordinal number describing the position in a sequence.

cards.sideA: Estamos en la cuarta etapa de desarrollo.

sideB.text: We are in the fourth stage of development.
We're in the fourth development stage.
We are currently in stage four of development.
We are in the fourth step of development.

cards.note:
**[123]**

[Fourth] (4th) follows the standard rule of adding -th to the number four.

cards.sideA: Estamos revisando la tercera iteración.

sideB.text: We are reviewing the third iteration.
We're checking the third iteration.
We are going over the third iteration.

cards.note:
**[123]**

[Third] (3rd) is irregular. It is not 'threeth'.

[Iteration] is a standard Agile/Scrum term for a cycle of development.

cards.sideA: Si en el array JSON tenemos dos Rows, significa que el backend devolvió dos registros.

sideB.text: If we have two rows in the JSON array, it means the backend returned two records.
If the JSON array contains two rows, it implies the backend sent back two records.
Having two rows in the JSON array signifies that the backend returned two records.

cards.note:
In a database context, [records] is the standard term for 'registros'.

While 'rows' is correct when mapping directly to a DB, generic JSON items are often called [items] or [objects].

~...the backend fetched two records~ (Meaning Mismatch: [Fetched] implies the backend got data *from* the DB. [Returned] matches 'devolvió' (sending data *to* the frontend).)

cards.sideA: Cada Row del JSON equivale a una fila de una consulta SQL.

sideB.text: Each JSON row corresponds to a SQL query row.
Every row in the JSON is equivalent to a row in a SQL query.
Each row in the JSON represents a single row from a SQL query.
Each row of the JSON is equivalent to a row of a SQL query.

cards.note:
[Corresponds to] or [is equivalent to] are precise ways to describe data mapping.

~Each row is equals to~ (Grammar error: [Equal] is an adjective here, so use [is equal to]. However, [equivalent] or [corresponds] fits better for mapping concepts.)

cards.sideA: Porque estamos tratando a estas variables de forma especial.

sideB.text: Because we are treating these variables in a special way.
Because we're handling these variables specially.
Since we are dealing with these variables in a specific way.

cards.note:
[Handling] or [treating] are the correct verbs for 'tratar' code/data.

~We are treating these variables special~ (Grammar: You need an adverb here, [specially], or a phrase like [in a special way].)

cards.sideA: Acá estamos llenando a la variable.

sideB.text: Here we are populating the variable.
We're assigning a value to the variable here.
We are filling the variable here.

cards.note:
[Populating] is the most professional term for adding data to a structure (variable, array, or database field).

[Assigning] is specific to setting a value (e.g., `x = 10`).

cards.sideA: De esa forma, podemos tener de regreso los datos hacia el frontend.

sideB.text: That way, we can get the data back to the frontend.
In that way, we can return the data to the frontend.
This allows us to send the data back to the frontend.

cards.note:
[That way] is the most natural conversational connector for 'De esa forma'.

[To get something back] or [To send something back] captures 'tener de regreso'.

~...get back the data to the...~ (Phrasing: While not strictly incorrect, it is much more natural to place the object in the middle of the phrasal verb: [get the data back].)

~...have back the data...~ (Unnatural: Use [get ... back] or [receive ... back] instead of 'have back'.)

~That way, we can have the data back to the frontend~ (Incorrect collocation: [Have ... back] is not a standard construction for data transfer. Use [get] or [send].)

cards.sideA: De esa forma, podemos enviar de regreso los datos hacia el backend.

sideB.text: That way, we can send the data back to the backend.
In this way, we can pass the data back to the backend.
That allows us to return the data to the backend.
That way, we can send back the data to the backend.

cards.note:
[Pass data] is also common when moving data between layers.

~In that form~ (False Friend: 'Forma' here means [Way] or [Manner], not 'Form' (shape/document). Use [That way].)

cards.sideA: No sé qué hace este código.

sideB.text: I don't know what this code does.
I'm not sure what this code does.
I have no idea what this code is doing.
I don't know what this code is for.

cards.note:
When a question is part of a sentence ('I don't know...'), use normal Statement Order: [Subject + Verb].

Correct: [what this code does].
Incorrect: ~what does this code~.

cards.sideA: No sé para qué es esta función.

sideB.text: I don't know what this function is for.
I'm not sure what the purpose of this function is.
I don't know what this function does.
I don't know what this function is used for.

cards.note:
**[111]**

The preposition [for] usually goes at the end of the clause in English: [what this function is for].

~I don't know for what is this function~ (Unnatural word order).

~I don't know what is this function for~ (Incorrect word order: In indirect questions, the subject [this function] must come before the verb [is]. Correct: [what this function is for].)

cards.sideA: ¿Para qué es este código?

sideB.text: What is this code for?
What is this code supposed to do?
What's the use of this code?
What is this code used for?

cards.note:
**[111]**

Again, place [for] at the end.

[Supposed to do] implies you are asking about the *intention* behind the code.


~What is this code meant?~ is grammatically incomplete. You must say [What is this code meant to do?] or [What is this code for?].

cards.sideA: ¿Qué hace esta parte?

sideB.text: What does this part do?
What is this part doing?
What is the function of this part?

cards.note:
Standard question structure with the auxiliary [does].

~What makes this part?~ (False friend: 'Hacer' is [Do] here, not 'Make'.)

~What does this part does?~ (Incorrect: Double conjugation. After the auxiliary 'does', the main verb must be in the base form [do].)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué hace esta pieza de código?

sideB.text: What does this piece of code do?
What does this code snippet do?
What is this bit of code doing?
What does this part of the code do?

cards.note:
[Snippet] or [Piece of code] are common terms for a small segment of code.

~What does this code part?~ (Grammar error: Missing the main verb. Correct: What does this part [do]?)

~What does this part of code do?~ (Slightly unnatural: It is better to use the specific article [part of the code] or the compound noun [code snippet].)

~What does this piece of the code do?~ (Style: While possible, [piece of code] is the standard fixed phrase. If using 'the', [part of the code] is more natural.)

cards.sideA: Sí sé qué hace esta parte.

sideB.text: I do know what this part does.
I know what this part does.
I understand what this part is doing.

cards.note:
**[116]**

To emphasize 'Sí' in 'Sí sé' (affirming against a doubt), we use the auxiliary [do] before the verb.

Example: I [do] want to go.

~I do know what this part do~ (Subject-verb agreement error: 'This part' is singular, so the verb must be [does].)

cards.sideA: Sí sé para qué se usa esta parte.

sideB.text: I do know what this part is used for.
I know what this part is for.
I understand what this part is used for.
I do know what this part does.
I do know what this part is for.

cards.note:
The preposition [for] goes at the end.

~I know for what is used this part~ (Incorrect Word Order).

cards.sideA: Esto es equivalente a eso que dices.

sideB.text: This is equivalent to what you are saying.
This corresponds to what you're saying.
This amounts to the same thing you're saying.
This is equivalent to what you say.

cards.note:
[Equivalent to] is the standard phrase.

[What you are saying] is a noun clause acting as the object of 'to'.

~This is equivalent to that what you say~ (Redundant: Use just [what] instead of 'that what').

cards.sideA: Listo. / Hecho.

sideB.text: Done.
All set.
Finished.
Ready.

cards.note: [All set] is a very common, friendly way to say you are ready or a task is complete in a team context.

cards.sideA: ¡Ahí tienen! / ¡Ahí va! (Al pasar un link o archivo)

sideB.text: There you go.
Here you go.
Link is in the chat.
Here you are.
There you are.

cards.note:
[There you go] or [Here you go] are the standard phrases when physically handing something to someone or pasting a link in a chat window.

~Here you there~ (Incorrect phrase: You can say [Here you are] or [There you go], but do not mix them.)

cards.sideA: Acabo de enviarlo.

sideB.text: Just sent.
I just sent it.
Just sent it over.
Sent.

cards.note:
In chat contexts, it is acceptable to drop the subject 'I' and just say [Just sent].

[Just] is used for very recent past actions.

cards.sideA: Acabo de subirlo.

sideB.text: Just uploaded it.
It's up.
File is uploaded.

cards.note:
[It's up] is a very idiomatic phrasal way to say something has been successfully uploaded to a server or cloud.

~Just uploaded~ (Incomplete: Since the Spanish is 'subirlo', you need the object [it] in English: [Just uploaded it].)

cards.sideA: La base de datos devolvió más de 1.000 registros.

sideB.text: The database returned more than 1,000 records.
The DB returned over 1,000 records.

cards.note:
**[134]**

In the context of databases, a 'row' of data is always called a [record].

~The database returned 1,000 registers~ (Incorrect: [Register] usually refers to a hardware component in a CPU or an official list of names, not rows of data.)

~The database returned back...~ (Incorrect: 'Return' already means 'to go back' or 'to give back'. Adding 'back' is a redundancy/pleonasm.)

cards.sideA: Cada registro en SQL equivale a una fila completa en el JSON.

sideB.text: Each record in SQL is equivalent to a complete row in the JSON.
Every SQL record corresponds to a full JSON row.
Each SQL record is equivalent to a complete JSON row.

cards.note:
**[134]**

Here we use [record] because we are referring to a single unit of stored information.

cards.sideA: Por favor, firme el registro de visitantes.

sideB.text: Please sign the visitor log.
Please sign the logbook.

cards.note:
**[134]**

When we track *events* (like people entering or exiting) in chronological order, we use [log] or [logbook].

~Sign the visitor record~ (Less natural: 'Record' usually implies the permanent file kept *after* the fact, not the book you sign at the door.)

~Please sign the log visitor~ (Incorrect word order: In English compound nouns, the main noun comes last. Use [visitor log].)

cards.sideA: La iglesia mantiene un registro detallado.

sideB.text: The church keeps a detailed register.
The church maintains a detailed register.

cards.note:
**[134]**

We use [register] here because it refers to an official, formal book of names (births, marriages, etc.). Ideally, a 'roll' or 'official list'.

Note: You could also say 'keeps detailed [records]' (general history), but 'register' captures the specific meaning of 'El Registro' (the official book).

cards.sideA: Son cálculos traídos desde la lógica de Java.

sideB.text: These are calculations brought from the Java logic.
These calculations come from the Java logic.
These calculations are derived from the Java logic.
They are calculations brought from the Java logic.
These calculations are brought from the Java logic.

cards.note:
**[176]**

[Derived from] is a professional technical term when data or values are calculated or extracted from a specific source.

~Calculations bringed from~ (Grammar error: The past participle of 'bring' is [brought], not 'bringed'.)

cards.sideA: Los cálculos vienen de la lógica de Java, de la parte web.

sideB.text: The calculations come from the Java logic, from the web part.
The calculations stem from the Java logic, specifically the web side.
The calculations originate in the Java logic, on the web side.

cards.note:
**[176]**

For 'parte web' in architecture, we often use [web side], [web tier], or [web layer].

[Stem from] is an excellent phrasal verb to describe the origin or root cause of something (data, errors, or logic).

cards.sideA: ¿Y qué pasará con mis feriados legales?

sideB.text: And what will happen with my legal holidays?
And what about my statutory holidays?
And what happens to my legal holidays?

cards.note:
In a formal HR context, 'feriados legales' are often referred to as [Statutory Holidays] (mandated by law) or simply [Annual Leave].

[What about...] is a very common conversational shortcut for 'What is going to happen with...'.

~And what will it be with my legal holidays?~ (Incorrect: 'What will it be with' is unnatural. Use 'What will [happen to]' or 'What [about]'.)

cards.sideA: Quisiera saber cuál será el horario de mis turnos.

sideB.text: I would like to know what my shift schedule will be.
I'd like to know what my roster will be.
I wanted to know what my shift hours are going to be.

cards.note:
[Shift schedule] is the standard American term. In British/Australian English, [roster] or [rota] is very common.

~...the schedule of my turns~ (False Friend: 'Turno' in a work context is [Shift]. 'Turn' usually refers to taking turns in a game or queue.)

~I would like to know what will be my shift schedule~ (Incorrect: In embedded questions, the subject comes before the verb: 'what [my shift schedule] [will be]'.)

cards.sideA: Quisiera saber si el horario de mis turnos es conversable.

sideB.text: I would like to know if my shift schedule is negotiable.
I'd like to know if there's any flexibility with my shift hours.
I wanted to ask if my shift schedule is up for discussion.
I would like to know if the schedule of my shift is negotiable.

cards.note:
To express 'conversable' (meaning it can be changed/discussed), use [negotiable] or [flexible].

~...is conversable~ (False Friend: In English, 'conversable' means someone who is easy to talk to, not that a topic is open to negotiation.)

~...if my schedule shift is negotiable~ (Incorrect Word Order: Adjectives or noun modifiers go before the main noun. Use [shift schedule].)

cards.sideA: Esos son solo cambios de espacios en blanco.

sideB.text: Those are just whitespace changes.
These are only whitespace changes.
It's just changes in whitespace.
They are just whitespace changes.

cards.note: [Whitespace] refers collectively to spaces, tabs, and newlines in code. It is a mass noun (uncountable).

cards.sideA: Es solo formato, no hay cambios de lógica.
