sideB.text: It's just formatting, no logic changes.
This is purely formatting, there are no logic changes.
It is just formatting, with no changes to the logic.

cards.note:
[Formatting] usually refers to code style (indentation, spacing) rather than functional behavior.

~It's just format~ (Incorrect: Use [formatting] for the action/style.)

cards.sideA: Por favor ignora los cambios de espacios.

sideB.text: Please ignore the whitespace changes.
Please disregard the whitespace diffs.
Please overlook the changes in whitespace.
Please ignore the whitespaces.

cards.note: [Disregard] is a more formal and professional synonym for [ignore].

cards.sideA: Ejecuté el auto-formateador, por eso hay muchas diferencias de espacios.

sideB.text: I ran the auto-formatter, so there are many whitespace diffs.
I used the auto-formatter, that's why there are many whitespace changes.
I ran the formatter, which explains the whitespace differences.
I ran the auto-formatter, for that reason there are many whitespace differences.

cards.note:
[Diffs] is the standard developer slang for 'differences' in code versions/commits.

~...so for that reason, there are...~ (Redundant: Use [so] OR [for that reason], not both.)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando los NULLs a Números para evitar errores.

sideB.text: We are parsing NULLs into Numbers to avoid errors.
We're converting NULLs to Numbers to prevent errors.
We are parsing NULL values into Numbers to avoid bugs.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[To avoid] means to prevent something bad from happening.

~We are parsing NULLs to Numbers~ (Style: With 'parsing', [into] is preferred for transformation/conversion. See rule **[146]**.)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando los valores vacíos en tipos de datos específicos.

sideB.text: We are parsing the empty values into specific data types.
We're casting the empty values to specific data types.
We are converting empty values into specific data types.
We are parsing the empty values into specific kind of data.

cards.note:
**[146]**

A [Data Type] defines what kind of value a variable can hold (e.g., Integer, String, Boolean).

~We are parsing the empty values in specific data types~ (Incorrect: Use [into] for transformation.)

cards.sideA: (Estamos parseando la variable de PL/SQL para que SQL pueda leerla).

sideB.text: We are parsing the PL/SQL variable so SQL can read it.
We're converting the PL/SQL variable so it is readable by SQL.
We are parsing the PL/SQL variable to make it readable for SQL.

cards.note: PL/SQL and SQL are different engines; data often needs [parsing] or [casting] to move between them.

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando el formato del tipo de dato.

sideB.text: We are parsing the data type format.
We're converting the data type format.
We are handling the parsing of the data type format.

cards.note:
[Format] implies the specific layout or representation of the data (e.g., Date strings). [Data type format] = Formato de tipo de dato.

~We are parsing the format...~ (Incorrect: We parse the [value] or [data], not the [format].)

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes revisar las últimas diferencias/cambios?

sideB.text: Can you check the latest diffs?
Can you review the latest changes?
Could you check the last diffs?
Can you check the last differences?
Can you check the last changes?

cards.note: [To review] is more formal and implies a thorough examination, while [to check] can be quick.

cards.sideA: Este Pull Request tiene demasiados cambios/diferencias.

sideB.text: This PR has too many diffs.
This Pull Request has too many changes.
There are too many diffs in this PR.

cards.note: [PR] is the standard acronym for Pull Request in Git workflows.

cards.sideA: Hice varias pruebas de humo en la nueva funcionalidad.

sideB.text: I performed several smoke tests on the new feature.
I ran several smoke tests on the new functionality.
I executed various smoke tests on the new feature.

cards.note:
**[145]**

[Make] means to create or build something new (e.g., 'I made a cake'). It is incorrect to use it for executing existing tests.

~I made smoke tests~ (Incorrect).

In software testing, the standard verbs are [run], [execute], or [perform].

~I performed several smoke tests in the new feature~ (Incorrect: Use preposition [on] for testing targets.)

cards.sideA: Hice varios test rápidos en el nuevo fix.

sideB.text: I ran several quick tests on the new fix.
I performed several sanity checks on the new fix.
I executed a few quick tests on the new fix.

cards.note:
**[145]**

[Sanity Checks] is a professional term for "quick tests" to ensure basic functionality works after a fix.

~I ran several quick tests in the new fix~ (Incorrect: Use preposition [on] for testing targets.)

cards.sideA: Ok, haré algunas pruebas de humo en este asunto.

sideB.text: Ok, I will run some smoke tests on this matter.
Ok, I'll perform some smoke tests on this issue.
Ok, I will execute a few smoke tests on this.

cards.note:
**[145]**

Remember: We [run] tests, we do not ~make~ tests.

~smoking tests~ (Incorrect: The term is [smoke tests].)

cards.sideA: Ok, haré algunos test rápidos en este asunto.

sideB.text: Ok, I'll run some quick tests on this matter.
Ok, I will perform some quick tests on this issue.
Ok, I'll do some quick sanity checks on this.

cards.note:
**[145]**

Future tense with [will] or [going to] is appropriate here for immediate actions.

~I'll run some quick tests in this matter~ (Incorrect: Use preposition [on] or [regarding].)

cards.sideA: Aparte del formato, el código es el mismo.

sideB.text: Aside from the formatting, the code is the same.
Apart from the format, the code is identical.
Except for the formatting, the code is the same.
Aside from the format, the code is the same.

cards.note:
**[128]**

[Identical] is a strong synonym for 'the same'.

~Besides the formatting, the code is the same~ (Ambiguous: [Besides] often means 'In addition to'. Use [Except for] or [Apart from] for clarity.)

cards.sideA: Estamos inicializando contenedores vacíos.

sideB.text: We are initializing empty containers.
We're setting up empty containers.
We are initializing blank containers.

cards.note: [To initialize] means to assign an initial value or state to a variable or object.

cards.sideA: Estamos abriendo el puntero para permitir que el frontend recupere datos.

sideB.text: We are opening the pointer to allow the frontend to fetch data.
We're opening the cursor so the frontend can retrieve the data.
We are opening the reference cursor for the frontend to get the data.

cards.note:
In Database contexts, [fetch] or [retrieve] are the standard verbs for getting data.

~...to allow the frontend fetches data~ (Incorrect: After [allow] + object, use the [infinitive] 'to fetch'.)

cards.sideA: Estamos usando ROWNUM para generar un índice numérico para las filas.

sideB.text: We are using ROWNUM to generate a numeric index for the rows.
We're utilizing ROWNUM to create a numeric index for the rows.
We use ROWNUM to generate a row index.

cards.note:
[ROWNUM] is a specific pseudo-column in Oracle SQL that returns the number of the row in a result set.

~...index for the files~ (Incorrect: [ROWNUM] applies to database [rows], not [files].)

cards.sideA: P RECORDSET es el puntero del cursor SYS REFCURSOR.

sideB.text: P RECORDSET is the pointer for the SYS REFCURSOR cursor.
P RECORDSET acts as the pointer for the SYS REFCURSOR.
P RECORDSET is the SYS REFCURSOR pointer.
P RECORDSET is the cursor pointer.

cards.note: Prefixes like [P_] often denote a Parameter in stored procedures naming conventions.

cards.sideA: Que la variable sea local, significa que solo existe dentro del bloque.

sideB.text: That the variable is local means it only exists within the block.
Since the variable is local, it only exists inside the block.
The variable being local means it's scoped to the block.
That the variable is local means it only exists in the block.

cards.note: [Scoped to] is a very professional way to describe visibility logic in programming.

cards.sideA: Es solo una convención de nomenclatura.

sideB.text: It's just a naming convention.
It is simply a naming convention.
That's just a standard naming convention.

cards.note: A [Convention] is an agreed-upon standard or rule, not strictly enforced by the compiler but by the team. [Nomenclature] exists but is rare in IT; [Naming Convention] is the standard translation.

cards.sideA: Estamos creando 6 tablas virtuales, una por cada array.

sideB.text: We are creating 6 virtual tables, one for each array.
We're generating 6 virtual tables, one per array.
We are making 6 virtual tables, corresponding to each array.

cards.note:
**[145]**

A [Virtual Table] exists in memory during query execution, not on disk.

cards.sideA: Estamos creando 6 tablas virtuales, para luego unirlas con JOIN.

sideB.text: We are creating 6 virtual tables to join them later.
We're creating 6 virtual tables to join them afterwards.
We are setting up 6 virtual tables to perform a JOIN later.
We are creating 6 virtual tables so then we can join them.

cards.note:
**[145]**

[Join] is both a noun (SQL clause) and a verb (the action of combining tables).

cards.sideA: Al final, unimos las tablas por sus índices.

sideB.text: In the end, we join the tables by their indices.
Finally, we join the tables using their indices.
Ultimately, we join the tables based on their indices.
At the end, we join the tables by their indices.
In the end, we join the tables by their indexes.

cards.note: [Indices] is the plural of Index, though [Indexes] is also accepted in American English.

cards.sideA: Este nombre es solo un apodo.

sideB.text: This name is just a nickname.
This name is only an alias.
This is just an alias name.

cards.note: In SQL context, [Alias] is the technical term for a temporary name given to a table or column.

cards.sideA: Esto es solo un parseo.

sideB.text: This is just parsing.
This is just a parsing operation.
It's just parsing.

cards.note:
[Parsing] refers to analyzing a string of symbols (code) to understand its structure.

~This is just a parser~ (Incorrect: A parser is the tool/program, parsing is the action.)

~This is just parse~ (Incorrect: Grammar requires the gerund/noun 'parsing'.)

~This is just a parsing~ (Incorrect: [Parsing] as a process is uncountable. Remove [a].)

~This is just a parse~ (Style: 'Parse' is typically a verb. Use 'parsing' for the action.)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando esto antes de usarlo.

sideB.text: We are parsing this before using it.
We're parsing this prior to use.
We parse this before we use it.

cards.note: [Prior to] is a formal equivalent of [before].

cards.sideA: SQL no puede hacer un select en un ARRAY.

sideB.text: SQL cannot perform a select on an ARRAY.
SQL can't select directly from an ARRAY.
SQL acts on tables, so it cannot select from an ARRAY.

cards.note:
**[145]**

SQL is designed to work with sets (tables), not linear data structures like [Arrays] directly.

~SQL cannot perform a select into an ARRAY~ (Incorrect: [Select into] means saving data *to* the array, not querying *from* it.)

cards.sideA: Necesitamos convertir el ARRAY en una tabla virtual.

sideB.text: We need to convert the ARRAY into a virtual table.
We have to turn the ARRAY into a virtual table.
We need to parse the ARRAY into a virtual table.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Into] is the correct preposition when transforming one state/format to another.

~We need to cast the ARRAY into a virtual table~ (Incorrect: [Cast] is for type conversion; use [convert] or [unnest] for structures.)

cards.sideA: Necesitamos convertir temporalmente el ARRAY en una tabla virtual, para hacer un SELECT.

sideB.text: We need to temporarily convert the ARRAY into a virtual table to perform a SELECT.
We have to convert the ARRAY to a virtual table temporarily to select from it.
We need to cast the ARRAY into a virtual table temporarily for the SELECT.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Temporarily] means for a limited time, not permanently.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos el operador TABLE en el ARRAY para hacerle un SELECT.

sideB.text: We need the TABLE operator on the ARRAY to perform a SELECT.
We require the TABLE operator to select from the ARRAY.
We need to use the TABLE operator on the ARRAY to select data.

cards.note:
**[145]**

In Oracle SQL, the [TABLE()] operator casts a collection (array) into a queryable table source.

cards.sideA: El procedimiento estándar X devolverá datos de tipo JTF_NUMBER_TABLE.

sideB.text: The standard procedure X will return data of type JTF NUMBER TABLE.
Standard procedure X returns JTF_NUMBER_TABLE type data.
The standard proc X will pass back data of type JTF_NUMBER_TABLE.

cards.note:
[JTF] types (Java Technology Foundation) are common standard array types in Oracle EBS.

~The standard procedure X will return data type JTF...~ (Slightly imprecise. Use 'return data [of type] JTF...' or 'return JTF... type data'.)

cards.sideA: El procedimiento estándar Y tiene parámetros de salida tipo JTF_VARCHAR2_TABLE.

sideB.text: The standard procedure Y has output parameters of type JTF VARCHAR2 TABLE.
Standard procedure Y has JTF_VARCHAR2_TABLE type output parameters.
The procedure Y contains output parameters of the JTF_VARCHAR2_TABLE type.

cards.note: [Output parameters] (or OUT parameters) are variables where the procedure stores results to be read by the caller.

cards.sideA: El procedimiento estándar Z devolverá datos de tipo JTF_VARCHAR2_TABLE.

sideB.text: The standard procedure Z will return data of type JTF VARCHAR2 TABLE.
Standard procedure Z returns JTF_VARCHAR2_TABLE type data.
The Z procedure will return data formatted as JTF_VARCHAR2_TABLE.
The standard procedure Z will return data type JTF VARCHAR2 TABLE.

cards.note: [VARCHAR2] is the Oracle-specific data type for variable-length strings.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos inicializar las variables para evitar errores de nulos.

sideB.text: We need to initialize the variables to avoid null errors.
We must initialize the variables to prevent null pointer exceptions.
We need to set initial values for the variables to avoid nulls.

cards.note: A [Null Pointer Exception] occurs when code attempts to use a reference that points to no valid object.

cards.sideA: Una Common Table Expression es una vista local y temporal.

sideB.text: A Common Table Expression is a local and temporary view.
A CTE acts as a local, temporary view.
A Common Table Expression is effectively a temporary local view.
A Common Table Expression is a local temporary view.

cards.note:
[CTE] is a temporary result set that exists only for the duration of a single SQL statement.

~...local temporal view~ (Incorrect: Use [temporary] for short-lived items; [temporal] usually relates to time/history.)

cards.sideA: Una Common Table Expression solo existe mientras la consulta está corriendo.

sideB.text: A Common Table Expression only exists while the query is running.
A CTE exists only for the duration of the query execution.
A Common Table Expression persists only while the query runs.

cards.note: [Runtime] refers to the period during which a program (or query) is executing.

cards.sideA: CTE significa (Common Table Expression).

sideB.text: CTE stands for Common Table Expression.
CTE means Common Table Expression.
The acronym CTE stands for Common Table Expression.

cards.note: [Stands for] is the standard phrase to define what an acronym represents.

cards.sideA: Toda esta estructura es la que llegará al frontend.

sideB.text: This whole structure is what will reach the frontend.
This entire structure is what gets sent to the frontend.
This is the structure that will be delivered to the frontend.
This whole structure will reach the frontend.
This whole structure is what will be delivered to the frontend.
This whole structure is what will go to the frontend.
All this structure is what will reach the frontend.

cards.note:
Data flows from the [Backend] (server/DB) to the [Frontend] (client/browser).

~This whole structure is what will get the frontend~ (Incorrect: This means the structure acquires the frontend.)

~All thos structure...~ (Typo/Grammar: Use [All this structure] or [All these structures].)

cards.sideA: Todos estos Alias son los que veremos en el frontend.

sideB.text: All these Aliases are what we will see in the frontend.
These are the Aliases that will appear in the frontend.
We will see all these Aliases on the frontend side.
All these Aliases will be seen in the frontend.

cards.note:
DB column names are often mapped to different names in the frontend API response via [Aliases].

~All these Aliases are the ones will see~ (Incorrect: Missing subject or relative pronoun. Use 'the ones [we] will see' or 'the ones [that] will be seen'.)

cards.sideA: Cada uno de estos Alias se verán en el JSON de salida.

sideB.text: Each of these Aliases will be seen in the output JSON.
Each one of these Aliases will appear in the output JSON.
These Aliases will all be visible in the JSON output.
Each one of these Aliases will be seen in the output JSON.

cards.note:
[Output] refers to the data generated by a process.

~Each one of these Aliases will be watched in the output JSON~ (Incorrect: Use [seen], [visible], or [appear] for static data.)

cards.sideA: Convierte la colección PL/SQL en un tipo de datos legible por SQL.

sideB.text: It converts the PL/SQL collection into a SQL-readable data type.
It casts the PL/SQL collection to a SQL-readable type.
It transforms the PL/SQL collection into a format SQL can read.
Convert the PL/SQL collection into a SQL-readable data type.

cards.note:
**[146]**

We often use [Cast] or [Convert] for this action.

~...SQL legible data type~ (Incorrect: [Legible] usually refers to handwriting. For code/formats, use [readable].)

cards.sideA: Es solo para evitar errores.

sideB.text: It is just to avoid errors.
It's only to prevent mistakes.
It is simply to avoid errors.

cards.note:
[To avoid] and [To prevent] are often interchangeable in this context.

~It is just for avoid errors~ (Incorrect: After a preposition like 'for', you must use the gerund 'avoiding', or use the infinitive 'to avoid' to express purpose).

cards.sideA: Si el id del usuario es mayor a 0 podemos proceder.

sideB.text: If the user ID is greater than 0, we can proceed.
If the user ID is over 0, we can continue.
Provided the user ID is greater than 0, we can proceed.

cards.note:
**[94]**

[Greater than] is the standard mathematical comparison term (>).

[Provided] is a formal conditional connector similar to 'If'.

cards.sideA: Son las condiciones de unión.

sideB.text: They are the join conditions.
These are the join conditions.
Those are the conditions for the join.

cards.note: In SQL, the logic that links two tables is called a [Join Condition].

cards.sideA: Son las condiciones de Filtrado.

sideB.text: They are the filter conditions.
These are the filtering conditions.
They are the filter criteria.

cards.note: [Criteria] (plural) is often used for complex filtering logic.

cards.sideA: fnd_global gestiona las variables globales y el estado de la sesión actual.

sideB.text: fnd_global manages global variables and the current session state.
fnd_global handles global variables and the current session state.
The fnd_global package manages global variables and the session status.
fnd_global manages global variables and the current session status.

cards.note:
[fnd_global] is a core Oracle EBS package.

[Manages] or [Handles] are appropriate verbs for software components controlling state.

cards.sideA: APPS_INITIALIZE establece el contexto de seguridad simulando un inicio de sesión.

sideB.text: APPS_INITIALIZE sets the security context by simulating a user login.
APPS_INITIALIZE establishes the security context by simulating a login.
APPS_INITIALIZE configures the security context via a simulated login.
APPS_INITIALIZE sets the security context simulating a user login.

cards.note:
[Sets] or [Establishes] are used for configuring contexts.

[By simulating] explains the *method* (By + Gerund).

cards.sideA: USER_ID 6 identifica universalmente al usuario Invitado.

sideB.text: USER_ID 6 universally identifies the GUEST user.
USER_ID 6 is the universal identifier for the GUEST user.
The GUEST user is universally identified by USER_ID 6.

cards.note: [Universally] implies across the entire system/application instance.

cards.sideA: RESP_ID 22372 define los permisos y menús de un cliente de iStore.

sideB.text: RESP_ID 22372 defines the permissions and menus for an iStore customer.
RESP_ID 22372 sets the permissions and menus for an iStore customer.
RESP_ID 22372 determines the permissions and menus of an iStore client.

cards.note: In Oracle EBS, [RESP_ID] stands for Responsibility ID, which controls what a user can see and do.

cards.sideA: RESP_APPL_ID 671 identifica la aplicación Oracle iStore (IBE).

sideB.text: RESP_APPL_ID 671 identifies the Oracle iStore (IBE).
RESP_APPL_ID 671 corresponds to the Oracle iStore application.
Oracle iStore (IBE) is identified by RESP_APPL_ID 671.

cards.note: [IBE] is the internal short code for iStore.

cards.sideA: La importancia de INVITADO es que actúa como un usuario 'público'.

sideB.text: The importance of GUEST is that it acts as a 'public' user.
GUEST is important because it acts as a 'public' user.
The significance of GUEST is its role as a 'public' user.

cards.note: [Acts as] describes the function or role of an entity.

cards.sideA: La importancia de iStore es que es el módulo propietario del comercio electrónico.

sideB.text: The importance of iStore is that it is the e-commerce module owner.
iStore is important as it is the proprietary module for e-commerce.
The key to iStore is that it owns the e-commerce functionality.

cards.note: [Module owner] in EBS refers to the application that 'owns' the data/tables.

cards.sideA: Define los privilegios del rol 'Cliente'.

sideB.text: It defines the 'Customer' role privileges.
It establishes the privileges for the 'Customer' role.
It specifies the privileges of the 'Customer' role.
It defines the privileges of the role 'Customer'.
It defines the privileges of the role 'Client'.
It defines the privileges of the Customer role.

cards.note: [Privileges] refers to the specific rights to perform actions.

cards.sideA: IBE_CUSTOMER define los privilegios del rol 'Cliente'.

sideB.text: IBE_CUSTOMER defines the 'Customer' role privileges.
IBE_CUSTOMER sets the privileges for the 'Customer' role.
The 'Customer' role privileges are defined by IBE_CUSTOMER.
IBE_CUSTOMER defines the privileges of the role 'Customer'.

cards.note:
We generally use the structure [Subject + defines + Object].

~...of the rol 'Customer'~ (Spelling: The English spelling is [Role].)

cards.sideA: El formato de tipo de dato necesita parsearse.

sideB.text: The data type format needs to be parsed.
The data type format requires parsing.
We need to parse the data type format.

cards.note:
[Need] can be followed by a passive infinitive [needs to be parsed] or a gerund [needs parsing].

~The data type format needs to be parsing~ (Incorrect grammar. Use [needs parsing] or [needs to be parsed].)

cards.sideA: Probablemente esa es.

sideB.text: That is probably it.
That's probably the one.
That is likely it.
Probably that's it.
That's it probably.

cards.note: [That's it] is a common way to say 'Esa es' (identifying something correct).

cards.sideA: Probablemente eso es.

sideB.text: That is probably it.
That's likely the case.
That is probably correct.
Probably that's it.

cards.note: While 'Esa' and 'Eso' differ in gender in Spanish, in English [That] covers both.

cards.sideA: REG EXP LIKE significa Expresión Regular Similar.

sideB.text: REG EXP LIKE means Regular Expression Like.
REG EXP LIKE stands for Regular Expression Like.
The meaning of REG EXP LIKE is Regular Expression Like.

cards.note: [Means] defines the word. [Stands for] unpacks an acronym.

cards.sideA: REGEXP_LIKE compara texto con patrones complejos usando expresiones regulares.

sideB.text: REGEXP_LIKE compares text against complex patterns using regular expressions.
REGEXP_LIKE matches text with complex patterns using regular expressions.
REGEXP_LIKE compares text to complex patterns via regular expressions.
REGEXP_LIKE compares text with complex patterns using regular expressions.

cards.note:
[Compares ... against] is very precise for matching logic.

~compares text with~ (Acceptable, but 'against' or 'to' is often better for checking validity).

cards.sideA: Una Expresión Regular es una secuencia de caracteres que crea un patrón.

sideB.text: A Regular Expression is a sequence of characters that creates a pattern.
A regex is a sequence of characters creating a pattern.
A Regular Expression is a character sequence that forms a pattern.

cards.note: [Regex] is the standard abbreviation for Regular Expression.

cards.sideA: Los elegí al azar.

sideB.text: I chose them randomly.
I picked them at random.
I selected them randomly.

cards.note: We change the object pronoun from [it] to [them] for plural.

cards.sideA: GET LINE PRICE actúa estrictamente como un envoltorio.

sideB.text: GET LINE PRICE acts strictly as a wrapper.
GET LINE PRICE serves strictly as a wrapper.
GET LINE PRICE functions strictly as a wrapper.

cards.note:
A [Wrapper] is a function whose main purpose is to call another function, often to simplify the interface or add security.

~...acts strictly as a wrapping/wrap~ (Incorrect: In design patterns, the noun is [Wrapper].)

cards.sideA: Parsea el ID de entrada y delega la ejecución.

sideB.text: It parses the input ID and delegates the execution.
It analyzes the input ID and delegates execution.
It reads the input ID and delegates the execution.

cards.note: [To delegate] means to pass the responsibility or task to another component.

cards.sideA: No contiene lógica de negocio, solo parseo de parámetros.

sideB.text: It contains no business logic, only parameter parsing.
It doesn't contain business logic, just parameter parsing.
It holds no business logic, only parameter analysis.

cards.note: [Business Logic] refers to the core rules that determine how data is created, stored, and changed.

cards.sideA: La lógica de cálculo es manejada por el procedimiento interno.

sideB.text: The calculation logic is handled by the internal procedure.
The internal procedure handles the calculation logic.
Calculation logic is managed by the internal procedure.

cards.note: Passive voice [is handled by] shifts focus to the logic rather than the procedure.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos un valor de respaldo numérico, como 0.

sideB.text: We require a numeric fallback value, such as 0.
We need a numeric fallback, like 0.
We require a numeric default, for instance, 0.
We require a numeric placeholder value, like 0.
We require a number as a fallback value, like 0.
We need a numeric value as a fallback, like 0.

cards.note: A [Fallback] is a plan or value used if the original one fails or is missing.

cards.sideA: Usamos la variable J como marcador de posición.

sideB.text: We use the J variable as a placeholder.
We're using variable J as a placeholder.
The J variable is used as a placeholder.
We use the J variable like a placeholder.

cards.note:
A [Placeholder] is a temporary variable or value used until the final value is known.

~...as a position marker~ (Non-standard: The technical term for a temporary variable is 'placeholder'.)

cards.sideA: Retorna nulo si los 2 valores son iguales.

sideB.text: Returns null if the two values are equal.
It returns null if both values are equal.
It passes back null if the two values are the same.

cards.note: This describes the behavior of the `NULLIF` function.

cards.sideA: Estamos redondeando el valor, luego dividiéndolo.

sideB.text: We are rounding the value, then dividing it.
We're rounding the value before dividing it.
We round the value, then divide it.

cards.note:
**[94]**

Sequence of operations: [Action A], then [Action B].

cards.sideA: Estamos multiplicando el valor, luego sumándolo.

sideB.text: We are multiplying the value, then adding it.
We're multiplying the value, then summing it up.
We multiply the value and then add it.

cards.note:
**[63]**

[Then] acts as a connector for sequential actions.

cards.sideA: Estamos restando el valor, luego redondeando.

sideB.text: We are subtracting the value, then rounding it.
We're deducting the value, then rounding.
We subtract the value and then round it.

cards.note:
**[94]**

Math verbs: [Subtract] (Resta), [Round] (Redondear).

cards.sideA: Estamos redondeando al 7mo decimal.

sideB.text: We are rounding to the 7th decimal place.
We're rounding to 7 decimal places.
We are rounding off to the 7th decimal.
We are rounding to the 7th decimal.

cards.note:
**[123]**

The standard term for precision is [Decimal Place].

cards.sideA: Estamos implementando lógica de división segura.

sideB.text: We are implementing safe division logic.
We're applying safe division logic.
We are setting up safe division logic.

cards.note:
[Safe division] prevents 'Division by Zero' errors.

~...secure division logic~ (Incorrect: [Secure] implies protection against attacks. Use [safe] for preventing errors/crashes.)

~...safe logic division~ (Word Order: This implies the division of logic. Use [safe division logic] to describe logic for safe division.)

cards.sideA: Eso ya estaba.

sideB.text: That was already there.
That was already in place.
That already existed.

cards.note: [In place] is a common idiom in engineering to mean something is established, implemented, or ready.

cards.sideA: Eso ya estaba ahí.

sideB.text: That was already there.
It was already there.
That was already present right there.

cards.note: Emphasizing [there] points to a specific location in the code or file.

cards.sideA: El código de la provincia cambia dinámicamente.

sideB.text: The province code changes dynamically.
The province code changes on the fly.
The province code updates dynamically.
The code of the province changes dynamically.

cards.note:
**[175]**

[Dynamically] is the standard adverb for runtime changes.

[On the fly] is a more casual, very common technical idiom for dynamic changes during execution.

cards.sideA: Estoy mezclando lenguajes.

sideB.text: I am mixing languages.
I'm mixing up languages.
I am combining languages.

cards.note:
[Mixing] usually means using two things together (e.g., Python and SQL).
[Mixing up] implies confusion or making a mistake between two things.

cards.sideA: Estoy mezclando conceptos.

sideB.text: I am mixing up concepts.
I'm confusing concepts.
I am getting the concepts mixed up.
I am mixing concepts.

cards.note:
When you are confused between two ideas, the phrasal verb [mix up] is more accurate than just 'mix'.

~I am stirring concepts~ (Incorrect: 'Stir' is for liquids/cooking. Use 'mix up' or 'confuse' for ideas.)

cards.sideA: Tengo una vaga idea de cómo hacerlo.

sideB.text: I have a vague idea of how to do it.
I have a rough idea of how to do it.
I have a general idea how to do it.
I have a general idea of how to do it.

cards.note:
[Vague] means unclear or undefined.
[Rough idea] suggests an approximation or a draft plan, often used when you are about to start coding.

cards.sideA: Todos estos apodos son los que llegarán al frontend.

sideB.text: All these aliases are the ones that will reach the frontend.
All these nicknames will reach the frontend.
These are all the aliases that will get to the frontend.
All these aliases are what will reach the frontend.

cards.note:
In a data/database context (SQL `AS`), 'apodos' are technically called [Aliases].

[Nicknames] is the literal translation, usually reserved for people or user profiles.

cards.sideA: Los valores por defecto son estos.

sideB.text: These are the default values.
The default values are these.
These are the defaults.

cards.note: [Defaults] can be used as a noun to refer to 'default values'.

cards.sideA: Hasta ahí, todo bien.

sideB.text: So far, so good.
Everything is good so far.
Up to that point, everything is fine.
So far, everything is good.

cards.note:
[So far, so good] is the standard fixed expression for this sentiment.

~Until there, all good~ (Literal translation error. Use [So far] for 'hasta ahora/ahí' in progress contexts.)

cards.sideA: ¿Para qué es esta función?

sideB.text: What is this function for?
What does this function do?
What is the purpose of this function?
What is this function used for?

cards.note:
**[111]**

Standard question structure: [Question Word] + [Auxiliary/Verb] + [Subject] + [Preposition]?

~For what is this function?~ (While grammatically possible, it sounds very formal or archaic. [What is this function for?] is the standard natural form.)

~What does this function for?~ (Incorrect: 'Does' requires a main verb like 'do'. Since the question uses the preposition 'for' to ask about purpose, use the verb [is]: 'What [is] this function for?')

~What does this function used for?~ (Incorrect: 'Used' is a past participle here requiring the passive voice auxiliary [is], not 'does'. Correct: 'What [is] this function used for?')

~What is meant to be this function?~ (Incorrect Word Order: This asks about identity, not purpose. Correct structure: 'What [is] this function [meant to be]?')

cards.sideA: No sé qué hace esta parte del código.

sideB.text: I don't know what this part of the code does.
I'm not sure what this code snippet is doing.
I have no idea what this section of code does.

cards.note:
**[63]**

Indirect Question Rule: Use statement order [Subject + Verb].

Correct: ...what this part [does].

~...what does this part~ (Incorrect: In embedded questions, do not use the auxiliary 'do/does' and do not invert the order. The subject 'this part' must come before the verb 'does'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuáles serían mis feriados legales?

sideB.text: What would be my legal holidays?
Which ones would be my statutory holidays?
What are my statutory holidays?
Which ones would be my legal holidays?

cards.note:
When choosing from a specific group (days in a calendar), [Which] or [Which ones] is precise.

Use [What] or [Which] for days.

~Which ones my legal holidays would be?~ (Incorrect Word Order: For questions, the verb comes before the subject: [would be my legal holidays].)

cards.sideA: Solo arreglé la indentación ahí.

sideB.text: I only fixed the indentation there.
I just corrected the indentation there.
I simply fixed the indentation in that part.
I just fixed the indentation there.

cards.note: [Indentation] refers to the space at the beginning of a line of code to indicate hierarchy.

cards.sideA: El cambio de lógica real está en la línea 45.

sideB.text: The actual logic change is in line 45.
The real logic change is on line 45.
The logic change itself is found on line 45.

cards.note:
Use preposition [in] or [on] for code lines.

~The actual logic change is at line 45~ (Less common, but understandable. [On line X] is preferred.)

~The real logic change is on the line 45~ (Incorrect: Do not use [the] before a number; say [Line 45].)

~The actual logic change is in the line 45~ (Incorrect: Remove [the].)

cards.sideA: Ahora inserta un salto de línea.

sideB.text: Now it inserts a line break.
Now it adds a newline.
It inserts a newline character now.
Now, insert a line break.

cards.note:
[Newline] or [Line break] are the technical terms for the character that moves the cursor to the next line.

~...insert a break line~ (Incorrect: The compound noun is [line break], not [break line].)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando el array en una tabla virtual.

sideB.text: We are parsing the array into a virtual table.
We're converting the array into a virtual table.
We are parsing the array to create a virtual table.

cards.note:
**[146]**

We generally say [parse into] when transforming data structure A to structure B.

~We are parsing the array in a virtual table~ (Incorrect: Use [into] for transformation.)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando la lista en filas de SQL.

sideB.text: We are parsing the list into SQL rows.
We are converting the list into SQL rows.
We're transforming the list into SQL rows.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Rows] refers specifically to horizontal records in a database table.

~We are parsing the list in SQL rows~ (Incorrect: Use [into] for transformation.)

cards.sideA: La variable está siendo convertida por Cast a otro tipo.

sideB.text: The variable is being cast to another type.
We are casting the variable to a different type.
The variable is being converted via Cast to another type.

cards.note:
In programming, [Cast] is used as a verb: 'To cast X to Y'.

~The variable is being cast into another type~ (Incorrect: Use [to] for type casting.)

~...parsed by cast...~ (Incorrect: [Parsing] (analyzing text) and [Casting] (converting types) are different operations. Use [converted] or just [cast].)

cards.sideA: Lo elegí al azar.

sideB.text: I chose it randomly.
I picked it at random.
I selected it randomly.

cards.note: [At random] and [Randomly] are interchangeable adverbs here.

cards.sideA: El valor por defecto de la columna de estado es 'Activo'.

sideB.text: The default value of the status column is 'Active'.
The status column's default value is 'Active'.
'Active' is the default value for the status column.
The default value of the state column is 'Active'.

cards.note:
[Default value] is the value a variable/column takes if none is specified.

~The defect value...~ (Incorrect: [Defect] means a flaw or bug. Use [Default] for a preset value.)

~The default value of the state of the column...~ (Too wordy. Use [Status column] or [Column status] for technical precision.)

cards.sideA: Si G es igual a 0, el resultado de NULLIF es NULL.

sideB.text: If G is equal to 0, the result of NULLIF is NULL.
If G equals 0, NULLIF returns NULL.
When G is 0, the result of NULLIF is NULL.

cards.note: [NULLIF(a,b)] is a SQL function that returns NULL if a equals b, otherwise it returns a.

cards.sideA: Estamos realizando manejo de nulos aquí.

sideB.text: We are performing null handling here.
We're handling nulls here.
We are doing null handling here.

cards.note: [Null handling] is the technique of safely managing potential null values.

cards.sideA: Es mejor que lo aprendas rápido.

sideB.text: You'd better learn it fast.
It's best if you learn it quickly.
You better learn it fast.
It's better you learn it fast.

cards.note:
**[37]**

To give strong advice or a warning (implying negative consequences if not followed), we use [You'd better] (contraction of 'You had better').

~It's better that you learn it~ (Grammatically valid but less idiomatic for direct advice. [It's best if...] is a good alternative.)

cards.sideA: Necesitamos ver cuál es el cuello de botella que retrasa el sistema.

sideB.text: We need to see what the bottleneck slowing down the system is.
We need to identify the bottleneck delaying the system.
We need to find out what bottleneck is holding up the system.
We need to see what the bottleneck delaying the system is.
We need to see which one the bottleneck that is delaying the system is.
We need to see which one the bottleneck is.

cards.note:
**[148]**

A [Bottleneck] is a point of congestion in a system that slows down the overall process.

[Holding up] is a common phrasal verb for 'retrasando' or 'deteniendo' progress.

~...what is the bottleneck delaying the system~ (Incorrect Word Order: In embedded questions [statements], the verb must come after the subject: '...what the bottleneck... [is]'.)

~...which one is the bottleneck that is delaying the system~ (Incorrect Word Order: In a dependent clause within a statement, use subject-verb order: '...which one the bottleneck... [is]'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el cuello de botella que retrasa el sistema?

sideB.text: What is the bottleneck slowing down the system?
Which bottleneck is delaying the system?
What is the bottleneck holding up the system?
What is the bottleneck that delays the system?
Which one is the bottleneck that delays the system?
What is the bottleneck?
Which one is the bottleneck?

cards.note:
We use [What] when asking about the nature of the bottleneck.

 We use [Which] if we are selecting from a known list of potential bottlenecks.

~Which one is the bottleneck that it delays the system?~ (Incorrect: Do not use the pronoun [it] after 'that', as 'that' already represents the bottleneck.)

cards.sideA: Lo que más demora en cargar es...

sideB.text: What takes the longest to load is...
The part that takes the most time to load is...
What takes the most time to load is...
What takes the longest is...

cards.note:
**[102]**

This is a Noun Clause starting with [What] (Lo que).

~The which takes the longest~ (Incorrect: Never say 'The which'. Use [What] or [The thing that].)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué estás dispuesto a hacer?

sideB.text: What are you willing to do?
What are you prepared to do?
How far are you willing to go?

cards.note:
**[150]**

[To be willing to] means to be ready, eager, or prepared to do something (estar dispuesto).

~What are you disposed to do?~ (False Friend: 'Disposed' typically means 'inclined' or 'likely' [e.g., 'disposed to agree'], or 'arranged'. It is very formal and rarely used to mean 'willing' in this context.)

cards.sideA: Las mejoras del proceso no estaban ahí.

sideB.text: The process improvements weren't there.
The improvements to the process were not there.
The process enhancements weren't there.
The improvements of the process were not there.

cards.note:
**[175]**

[Improvements] or [Enhancements] are standard terms for 'mejoras'.

When using compound nouns, the singular acts as an adjective: [Process improvements] (not ~Processes improvements~).

~...weren't be there~ (Incorrect grammar: You cannot use 'were' and 'be' together like this. Use [weren't there].)

~The improvement process weren't there~ (Incorrect: Subject-verb agreement. [Process] is singular and requires 'wasn't'. Also, this changes the meaning from the specific [improvements] to the general [process].)

cards.sideA: Las fechas tentativas no las manejo yo.

sideB.text: I don't handle the tentative dates.
I don't manage the tentative dates.
The tentative dates aren't up to me.

cards.note:
[Tentative] means provisional or subject to change.

[To handle] is a very common verb for 'manejar' in the sense of dealing with or controlling a situation/task.

[Not up to me] is an idiomatic way to say it is not your decision or responsibility.

cards.sideA: Viene directo en el array.

sideB.text: It comes directly in the array.
It comes straight from the array.
It is found directly in the array.
It comes in the array directly.

cards.note: [Straight from] implies without intermediate steps.

cards.sideA: Itera por los valores y los suma.

sideB.text: It iterates through the values and sums them up.
It loops through the values and adds them.
It iterates over the values and sums them.
It iterates through the values and adds them.

cards.note:
We say [iterate through] or [iterate over] a list/array.

[Sum up] is the phrasal verb for calculating the total.

~...and then adding them~ (Incorrect grammar: Parallel structure is required. 'Iterates' (verb) ... 'adds' (verb).)

cards.sideA: Los detalles de precios están destinados a mostrar los ajustes de precios.

sideB.text: The pricing details are meant to display price adjustments.
The pricing details are intended to show price adjustments.
The pricing details are designed to display price adjustments.
The pricing details are meant to show the adjustment prices.

cards.note:
**[147]**

[Be meant to] is an excellent phrase for 'Estar destinado a', 'Tener el propósito de', or 'Se supone que'.

[Pricing] refers to the structure/strategy of prices, while [Price] refers to the value itself.

cards.sideA: Este campo tiene el propósito de capturar el email principal del usuario.

sideB.text: This field is meant to capture the user's primary email address.
This field is intended to capture the user's main email address.
The purpose of this field is to capture the user's primary email.
This field is meant to capture the main user's email.

cards.note:
**[175]**

Use [meant to] or [intended to] for functionality goals.

[Primary] is more formal and technical than 'Main' in database contexts.

[Capture] is the standard industry verb for getting input from a user.

~...the main email of the user~ (Unnatural: For people and users, we prefer the possessive 's: [the user's email].)

cards.sideA: La columna UNIT_LIST_PRICE está destinada a contener el precio sin ajustes.

sideB.text: The UNIT LIST PRICE column is meant to hold the non-adjusted price.
The UNIT LIST PRICE column is intended to contain the unadjusted price.
The UNIT_LIST_PRICE column is meant to store the price without adjustments.

cards.note:
**[147]**

Database columns [hold] or [store] data.

[Non-adjusted] or [Unadjusted] are precise technical terms.

cards.sideA: La función totalAdjustmentIncrement() tiene el propósito de calcular la suma.

sideB.text: The totalAdjustmentIncrement function is meant to calculate the sum.
The totalAdjustmentIncrement  function is intended to compute the sum.
The purpose of the totalAdjustmentIncrement() function is to calculate the sum.
The totalAdjustmentIncrement function is meant to calculate the addition.

cards.note:
**[147]**

Again, [is meant to] is the most natural way to describe what a function is supposed to do.

~...has the purpose of calculate...~ (Incorrect: After prepositions like 'of', you must use the gerund [-ing]: 'purpose of calculating'. Also, 'is meant to' is more natural than 'has the purpose'.)

cards.sideA: Todo este módulo está destinado a ser compatible con iOS 13.0 en adelante.

sideB.text: This entire module is meant to be compatible with iOS 13.0 and above.
This whole module is intended to support iOS 13.0 and later.
This module is meant to be compatible with iOS 13.0 onwards.
All of this module is meant to be compatible with iOS 13.0 and above.

cards.note:
**[147]**

For versions, we use [and above], [and later], or [onwards] to express 'en adelante'.

~...iOS 13.0 in forward~ (Incorrect literal translation.)

~All this module...~ (Incorrect: 'All' requires 'of' or 'the' in this structure: 'All of this module' or 'The whole module'. [This entire module] is more precise.)

cards.sideA: Lo que más me gusta es la simplicidad.

sideB.text: What I like the most is the simplicity.
The thing I like most is the simplicity.
What I like best is the simplicity.

cards.note:
**[149]**

This is a Noun Clause starting with [What] (Lo que).

Structure: [What] + [Subject] + [Verb] + [is]...

~What the most I like...~ (Incorrect: The word order is [What] + [Subject] + [Verb] + [Adverb]. Example: 'What I like most'.)

cards.sideA: Lo que menos me gusta es la falta de documentación.

sideB.text: What I like the least is the lack of documentation.
The thing I like least is the lack of documentation.
What I dislike the most is the lack of documentation.
What I don't like the most is the lack of documentation.

cards.note:
**[149]**

For 'Lo que menos...', we use [What I like the least] or we switch the verb to [What I dislike the most].

~What I less like...~ (Incorrect: [Less] is for comparisons (2 things). For 'lo que menos', use the superlative [Least] or [Dislike the most].)

cards.sideA: Lo que más pesa son los archivos de video.

sideB.text: What takes up the most space are the video files.
The heaviest files are the video files.
What uses the most storage are the video files.
What weighs the most are the video files.

cards.note:
**[149]**

While [heaviest] is technically correct, in digital contexts we often talk about what [takes up space] or [uses storage].

~What weights the most...~ (Incorrect: [Weight] is a noun. The verb is [Weigh]. Correct: 'What [weighs] the most'.)

~What weight the most...~ (Incorrect verb conjugation.)

cards.sideA: Lo que más toma tiempo es el envío de los datos.

sideB.text: What takes the longest is sending the data.
The most time-consuming part is the data transmission.
What takes the most time is sending the data.

cards.note:
**[149]**

[Takes the longest] is the most natural way to express maximum duration.

[Time-consuming] is a great adjective for 'algo que toma mucho tiempo'.

~What takes most time...~ (Incorrect: Superlatives require the definite article: 'What takes [the] most time'.)

~What takes the longest is the sending data~ (Incorrect: Use 'is sending data' or 'is the sending of data'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo sería eso?

sideB.text: What would that look like?
How would that work?
What would that be like?
How would it be?
How would that be?

cards.note:
When asking for a description or an explanation of a concept/process, [What would that look like?] is very common in business/tech contexts.

~How would be that?~ (Incorrect structure. Subject [that] must come after the auxiliary [would].)

~How would it be that?~ (Incorrect structure. 'That' is the subject, so it cannot be placed at the end if 'it' is also used as a dummy subject in this way.)

cards.sideA: abs() significa valor absoluto.

sideB.text: abs() stands for absolute value.
abs() means absolute value.
The function abs() represents absolute value.

cards.note:
When explaining abbreviations or acronyms, [stands for] is the precise verb.

Example: HTML [stands for] HyperText Markup Language.

cards.sideA: La función abs() siempre devuelve un número positivo.

sideB.text: The abs() function always returns a positive number.
abs() always returns a positive value.
The abs() function always yields a positive number.

cards.note:
In programming, functions [return] values.

~...comes back a number...~ (Incorrect: Use [returns].)

cards.sideA: Si el número es positivo, abs() no lo cambia.

sideB.text: If the number is positive, abs() doesn't change it.
If the number is positive, abs() leaves it unchanged.
For positive numbers, abs() makes no changes.

cards.note: [Leaves it unchanged] is a very elegant way to say 'no lo cambia'.

cards.sideA: Si el número es negativo, abs() elimina el signo.

sideB.text: If the number is negative, abs() removes the sign.
If the number is negative, abs() strips the sign.
For negative numbers, abs() gets rid of the sign.

cards.note:
**[65]**

[Strips] is a technical verb often used for removing characters or formatting.

[Get rid of] is a common phrasal verb for 'eliminar/deshacerse de'.

~...abs() deletes the sign~ (Unnatural: 'Delete' usually implies erasing a file or an object. For values or properties, we use [removes], [strips], or [drops].)

cards.sideA: Una vez resolvamos el problema, podremos crear un nuevo release.

sideB.text: Once we solve the problem, we can create a new release.
As soon as we fix the issue, we'll be able to cut a new release.
Once the issue is resolved, we can generate a new release.

cards.note:
Time Clause Rule: After [Once], [When], or [As soon as] referring to the future, use the **Present Tense**.

~Once we will solve...~ (Incorrect: Never use 'will' immediately after 'Once' in this context.)

[Cut a release] is common industry slang for creating a specific version.

cards.sideA: No quiero hacerlos perder el tiempo.

sideB.text: I don't want to waste your time.
I don't want to take up too much of your time.
I don't want to make you lose time.
I don't want you to waste your time.

cards.note:
[Waste time] implies using it unproductively.

[Take up time] implies occupying someone's schedule.

~Make you lose time~ (Understandable, but [waste your time] is the standard phrase.)

~I don't want to you waste...~ (Grammar Error: 'Want' is followed by Object + Infinitive: 'I don't want [you] [to waste]'.)

cards.sideA: No quiero cagarla.

sideB.text: I don't want to screw it up.
I don't want to mess it up.
I don't want to drop the ball.

cards.note:
[Screw up] and [Mess up] are common informal phrasal verbs for making a mistake ('cagarla'/'arruinarla').

[Drop the ball] is a business idiom meaning to fail in a responsibility.

cards.sideA: Sorry, estoy activando los captions.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm turning on the captions.
Sorry, I'm enabling the captions.
Apologies, I'm just switching on the closed captions.
Sorry, I'm activating the captions.

cards.note: Use [turn on], [switch on], or [enable] for features/settings.

cards.sideA: Sí, son súper útiles para mí los captions.

sideB.text: Yeah, captions are super useful for me.
Yes, captions are really helpful to me.
Yeah, I find captions very useful.

cards.note: [Helpful] and [Useful] are generally interchangeable here.

cards.sideA: Perdona, estoy algo perdido.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm a bit lost.
Excuse me, I'm a little lost.
Sorry, I'm not following.
Sorry, I'm a bit confused.

cards.note: [I'm not following] is a professional way to say you don't understand the current explanation.

cards.sideA: Perdona, estoy algo perdido en esta materia.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm a bit lost on this subject.
Sorry, I'm a little out of my depth here.
Excuse me, I'm not very familiar with this topic.
Sorry, I'm a bit lost on this matter.

cards.note: [Out of my depth] is an idiom meaning the topic is too advanced or difficult for your current knowledge.

cards.sideA: Necesito actualizar algunas filas del excel.

sideB.text: I need to update a few rows in the Excel file.
I need to update some rows in the spreadsheet.
I have to update a few rows in the sheet.

cards.note: [Spreadsheet] is the generic technical term for Excel/Google Sheets files.

cards.sideA: Si tuviese una reunión uno a uno, sería más sencillo.

sideB.text: If I had a one-on-one meeting, it would be simpler.
It would be easier if I had a one-on-one.
If I were in a one-on-one meeting, it would be easier.

cards.note:
**[9]**

Second Conditional: [If] + [Past Simple], ... [Would] + [Verb].

[One-on-one] (often written 1:1) is the standard term for a meeting between two people.

~If I had a meeting one-on-one...~ (Unnatural Word Order: Adjectives usually come before the noun in English: [a one-on-one meeting].)

cards.sideA: El problema ahora es este servicio que lo está arruinando todo.

sideB.text: The problem right now is this service that's messing everything up.
The issue now is this service that is ruining everything.
The problem is this service is screwing everything up.
The problem now is this service that is messing everything up.

cards.note: [Messing up] is informal but very common for 'arruinando' or 'desordenando'.

cards.sideA: Esto lo está arruinando todo.

sideB.text: This is ruining everything.
This is messing everything up.
This is throwing a wrench in the works.
This is messing up everything.

cards.note: [Throwing a wrench in the works] is an idiom for when something suddenly disrupts a plan or process.

cards.sideA: Tuvimos un retroceso.

sideB.text: We had a setback.
We hit a snag.
We experienced a setback.

cards.note:
[Setback] is the professional term for a reversal in progress ('retroceso').

[Hit a snag] implies encountering a small, unexpected problem.

~We had a stepback~ (Incorrect: Use [setback] for progress reversal. A 'step back' is a physical move or a strategic retreat.)

cards.sideA: Tuvimos un retroceso en ese tema.

sideB.text: We had a setback on that issue.
We faced a setback regarding that topic.
We hit a snag on that matter.

cards.note:
We typically use the preposition [on] or [with] when talking about setbacks in specific areas.

~We had a delay~ (Nuance: A [delay] means time was lost. A [setback] implies progress was lost or a new problem appeared.)

~We had a step back~ (Incorrect: [Step back] usually refers to physically moving back or gaining perspective. The noun for 'contratiempo' is [setback].)

cards.sideA: Lo que menos me gusta es la falta de puntualidad.

sideB.text: What I like the least is the lack of punctuality.
The thing I like least is the lack of punctuality.
What I dislike the most is the lack of punctuality.
What I don't like the most is the lack of punctuality.

cards.note:
**[149]**

For "Lo que menos...", we use the structure [What I like the least...].

Alternatively, you can switch the verb to the opposite ([dislike]) and use [the most].

cards.sideA: Lo que menos quiero es hacer eso.

sideB.text: What I want the least is to do that.
The last thing I want is to do that.
What I want least of all is to do that.
What I don't want the most is to do that.

cards.note:
**[149]**

Note that after [want] (a verb of intent), we use the **Infinitive** ([to do]), not the Gerund.

[The last thing I want] is a very common idiom to express strong reluctance ("lo último que quiero").

cards.sideA: Las reglas serán destacadas en color rojo.

sideB.text: The rules will be highlighted in red.
The rules will be marked in red.
Rules will be featured in red color.
The rules will be highlighted in red color.

cards.note:
Use [highlighted] when referring to visual emphasis in UI/UX.

~The rules will be bolded in red~ (Incorrect: 'Bolded' refers to thickness, not necessarily color. Use [highlighted] or [marked].)

cards.sideA: Se destacarán en rojo, en caso de no cumplirse las reglas.

sideB.text: They will be highlighted in red if the rules are not met.
They will stand out in red in case of non-compliance.
These will be shown in red if the rules are violated.
They will be highlighted in red in case of not meeting the rules.

cards.note:
**[152]**

To [meet the rules] or [meet requirements] is the standard professional way to say 'cumplir'.

~In case of not comply~ (Incorrect Grammar: After 'of', you must use a noun or gerund: 'of [non-compliance]' or 'of [not complying]').

~They will be highlighted in red in case of the rules are not met.~ (Incorrect: [In case of] must be followed by a noun or gerund, not a full clause. Use 'in case the rules are not met'.)

~It will be highlighted in red in case of not meeting the rules~ (Incorrect: Use 'They' to match the plural subject.)

cards.sideA: El precio se calcula según lo que cuesta el producto el día que se hace el pedido.

sideB.text: The price is calculated based on the product cost on the day the order is placed.
Pricing is based on the cost at the time the order is made.
The price depends on the product cost on the ordering date.

cards.note:
[To place an order] is the specific collocation for 'hacer un pedido'.

~On the day the order is done~ (Unnatural: We 'place' or 'make' orders, we don't 'do' them.)

cards.sideA: Eso tomaría un poco más de tiempo.

sideB.text: That would take a bit more time.
That would take a little longer.
That might take some extra time.
That would take a little more time.
That would take a little bit more time.

cards.note:
Use [would] for the conditional 'tomaría'.

[A little longer] is the most idiomatic way to express 'un poco más de tiempo'.

~That would take a little bit of more time.~ (Incorrect: Remove [of] in this structure. Use 'a little bit more time'.)

cards.sideA: Sean cambió este código.

sideB.text: Sean changed this code.
Sean modified this code.
Sean made changes to this code.

cards.note: Standard Past Simple. Use [modified] for a more formal/technical tone.

cards.sideA: Fue Sean quien cambió este código.

sideB.text: It was Sean who changed this code.
Sean was the one who modified this code.
It was Sean that made the changes to this code.

cards.note:
This is a Cleft Sentence (It was X who...). It is used to provide emphasis on the person.

~He was Sean who...~ (Incorrect: Use [It was] to introduce the subject of emphasis.)

~Sean was who changed this code.~ (Incorrect: Needs a noun/pronoun before 'who'. Use 'Sean was [the one] who'.)

cards.sideA: Por ahora no tengo una respuesta para eso.

sideB.text: I don't have an answer for that right now.
For the time being, I don't have an answer for that.
I don't have an answer to that at the moment.
For now I don't have an answer for that.

cards.note:
[For the time being] and [Right now] are common phrases for 'por ahora'.

~I don't have now an answer for that~ (Incorrect: Adverb placement. Use 'I don't have an answer for that [now]'.)

cards.sideA: Puedo trabajar en ello, crearé una task.

sideB.text: I can work on it; I'll create a task.
I can look into that and set up a ticket.
I can handle it; I'll open a task for it.

cards.note:
[I'll] (I will) for spontaneous decisions or promises. 

[Ticket] is often used instead of 'task' in Jira/ServiceNow environments.

cards.sideA: Echaré un vistazo en eso, y te haré saber.

sideB.text: I'll take a look at that and let you know.
I'll look into it and get back to you.
I'll check that out and keep you posted.
I'll take a look at that and I'll let you know.

cards.note:
Professional collocations: [Let you know], [Get back to you], [Keep you posted].

[Look into it] is more formal than 'take a look'.

~I'll take a look on that~ (Incorrect: The fixed preposition for this expression is [take a look at] something.)

~I'll take a look at that and I let you know~ (Incorrect: Tense mismatch. Use '...and [let] you know' or '...and [I will] let you know'.)

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time.
It's only a matter of time.
It's simply a question of time.

cards.note: [A matter of time] is the fixed idiomatic expression for 'cosa de tiempo'.

cards.sideA: Lo siento, no tengo ningún archivo adjunto.

sideB.text: I'm sorry, I don't have any attachments.
Sorry, I don't have any attached files.
I'm sorry, there are no files attached.

cards.note:
Use [Attachments] or [Attached files] for documents sent along with a message.

~I don't have any adjunt file~ (Incorrect: 'Adjunt' is not an English word. Use the past participle [Attached].)

cards.sideA: Al revisar el código para la visualización del catálogo, he encontrado ...

sideB.text: While reviewing the code for the catalog display, I found...
Upon reviewing the code for the catalog view, I've found...
While checking the catalog visualization code, I discovered...
While reviewing the code to see the catalog, I've found...

cards.note:
[While reviewing] or [Upon reviewing] are professional ways to introduce an action performed during another activity.

[Display], [View], and [Visualization] are common terms for 'visualización' in UI contexts.

cards.sideA: No estoy seguro de cuál es el comportamiento esperado para el catálogo.

sideB.text: I'm not sure what the expected behavior is for the catalog.
I'm uncertain about the expected behavior of the catalog.
I don't know what the intended behavior for the catalog is.

cards.note:
**[148]**

In technical English, [Behavior] refers to how a system or component functions.

Indirect Question Rule: The verb [is] goes at the end of the clause: '...what the expected behavior [is]'.

cards.sideA: No tengo que cambiar nada, a no ser que me lo pidan.

sideB.text: I don't have to change anything unless I'm asked to.
I don't need to change anything unless requested.
I am not to change anything unless I am told to.
I don't have to change anything, unless they ask me.

cards.note:
[Unless] means 'except if'. It is often followed by a passive structure like [unless I am asked].

~Unless they ask to me~ (Incorrect: 'Ask' does not take 'to' before the person. Correct: 'Unless they ask me'.)

cards.sideA: A no ser que me lo pidan, no debo cambiar nada.

sideB.text: Unless I'm asked, I shouldn't change anything.
Unless requested, I must not change anything.
Unless I am told otherwise, I won't change anything.
Unless they ask me, I shouldn't change anything.

cards.note:
[Shouldn't] indicates it is not advisable. [Must not] indicates a prohibition or strict rule.

[Unless told otherwise] is a very common professional phrase meaning 'a menos que se me diga lo contrario'.

cards.sideA: No he hecho este código en absoluto.

sideB.text: I didn't write this code at all.
I haven't written this code whatsoever.
I didn't create this code at all.

cards.note:
[At all] and [Whatsoever] are used at the end of negative sentences to add emphasis.

~I haven't made/done this code~ (Incorrect: In coding, we [write], [create], or [develop] code. Avoid using 'make' or 'do' for programming.)

cards.sideA: El codigo entrante a la izquierda.

sideB.text: The incoming code is on the left.
The incoming code is positioned on the left side.
The left side shows the incoming code.

cards.note:
**[153]**

In merge tools, [Incoming] refers to the changes coming from another branch/source.

Use the preposition [on] for sides: [on the left], [on the right].

~The incoming code to the left~ (Incorrect: In English, you must include the verb [is] to indicate location.)

cards.sideA: El codigo actual a la derecha.

sideB.text: The current code is on the right.
The current code is positioned to the right.
The right side shows the current code.

cards.note:
**[153]**

[Current] refers to the code in your local branch where you are merging into.

~The current code on the right~ (Incorrect: In English, sentences describing location require a verb like [is].)

cards.sideA: El codigo de la derecha es de la rama actual.

sideB.text: The code on the right is from the current branch.
The right-side code belongs to the current branch.
The code to the right represents the current branch.
The right code is from the current branch.
The code on the right side is from the current branch.

cards.note:
**[153]**

When comparing code in a diff viewer, we use [on the right] to locate the local version.

cards.sideA: El panel inferior es el resultado de ambos.

sideB.text: The bottom panel is the result of both.
The lower panel shows the outcome of both.
The panel at the bottom is the combined result.

cards.note:
**[153]**

[Bottom] or [Lower] panel refers to the merge editor's result area.

~The low panel is...~ (Incorrect: [Low] describes general height. To identify a specific position in a UI layout, use [Bottom] or the comparative [Lower] panel.)

~The low panel~ (Incorrect: [Low] describes general height. To identify a specific position in a UI layout, use [Bottom] or the comparative [Lower] panel.)

cards.sideA: Por lo general el codigo entrante tiene prioridad en el actual.

sideB.text: Usually, the incoming code takes priority over the current one.
Generally, incoming changes override the current code.
The incoming code typically has precedence over the existing one.
Usually, the incoming code has priority over the current one.

cards.note:
[Takes priority over] and [Has precedence over] are formal ways to say one thing is more important.

[Override] is a specific technical verb for one piece of code replacing another.

cards.sideA: Debemos presionar 'completar' por cada archivo.

sideB.text: We must press 'complete' for each file.
We have to click 'complete' for every file.
We need to hit 'complete' on every single file.

cards.note:
Use [Every] or [Each] for individuals in a group.

[Hit] is a common informal synonym for 'press' or 'click' a button.

cards.sideA: Baja un poco ese panel para ver los otros.

sideB.text: Move that panel down a bit to see the others.
Lower that panel slightly to view the rest.
Pull that panel down a little to see the other items.
Lower that panel down a bit to see the other ones.

cards.note:
[Move down], [Lower], or [Pull down] are used for UI elements.

[A bit], [Slightly], and [A little] are all used for 'un poco'.

~Low that panel down a bit~ (Incorrect: 'Low' is an adjective. Use the verb [Lower].)

cards.sideA: Sube un poco ese panel para verlo completo.

sideB.text: Move that panel up a bit to see it fully.
Raise that panel slightly to see the whole thing.
Push that panel up a little to see the full view.
Move that panel up to see it completely.

cards.note:
**[154]**

[Move up], [Raise], or [Push up] are the counterparts for moving elements upwards.

~Upper that panel to see it completely~ (Incorrect: [Upper] is an adjective, not a verb. Use the phrasal verb [Move up] or the verb [Raise].)

cards.sideA: Conserva lo que tienes ahi, no lo borres.

sideB.text: Keep what you have there; don't delete it.
Hold on to what you've got there; do not erase it.
Save what is there; don't wipe it out.

cards.note:
[Hold on to] is a phrasal verb meaning to keep something.

[Wipe out] is a phrasal verb meaning to completely erase or delete.

cards.sideA: No he dicho eso en 2 meses y medio atras.

sideB.text: I haven't said that in two and a half months.
It's been two and a half months since I said that.
I haven't said that since two and a half months ago.
I haven't told that in two and a half months.

cards.note:
**[151]**

When using [Ago] (atrás), we usually use the Past Simple: 'I said that 2 months ago'.

When using [Haven't said] (Present Perfect), we use [In] or [For] to show duration: 'I haven't said that [in] 2 months'.

~I haven't said that 2 months back~ (Unnatural: Use [ago] or duration with 'in/for'.)

cards.sideA: No he usado eso en 3 meses y medio atras.

sideB.text: I haven't used that in three and a half months.
I haven't used that since three and a half months ago.
The last time I used that was three and a half months ago.

cards.note:
Duration with Present Perfect: [Haven't used] + [in] + time.

[Three and a half] is the standard way to express '3 y medio'.

cards.sideA: El día que se hace el pedido.

sideB.text: The day the order is placed.
The date the order is made.
The day of the order placement.

cards.note:
[To place an order] is the idiomatic technical term for 'hacer un pedido'.

~The day the order is asked~ (Incorrect: 'Asked' is for questions. For products or services, use [placed], [requested], or [ordered].)

~The day the order is done~ (Incorrect: We don't 'do' orders. We [place] or [make] them.)

cards.sideA: He hecho una prueba rápida en el código.

sideB.text: I've run a quick test on the code.
I performed a quick test on the code.
I've carried out a quick test on the code.
I've performed a quick test on the code.

cards.note:
**[145]**

In technical English, we [run], [perform], or [execute] a test.

~I've made a quick test~ (Incorrect: We don't 'make' tests in programming context.)

~I've realized a quick test~ (False Friend: 'Realize' means to become aware of something. Use [performed] or [conducted] for 'realizado').

cards.sideA: Puedo confirmar que el servicio está funcionando como se esperaba.

sideB.text: I can confirm the service is working as expected.
I can confirm that the service is functioning as expected.
I can confirm the service is running as intended.
I can confirm that the service is working correctly.

cards.note:
[As expected] is the standard professional phrase for 'como se esperaba'.

Note that in the phrase 'confirm [that] the service...', the word 'that' is optional in English but the word order remains [Subject] + [Verb].

cards.sideA: El mapeo del nuevo endpoint en el archivo se ha actualizado correctamente.

sideB.text: The mapping of the new endpoint in the file has been updated correctly.
The new endpoint mapping in the file has been successfully updated.

cards.note:
[Mapping] refers to how one data element or URL is linked to another.

Use [Correctly] or [Successfully] to emphasize that the operation was completed without errors.

cards.sideA: El endpoint ya es accesible.

sideB.text: The endpoint is now accessible.
The endpoint is accessible now.
The endpoint is already accessible.
The endpoint is reachable now.
The endpoint is accessible already.

cards.note:
We use [Now] to indicate a change in state (it wasn't accessible before, but it is now).

[Reachable] is a common technical alternative to 'accessible' when talking about network endpoints.

cards.sideA: El día del envío del producto.

sideB.text: The product's shipping day.
The day the product is shipped.
The shipping date of the product.
The delivery day.

cards.note:
[Shipping] refers to the process of sending the goods.

~The day of the product send~ (Incorrect: 'Send' is a verb. Use the noun [shipping] or the past participle [shipped] in a passive structure.)

~The day of the product is shipped~ (Incorrect: Grammatically awkward. Use [The day the product is shipped].)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es la parte que más demora en cargar?

sideB.text: Which part takes the longest to load?
What part takes the most time to load?
Which part is taking the longest to load?
What part takes the longest to load?
Which one is the part that takes the longest to load.
What is the part that takes the longest to load?

cards.note:
**[2]**

For duration, we use the structure: [Takes] + [Time].

[The longest] is the most natural superlative for time duration.

~Which part delays more in load?~ (Incorrect: 'Delay' is usually transitive or implies lateness, not duration. Use [takes the longest].)

cards.sideA: Eso sería como un reinicio forzado.

sideB.text: That would be like a hard reset.
It would be similar to a forced reboot.
That would look like a hard reset.
That would be like a force restart.

cards.note: Use [be like] to make comparisons.

cards.sideA: El precio se calcula según lo que cueste el producto el día que se entrega.

sideB.text: The price is calculated based on the product cost on the delivery day.
The price is determined by the product's value on the day it is delivered.
The price is calculated according to the product cost at the time of delivery.

cards.note:
**[21]**

[Based on] and [According to] are perfect for 'según'.

~...in the delivery day~ (Incorrect: Specific calendar days or dates require the preposition [on].)

~Calculated like the cost~ (Unnatural: Use [based on] for calculations.)

cards.sideA: Eso me tomaría un poco más de tiempo.

sideB.text: That would take me a bit more time.
It would take me a little longer.
That might take me some additional time.
That would take me more time.

cards.note:
When specifying the person, the object pronoun [me] goes between the verb and the time: [take me] + [time].

~That would take to me...~ (Incorrect: Do not use 'to' with the verb 'take' in this context.)

~That would take me a little bit of more time~ (Incorrect: Remove [of]. Use 'a little bit more time'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuánto tomaría eso?

sideB.text: How long would that take?
How much time would that take?
How long might that take?
How long would it take?

cards.note:
**[102]**

Use [How long] for duration. 

~How would that take?~ (Incorrect: Questions about duration require [long] or [much time].)

~How much would that take?~ (Ambiguous: This sounds like you are asking about cost/quantity, not time duration.)

cards.sideA: Nunca he visto algo sobre eso.

sideB.text: I've never seen anything about that.
I haven't seen anything regarding that before.
I've never come across anything like that.
I've never seen anything like that.

cards.note:
Use [Present Perfect] (I have seen) for experiences. 

[Come across] is a phrasal verb meaning to find or see something by chance.

~I've never seen something about that~ (Incorrect: In negative sentences or Present Perfect experiences, use [anything] instead of 'something'.)

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo para que ocurra.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time before it happens.
It's only a matter of time until it occurs.
It is just a matter of time for it to happen.
It's just a matter of time until it happens.

cards.note:
Notice the use of [before] or [until] after the expression to indicate the event.

~It is matter of time~ (Incorrect: Needs the article [a matter of time]).

~It's just a matter of time to happen~ (Incorrect: In this specific idiom, we do not use the infinitive 'to' directly. You must use a clause starting with [before] or [until], or the prepositional phrase [for it to happen].)

~It's just a matter of time that it happens~ (Incorrect: Use [before] or [until] instead of 'that' in this idiom.)

cards.sideA: Esa rama es la que tiene cambios que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That branch is the one with the changes we need to pull.
That branch has the changes we need to bring in.
That's the branch that contains the changes we need to merge.
That branch is the one which has the changes we need to pull.
That branch is the one that has the changes we need to pull.
That branch is the one with the changes we need to fetch.

cards.note: In Git terminology, [Pull], [Bring in], or [Merge] are used for bringing changes from one branch to another.

cards.sideA: Esa tabla es la que tiene datos que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That table is the one with the data we need to fetch.
That table has the data we need to pull.
That's the table containing the data we need to bring over.
That table is the one which has the data we need to fetch.
That table is the one which has the data we need to bring in.
That table is the one that has the data we need to fetch.

cards.note:
For databases, [Fetch] is the standard verb for retrieving data.

~That table is who has~ (Incorrect: Use [which] or [that] for objects like tables, never 'who'.)

cards.sideA: El codigo entrante es el nuevo que viene.

sideB.text: The incoming code is the new one coming in.
Incoming code refers to the new changes.
The code coming in is the new version.
The incoming code is the new one coming.
The incoming code is the new one which is coming in.

cards.note:
[Incoming] is the technical term for the 'entrante' code in a conflict resolution tool.

~The incoming code is the new one is coming in~ (Incorrect: Missing the relative pronoun [which] or [that] to connect the clauses.)

cards.sideA: El día que se hace el pedido.

sideB.text: The day the order is placed.
The date the order is made.

cards.note:
We use the verb [place] for orders.

~The order day~ (Incorrect: This sounds like a day dedicated to ordering. Use [the day the order is placed].)

~The placed order day~ (Incorrect: Unnatural phrasing. Use a relative clause like 'the day the order is placed'.)

~The day the order is done~ (Incorrect: Use [placed] or [made] for formal requests.)

~The day of the order is placed~ (Incorrect: The word 'of' is unnecessary here. Use [The day the order is placed].)

~The order's day is placed~ (Incorrect: A day cannot be 'placed'; only the [order] is.)

~The day's order is placed~ (Incorrect: This implies 'the order belonging to the day', which does not match the prompt.)

cards.sideA: El día del envío del producto.

sideB.text: The product's shipping day.
The day the product is shipped.
The shipping date of the product.
The shipping day.
The delivery day.

cards.note:
[Shipping] refers to the process of sending the goods.

~The day of the product send~ (Incorrect: 'Send' is a verb. Use the noun [shipping] or the adjective [shipped].)

cards.sideA: Me comí la letra 'N'.

sideB.text: I dropped the 'n'.
I missed the 'n'.
I left out the 'n'.
I omitted the 'n'.
I dropped the 'n' letter.

cards.note: In a coding context, [dropped] or [missed] are very common ways to describe a typo where a character is missing.

cards.sideA: Le di un vistazo a eso, y te cuento que...

sideB.text: I took a look at that, and let me tell you...
I've had a look at it, and I'll let you know...
I checked that out, and here is what I found...
I took a look at that, and I'll let you know...

cards.note:
[Take a look] or [Check out] are the standard phrases for 'dar un vistazo'.

[Let me tell you] is used to introduce the feedback.

~I let you know~ (Incorrect: When promising information in the future, you must use the future [will] or [I'll].)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué tan lejos podré llegar?

sideB.text: How far will I be able to get?
How far can I go?
How far will I reach?
How far could I go?

cards.note:
**[102]**

[How far] is the question used for distance or progress.

Use [be able to] to express future ability.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué tan lejos podrás llegar?

sideB.text: How far will you be able to get?
How far can you go?
How far will you reach?
How far could you reach?

cards.note:
Same structure as the previous card, applied to the second person [you].
