~How far will you get reached?~ (Incorrect: Passive construction is grammatically incorrect here.)

~How far can you arrive?~ (Incorrect: Use [go] or [get] for distance; 'arrive' is only for specific destinations.)

cards.sideA: Dame un segundo, buscaré la traducción.

sideB.text: Give me a second; I will look up the translation.
One second, let me find the translation.
Hold on, I am going to search for the translation.
Hold on a second; I will look up the translation.
Give me a second; I will look the translation up.

cards.note:
The phrasal verb [Look up] is specifically used when searching for information in a dictionary, database, or list.

~I will look it up the translation~ (Incorrect: Redundant object. Use 'look up the translation' or 'look it up'.)

cards.sideA: Buscaré la traducción de lo que quiero decir.

sideB.text: I will look up the translation for what I want to say.
I am going to find the translation of what I mean.
I will search for the translation of my intended meaning.
I will look the translation up for what I want to say.
I will look up the translation of what I want to say.

cards.note:
[What I mean] is often more natural than the literal 'what I want to say' in a conversation.

~I will look the translation for what I want to say~ (Incorrect: Searching requires the particle [up] to complete the phrasal verb.)

Both [of] and [for] are correct here. Use [for] to emphasize the purpose (a translation intended for a phrase) and [of] to emphasize the content (the translation belonging to that phrase).

cards.sideA: La inicialización es donde le decimos a Oracle: ¿Quién pregunta?

sideB.text: Initialization is where we tell Oracle: Who's asking?
The init phase is where we define for Oracle: Who is requesting?
The setup is where we let Oracle know: Who is the caller?

cards.note:
In a database context, [Initialization] or [Init] refers to the process of setting up the session variables or security context.

~Initialization is where we say Oracle: Who's asking?~ (Incorrect: 'Say' requires [to] before a recipient; use 'tell Oracle' or 'say to Oracle'.)

cards.sideA: ¡Estoy casi seguro!

sideB.text: I'm almost certain!
I'm pretty sure!
I'm nearly positive!

cards.note: [Pretty sure] is very common in spoken English. [Almost certain] sounds more formal.

cards.sideA: Estoy casi seguro de lo que digo.

sideB.text: I'm almost sure of what I'm saying.
I'm pretty certain about what I am telling you.
I'm fairly positive about my statement.
I'm almost sure of what I say.

cards.note: You can be sure [of] something or sure [about] something. Both are correct.

cards.sideA: Arriba del UNION: Reglas especiales.

sideB.text: Above the UNION: Special rules.
Over the UNION: Special rules.
The part before the UNION: Special rules.

cards.note:
**[155]**

[Above] refers to the code lines that appear before the SQL [UNION] operator.

~Up the UNION~ (Incorrect: 'Up' is a direction, use [above] for spatial hierarchy.)

~Upper the UNION~ (Incorrect: 'Upper' is an adjective, not a preposition.)

cards.sideA: Abajo del UNION, todos los demás.

sideB.text: Below the UNION, everyone else.
Under the UNION, all the others.
The section after the UNION, all the rest.

cards.note:
**[157]**

[Below] is the standard way to describe code following a specific line or block.

cards.sideA: Si es necesario agregar formato para provincias que no sean Quebec.

sideB.text: If it is necessary to add formatting for provinces other than Quebec.
In case we need to add formatting for provinces besides Quebec.
If formatting needs to be added for provinces apart from Quebec.

cards.note:
**[128]**

[Other than] is the most professional way to say 'que no sean' in this context.

~...for provinces not other than Quebec~ (Incorrect: Double negative that creates a confusing meaning.)

cards.sideA: Primero consultamos aquí, luego acá, y finalmente aquí.

sideB.text: First we query here, then there, and finally here.
First we check here, then over here, and lastly here.
We search here first, then here, and finally in this spot.

cards.note: Connectors like [First], [Then], and [Finally] are essential for explaining data flow.

cards.sideA: Hice un nuevo amigo.

sideB.text: I made a new friend.
I have made a new friend.
I gained a new friend.

cards.note:
**[18]**

We always use the verb [make] for friends. 

~I did a new friend~ (Incorrect: In English, you 'make' friends, you don't 'do' them.)

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo antes que ocurra.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time before it happens.
It's only a matter of time until it occurs.
It is just a matter of time for it to take place.

cards.note: [A matter of time] is the fixed idiom for 'cosa de tiempo'.

cards.sideA: Que no sean esas.

sideB.text: Other than those ones.
Besides those.
Apart from those.
Other than those.

cards.note:
**[128]**

Use [other than] or [apart from] to exclude specific elements from a selection.

~Not those~ (Incorrect: This is a fragment used for pointing/rejection, not for expressing exclusion in a sentence.)

~Than not be those~ (Incorrect: Literal translation that doesn't follow English syntax for exclusion.)

cards.sideA: Estamos esperando que no sean de ese tipo.

sideB.text: We are hoping they aren't of that type.
We are expecting them not to be that kind.
We're hoping those aren't the type.

cards.note:
When you want something (Hoping), use [hope] + [clause]. When you anticipate something based on logic (Expecting), use [expect] + [object] + [to be].

~We are expecting them not that kind~ (Incorrect: Missing the infinitive [to be].)

~We are expecting other than that kind~ (Incorrect: 'Expect' requires a direct object or a specific action clause.)

~We are waiting that not be...~ (Incorrect: [Wait] is for time duration. For desires or logical anticipation, use [hope] or [expect].)

~We are expecting them not that kind~ (Incorrect: 'Expect' requires an [object + infinitive] structure. You must use [to be] to link the object to its description.)

~We are expecting aren't that kind~ (Incorrect: You cannot use a conjugated verb like [aren't] directly after the object in this structure; you must use the infinitive [to be].)

~We are expecting them aren't that kind~ (Incorrect: After the object 'them', you must use the infinitive 'to be' or 'not to be', not a conjugated verb like 'aren't'.)

cards.sideA: Estamos esperando que sean de ese tipo.

sideB.text: We are hoping they are of that type.
We are expecting them to be that kind.
We're hoping those are the type.

cards.note:
**[156]**

Positive counterpart of the previous card. Notice that after [hope], we use a normal sentence: [they are...]. After [expect], we often use an infinitive structure: [expect them TO BE...].

~We are expecting those kind~ / ~We are expecting those type~ (Incorrect: [Those] is plural and requires plural nouns like [kinds] or [types], or use 'that kind'.)

cards.sideA: El texto esta escrito en primera persona.

sideB.text: The text is written in the first person.
The text is in the first person.
The writing is in the first person.

cards.note:
Use [written in] for passive voice structures.

~The text is written by first person~ is incorrect because we use the preposition 'in' to describe the perspective or voice. Use [written in].

cards.sideA: Pidele que no te conteste en segunda persona.

sideB.text: Ask it not to answer you in the second person.
Tell it not to reply using the second person.
Ask for the response to not be in the second person.
Ask him not to answer you in the second person.

cards.note: Negative command: [Ask it not to] + [verb].

cards.sideA: ¿Que le pasa a el?

sideB.text: What is wrong with him?
What's going on with him?
What's happening to him?
What happens to him?

cards.note:
**[160]**

[What's wrong with...] is the most common way to ask about someone's state.

~What does he happen?~ is not valid because 'happen' is an intransitive verb where the subject is the event, not the person. Use [What happened to him?].

cards.sideA: ¿Que le paso a ella?

sideB.text: What happened to her?
What went on with her?
What was the matter with her?

cards.note:
**[160]**

[What happened] is the standard past tense for occurrences.

~What did it happen to her?~ is incorrect because 'happen' is intransitive and doesn't use the 'it' dummy subject in this specific question structure. Use [What happened to her?].

cards.sideA: No se como se dice ese oficio.

sideB.text: I don't know how to say that job.
I'm not sure how to call that trade.
I don't know the word for that profession.

cards.note: [Trade] or [Job] are natural for 'oficio'.

cards.sideA: (Solo puedes arrastrar y soltar los archivos aquí).

sideB.text: You can just drag and drop the files here.
You can only drag and drop files in this area.
Simply drag and drop your files here.

cards.note: [Drag and drop] is the standard UI terminology.

cards.sideA: (Usa la función de arrastrar y soltar para subir tu foto).

sideB.text: Use the drag-and-drop feature to upload your photo.
Use drag and drop to submit your picture.
You can use the drag-and-drop tool for your photo.

cards.note: When used as an adjective, it is hyphenated: [drag-and-drop] feature.

cards.sideA: Un embedding convierte palabras en una lista de números.

sideB.text: An embedding turns words into a list of numbers.
Embeddings transform text into numerical lists.
An embedding converts language into a sequence of numbers.
An embedding transforms words into a list of numbers.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Turns into] or [Converts into] are perfect for data transformations.

~transforms words in a list~ is incorrect for describing a conversion. Use [turns words into] or [transforms words into].

cards.sideA: Los embeddings representan el texto como coordenadas.

sideB.text: Embeddings represent text as coordinates.
Embeddings treat text as spatial coordinates.
Text is represented as coordinates through embeddings.

cards.note: [Represent as] is the standard technical term.

cards.sideA: Un vector es una lista de números llamada arreglo.

sideB.text: A vector is a list of numbers called an array.
Vectors are lists of numbers known as arrays.
An array is a list of numbers that represents a vector.
A vector is a list of numbers which is called an array.

cards.note:
[Called] or [Known as] are used to define terms.

~which are called array~ has subject-verb agreement issues (a list is...). Use [which is called an array] or [known as an array].

~A vector is a list of numbers called array~ is missing the indefinite article; use [called an array].

cards.sideA: Los vectores representan la ubicación exacta de un concepto.

sideB.text: Vectors represent the exact location of a concept.
Vectors show the precise position of a concept.
A vector maps the exact location of an idea.

cards.note:
[Maps] is a high-level verb for representing locations/relationships.

~ubication~ is a false friend from the Spanish 'ubicación'. Use [location].

cards.sideA: La búsqueda semántica busca el significado en lugar de palabras clave exactas.

sideB.text: Semantic search looks for meaning instead of exact keywords.
Semantic search focuses on intent rather than just keywords.
Instead of keywords, semantic search identifies the meaning.
Semantic search seeks meaning instead of exact keywords.

cards.note: [Instead of] is used to contrast two methods.

cards.sideA: La búsqueda semántica conecta 'abogado' con 'leyes' automáticamente.

sideB.text: Semantic search connects 'lawyer' with 'laws' automatically.
Semantic search links 'lawyer' and 'laws' by itself.
The system automatically associates 'lawyer' with 'laws'.

cards.note: [Associates with] is a formal synonym for 'connects'.

cards.sideA: RAG combina un motor de búsqueda con un modelo de lenguaje.

sideB.text: RAG combines a search engine with a language model.
RAG merges a search engine and a language model.
RAG is a combination of a search engine and an LLM.

cards.note: [LLM] stands for Large Language Model.

cards.sideA: Un pipeline es una secuencia de pasos automatizados.

sideB.text: A pipeline is a sequence of automated steps.
Pipelines are series of automated actions.
A pipeline refers to a chain of automated processes.

cards.note: [Chain of] is a good alternative for 'secuencia'.

cards.sideA: Los datos fluyen a través del pipeline de principio a fin.

sideB.text: Data flows through the pipeline from start to finish.
Information travels the pipeline from beginning to end.
Data goes through the entire pipeline.
Data flows through the pipeline from end to end.
Data flows through the pipeline from start to end.

cards.note:
[From start to finish] is the idiomatic way to say 'de principio a fin'.

[From start to end] is synonymous with [from start to finish]. However, [from end to end] implies covering the entire length or span, often translated as 'de extremo a extremo'.

cards.sideA: Los pipelines ayudan a organizar flujos de trabajo de IA complejos.

sideB.text: Pipelines help organize complex AI workflows.
Pipelines are useful for managing complex AI workflows.
Complex AI workflows are organized using pipelines.

cards.note: [Workflows] is the standard term for 'flujos de trabajo'.

cards.sideA: Un cluster es un grupo de servidores trabajando juntos.

sideB.text: A cluster is a group of servers working together.
Clusters are sets of servers operating in unison.
A group of servers working as one is called a cluster.

cards.note: [Working together] is simple and clear.

cards.sideA: Un cluster asegura que el sistema siga en línea si un servidor falla.

sideB.text: A cluster ensures the system stays online if one server fails.
Clusters guarantee uptime even if a server goes down.
A cluster keeps the system up if there is a server failure.

cards.note:
[Uptime] and [Stays online] are key for infrastructure.

~keeps online~ is not idiomatic. Use [stays online] or [remains online].

cards.sideA: LN en una variable significa 'Local number'.

sideB.text: LN in a variable stands for 'Local number'.
LN in a variable means 'Local number'.
The prefix LN usually represents 'Local number'.

cards.note: [Stands for] is commonly used for acronyms.

cards.sideA: La letra S significa Éxito

sideB.text: The letter S means Success.
The letter S stands for Success.
S represents Success in this context.

cards.note: Common flag in programming logic.

cards.sideA: La letra E significa Error

sideB.text: The letter E means Error.
The letter E stands for Error.
E is used to indicate an Error.

cards.note: Standard error flag.

cards.sideA: La letra U significa Error Inesperado

sideB.text: The letter U means Unexpected Error.
The letter U stands for Unexpected Error.
U represents an Unexpected Error status.

cards.note: [Unexpected] is used for errors not handled by specific logic.

cards.sideA: El código 200 significa Éxito

sideB.text: Code 200 means Success.
The 200 code represents a successful request.
A 200 status code indicates Success.

cards.note: Standard HTTP status for OK.

cards.sideA: El código 400 significa Error

sideB.text: Code 400 means Error.
The 400 code indicates a Bad Request or Error.
Status code 400 stands for a client-side Error.
The 400 code means Error.
400 code means Error.

cards.note: [Bad Request] is the official name for HTTP 400.

cards.sideA: La letra A significa Activo

sideB.text: The letter A means Active.
The letter A stands for Active.
A represents the Active status.

cards.note:
Common flag for database statuses.

~The A letter means Active~ is unnatural because in English, the identifying name usually follows the category noun. Use [The letter A].

cards.sideA: La letra Y significa Verdadero

sideB.text: The letter Y means True.
The letter Y stands for Yes or True.
Y represents a True boolean value.

cards.note: [Y] is usually 'Yes', representing 'True'.

cards.sideA: La letra N significa Falso o No.

sideB.text: The letter N stands for False or No.
The letter N means No or False.
N represents a False value.

cards.note: [N] is usually 'No', representing 'False'.

cards.sideA: La letra F significa Falso

sideB.text: The letter F stands for False.
The letter F means False.
F is used to represent a False boolean.

cards.note:
Direct boolean representation.

~The F letter~ is incorrect word order. In English, we place the specific identifier after the category. Use [The letter F].

cards.sideA: El record creado en otro paquete esta siendo poblado ahi

sideB.text: The record created in another package is being populated there.
That's where the record from a different package gets populated.
The record from another package is being filled in there.
The created record in another package is being populated there.

cards.note: [Is being populated] is the technical way to say data is being inserted/filled.

cards.sideA: Esto está fuera del alcance de mi trabajo.

sideB.text: This is out of the scope of my work.
This is outside my scope of work.
This falls outside the scope of my job.

cards.note: In professional contexts, [scope] refers to the boundaries of a project or role.

cards.sideA: El alcance del problema es enorme.

sideB.text: The scope of the problem is huge.
The scale of the issue is massive.
The magnitude of the problem is enormous.

cards.note:
[Scope] can also describe the extent or size of a technical challenge.

~The scope problem is huge~ is not valid because 'scope' requires the preposition [of] to connect it to the noun being described. Use [The scope of the problem].

cards.sideA: Arrastra el archivo hacia la carpeta.

sideB.text: Drag the file to the folder.
Drag the file into the folder.
Drag and drop the file into the folder.

cards.note: When moving items in a UI, use [drag to] for destination or [drag into] for containment.

cards.sideA: Se requiere que lo hagas si o si.

sideB.text: You are required to do it no matter what.
You must do it at all costs.
You're required to do it, period.
It requires you to do it no matter what.

cards.note:
The Spanish expression [Sí o sí] does not have a literal translation like ~yes or yes~.

To communicate this absolute necessity, English uses phrases like [no matter what], [at all costs], or the word [period] at the end of a sentence to indicate that there is no room for argument.

~It requires you do it no matter what~ is missing the particle 'to'. The verb 'require' follows the structure [require someone to do something].

cards.sideA: Deberemos hacerlo si o si.

sideB.text: We'll have to do it regardless.
We must get it done one way or another.
We are going to have to do it no matter what.
We must do it no matter what.

cards.note:
The Spanish expression [Sí o sí] does not have a literal translation like ~yes or yes~.

When [sí o sí] implies that something will happen despite obstacles, English speakers use [regardless] or [one way or another]. These emphasize that the result is inevitable.

~We must do it yes or yes~ is a common non-native error that should be avoided.

cards.sideA: Me dio risa

sideB.text: It made me laugh.
I found it funny.
I cracked up.
I laughed a lot.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, emotions and reactions are rarely 'given' (dar).

Instead of ~It gave me laugh~, we use a causative structure: [It made me laugh] or describe the internal state: [I found it funny].

[I cracked up] is a very natural phrasal verb used when something makes you laugh suddenly and intensely.

~I got laughed~ is incorrect because 'laugh' is an intransitive verb in this context; it doesn't describe a state you 'get'.

cards.sideA: Me dio hambre

sideB.text: I got hungry.
I started feeling hungry.
I'm getting hungry.
It made me hungry.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, emotions and reactions are rarely 'given' (dar).

Physical sensations like hunger or thirst use the verb [get] to indicate a change of state. 

~It gave me hunger~ is incorrect. Use [I got hungry] to describe the moment the sensation began.

~It made me hunger~ is incorrect because 'hunger' is a noun; you must use the adjective [hungry] in this structure.

cards.sideA: Me dio rabia

sideB.text: It made me angry.
I got so mad.
It was so frustrating.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, emotions and reactions are rarely 'given' (dar).

For intense negative emotions, English uses [make me] + adjective. 

~It gave me anger~ is not idiomatic. Use [It made me angry] to focus on the cause, or [I got mad] to focus on your reaction.

~I angered a lot~ is not natural. While 'anger' can be a verb, it is almost always used with an object. To describe your own feeling, use [I got angry] or [I was very angry].

cards.sideA: Me hizo feliz aquello.

sideB.text: That made me happy.
It made me happy.
That made me feel happy.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, we use the causative [make] + [object] + [adjective] to describe how something affects our emotions.

~It made me happy that~ is incomplete; [that] should be the subject [That made me happy] or refer to a specific clause.

cards.sideA: Me dio sueño la pelicula.

sideB.text: The movie made me sleepy.
It made me feel sleepy watching that movie.
That movie made me feel drowsy.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Sleepy] is the adjective for 'tener sueño'. In this case, the movie is the cause.

~It made me feel sleepy the movie~ is incorrect word order; the subject [the movie] should come first: [The movie made me feel sleepy].

cards.sideA: Me hizo pensar.

sideB.text: It made me think.
That made me think.
It gave me food for thought.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Food for thought] is a common idiom meaning something that provides mental stimulus or interest.

cards.sideA: Me hizo sentir mejor.

sideB.text: It made me feel better.
That made me feel better.
It made me feel a bit better.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Feel better] is the result caused by 'it' or 'that'.

cards.sideA: "nada que ver!" (idiom)

sideB.text: Not related at all!
Zero connection!
Completely unrelated!
That has nothing to do with it!

cards.note: [Nothing to do with it] is the most literal way to translate the sentiment of 'nada que ver' regarding topics.

cards.sideA: Usa una tabla de consulta para acelerar el proceso.

sideB.text: Use a lookup table to speed up the process.
The system failed during the database lookup.
Use a query table to accelerate the process.
Utilize a lookup table to optimize speed.

cards.note: [Lookup table] is the technical term for a table used to map or retrieve values quickly.

cards.sideA: Tenemos varias tablas de consulta para ese proposito.

sideB.text: We have several lookup tables for that purpose.
We have multiple lookup tables for that goal.
There are several lookup tables for that specific purpose.

cards.note: [Several] and [Multiple] are natural ways to say 'varias'.

cards.sideA: Chile está tres horas detrás del UTC.

sideB.text: Chile is three hours behind UTC.
Chile is UTC-3.
Chile lags three hours behind UTC.

cards.note:
**[177]**

Use [behind] to describe a negative offset from the UTC baseline.

cards.sideA: Canadá está dos horas detrás de Chile en el UTC

sideB.text: Canada is two hours behind Chile in UTC.
Canada lags two hours behind Chile on the UTC scale.
There is a two-hour UTC difference between Canada and Chile.

cards.sideA: El servidor de correo usa la hora UTC.

sideB.text: The mail server uses UTC time.
The email server is set to UTC.
The mail server runs on UTC.
The email server uses UTC time.

cards.note:
**[177]**

Servers typically [run on] or are [set to] UTC to maintain a consistent log timeline.

~The mail server uses UTC hour~ is not standard because [UTC] is already a time standard; we say [UTC time] or simply [UTC].

cards.sideA: UTC es el punto de partida para la hora mundial.

sideB.text: UTC is the starting point for world time.
UTC is the global time baseline.
UTC serves as the starting point for world time.
UTC is the start point for world time.

cards.note:
**[177]**

~UTC is the starting point for the world time~ is incorrect because 'world time' is a general concept that does not require [the].

cards.sideA: UTC-3 significa tres horas detrás del punto cero.

sideB.text: UTC-3 means three hours behind the zero point.
UTC-3 signifies being three hours behind point zero.
A UTC-3 offset means three hours behind the zero baseline.

cards.sideA: Chile usa el UTC-3 en verano y UTC-4 en invierno.

sideB.text: Chile uses UTC-3 in summer and UTC-4 in winter.
Chile switches between UTC-3 in summer and UTC-4 in winter.
Chile's offset is UTC-3 during summer and UTC-4 during winter.

cards.sideA: No se tanto como me gustaria.

sideB.text: I don't know as much as I'd like.
I don't know as much as I would like to.
My knowledge isn't as deep as I'd like it to be.

cards.note: Use [As much as] for comparisons of equality (or lack thereof).

cards.sideA: Apenas estoy sobreviviendo en las reuniones.

sideB.text: I'm barely surviving in the meetings.
I am just getting by in the meetings.
I'm barely keeping my head above water in the meetings.

cards.note: [Keeping my head above water] is an idiom meaning to just barely manage or survive a difficult situation.

cards.sideA: ... pero no tanto como me gustaria.

sideB.text: ...but not as much as I'd like.
...but not as much as I would like.
...but not to the extent I'd like.
...but not as much as I'd like to.

cards.note: [To the extent] is a formal way to say 'al grado' or 'tanto'.

cards.sideA: ¿Que hace esa opcion?

sideB.text: What does that option do?
What's the function of that option?
What does that setting do?

cards.note: Standard [What does ... do?] structure for inquiring about functionality.

cards.sideA: ¿Que hace este fragmento?

sideB.text: What does this snippet do?
What does this fragment do?
What is the purpose of this snippet?

cards.note: [Snippet] is the standard developer term for a small 'fragmento' of code.

cards.sideA: ... pero no tanto como quisiera.

sideB.text: ...but not as much as I'd want.
...but not as much as I would like.
...but not as much as I wish.
...but not as much as I'd want to.
...but not as much as I'd like to.

cards.note: Using [Wish] adds a slight tone of regret to the desire.

cards.sideA: Pidele en el prompt que te responda en tercera persona.

sideB.text: Ask it in the prompt to reply in the third person.
Tell it to respond in the third person within the prompt.
In the prompt, ask for a response in the third person.
Ask it in the prompt to answer you in the third person.
Ask it in the prompt to respond to you in the third person.

cards.note:
When interacting with AI, [ask it to] is standard for commands.

~answer your in the third person~ is incorrect because 'your' is a possessive adjective and needs a noun. Use [answer you].

~Ask it in the prompt to response you in the third person~ and ~Ask it in the prompt to response in the third person~ are incorrect because 'response' is a noun; use the verb [respond].

~Respond you~ is incorrect because 'respond' requires the preposition 'to' when followed by an object. Use [respond to you] or simply [answer you].

cards.sideA: (Este sitio web tiene una interfaz de arrastrar y soltar muy fácil).

sideB.text: This website has a very easy drag-and-drop interface.
The drag-and-drop interface on this site is very simple.
This site offers a user-friendly drag-and-drop UI.
This website has a very easy drag-and-drop UI.

cards.note: [User-friendly] is a common way to say something is easy to use.

cards.sideA: RAG obliga a la IA a consultar una biblioteca antes de responder.

sideB.text: RAG forces the AI to check a library before answering.
RAG makes the AI look up data before responding.
With RAG, the AI must consult a knowledge base first.
RAG forces the AI to query a library before answering.

cards.note:
[Knowledge base] is the technical term for the 'biblioteca' in RAG.

~ensures the AI to check~ is grammatically incorrect. 'Ensure' should be followed by a 'that' clause. Use [forces the AI to check].

cards.sideA: RAG evita que la IA invente hechos.

sideB.text: RAG prevents the AI from making up facts.
RAG stops the AI from hallucinating facts.
RAG keeps the AI from inventing information.

cards.note:
**[176]**

[Hallucinating] is the industry term for an AI inventing facts.

~avoids the AI from making up facts~ is incorrect; 'avoid' is followed by a gerund directly. ~prevents the AI make up facts~ is missing the preposition 'from'. Use [prevents the AI from making up].

cards.sideA: Los campos del record de otro paquete estan populandose ahi

sideB.text: The fields of the record from another package are being populated there.
That's where the record fields from another package are filled.
Record fields from a different package are being populated right there.
The fields of the record from another package are populated there.

cards.note: [Fields] are the specific attributes within a [Record].

cards.sideA: ¿Esto entra dentro del alcance del proyecto?

sideB.text: Is this within the project scope?
Does this fall under the project scope?
Is this in scope for the project?
Is this included in the scope of the project?
Is this in the scope of the project?

cards.note:
**[178]**

Use [in scope] or [within scope] to confirm if a task belongs to the current plan.

cards.sideA: Me puso nervioso lo que ellos dijeron.

sideB.text: What they said made me nervous.
What they said made me feel nervous.
It made me nervous what they said.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[What they said] acts as the subject that caused the state of being [nervous].

cards.sideA: Me dio asco esa cosa.

sideB.text: That thing made me sick.
That thing made me feel sick.
That made me feel disgusted.
I got sick with that thing.

cards.note:
**[39]**

To express 'dar asco', English often uses [made me sick] or [made me feel disgusted].

~It made me sick that thing~ is unnatural word order; use [That thing made me sick].

cards.sideA: Me hizo preguntarme eso que escuche.

sideB.text: What I heard made me wonder.
It made me wonder what I heard.
That made me question things after I heard it.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Wonder] is the base verb here. Remember that after [make], we use the base form without 'to'.

~What I heard, it made me wonder~ is redundant because [What I heard] is already the subject; you should not add [it] after it.

~It made me wonder about I heard~ is missing the relative pronoun; use [about what I heard].

cards.sideA: Me hizo quedar mal ella.

sideB.text: She made me look bad.
She made me look incompetent.
Her actions made me look bad.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[To look bad] is the standard idiom for 'quedar mal' in a social or professional sense.

~It made me look bad her~ is incorrect; the person doing the action must be the subject: [She made me look bad].

cards.sideA: Se requiere probar la función en el dispositivo real.

sideB.text: It is required to test the feature on a real device.
You are required to test the function on an actual device.
Testing the feature on the real device is required.

cards.note:
[Actual device] or [Real device] distinguish physical hardware from an emulator or simulator.

~It requires to test the feature on a real device~ is incorrect because [require] is not used as a dummy subject verb; use [It is required to test] or [Testing requires...].

cards.sideA: Quisiera que fuera más.

sideB.text: I wish it were more.
I'd like it to be more.
I want it to be more.
I'd like there to be more.

cards.note:
**[40]**

After 'I wish', we use the subjunctive [were] for hypothetical states.

~I'd like it to be more of it~ is invalid because it is redundant; use [I'd like more of it] or [I'd like it to be more] depending on whether you refer to quantity or quality.

~I'd like it there to be more~ is incorrect because it mixes the direct object 'it' with the existential 'there'. Use [I'd like it to be more] or [I'd like there to be more].

cards.sideA: Me gustaria que eso fuera mejor.

sideB.text: I'd like that to be better.
I wish that were better.
I would like that to be improved.

cards.note:
Structure: [I'd like] + [object] + [to be].

~I'd like that would be better~ and ~I'd like that will be better~ are incorrect because [would like] requires the [object + to + verb] structure.

~I'd like that was better~ and ~I'd like that were better~ are incorrect because 'would like' requires the [object + to + verb] structure: [I'd like that to be better].

cards.sideA: No estarán listas para el proximo release.

sideB.text: They won't be ready for the next release.
They aren't going to be ready by the next release.
Those won't be finished for the upcoming release.

cards.note:
Use [By] or [For] to indicate a deadline.

~They won't ready~ is incorrect; 'ready' is an adjective and requires the verb [to be].

cards.sideA: La petición en postman me devolvió un 400.

sideB.text: The Postman request returned a 400.
I got a 400 error from the Postman request.
The request in Postman resulted in a 400 status code.

cards.note:
In API context, [Returned] or [Got] are standard for status codes.

~The request returned 400~ is common, but adding [a 400] or [status 400] is more precise.

cards.sideA: La carga útil se encuentra en el cuerpo de la petición.

sideB.text: The payload is in the request body.
The payload can be found within the request body.
You'll find the payload inside the request body.
The payload is found in the request body.

cards.note: [Payload] refers to the actual data transmitted in an HTTP message.

cards.sideA: La petición en postman me retornó un 200.

sideB.text: The Postman request returned a 200.
I received a 200 OK response from Postman.
The Postman call came back with a 200.

cards.note: [Came back with] is an informal but very common way to describe API responses.

cards.sideA: La petición en postman me dio una respuesta con un código de estado.

sideB.text: The Postman request gave me a response with a status code.
The request in Postman returned a response and a status code.
I got a response with a specific status code from Postman.

cards.note: [Status code] is the formal technical term for the numeric response (200, 404, 500).

cards.sideA: ¿Qué ramas fueron unidas a la rama actual?

sideB.text: Which branches were merged into the current branch?
What branches have been merged into this one?
Which branches were joined with the current branch?
Which branches were merged into the current one?

cards.note:
**[146]**

In Git, [Merged into] is the standard preposition. 

~merged to the branch~ is less common than [merged into].

~Merged in the branch~ is acceptable but [merged into] is much more precise for technical operations involving integration.

cards.sideA: Estoy solo inventando.

sideB.text: I'm just making it up.
I'm just winging it.
I am simply inventing this as I go.

cards.note:
[Making it up] means creating a story or fact. [Winging it] means doing something without preparation.

~I'm just making up~ is not valid because [make up] (meaning to invent) is a transitive phrasal verb that requires an object like [it].

cards.sideA: Dejemos en claro eso.

sideB.text: Let's make that clear.
Let's be clear about that.
Let's get that straight.
Let's make it clear.

cards.note:
**[181]**

[Get that straight] is often used when resolving a confusion or misunderstanding.

~Let's leave it clear~ is a literal translation from Spanish. In English, we use [make it clear] to express clarifying a situation.

cards.sideA: Dejemos algo en claro.

sideB.text: Let me make one thing clear.
Let's clear something up.
Let's set the record straight.
Let's make something clear.

cards.note:
**[181]**

[Clear something up] usually implies resolving a doubt.

~Let's leave something clear~ is a direct translation; use [make something clear] or [set the record straight].

cards.sideA: DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line es simplemente una sentencia print.

sideB.text: DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line is just a print statement.
DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line is simply a way to print output.
It's just a print statement, DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line.

cards.note:
A [Print statement] is the general term in any language (Console.log, System.out.println, etc.).

~Print sentence~ is incorrect. In computing, code lines are [statements], not sentences.

cards.sideA: Agregué dos campos más a la clausula SELECT.

sideB.text: I added two more fields to the SELECT clause.
I've included two additional fields in the SELECT clause.
Two more fields were added to the SELECT clause.

cards.note: [Fields] is the common term for columns within a query context.

cards.sideA: Agregué dos atributos más a la clausula SELECT.

sideB.text: I added two more attributes to the SELECT clause.
I included two more attributes in the SELECT statement.
I've added a couple of attributes to the SELECT clause.

cards.note: [Attributes] is often used in relational modeling or OO contexts to refer to data fields.

cards.sideA: Son para usarlas más adelante en otro procedimiento.

sideB.text: They are for use later in another procedure.
Those are meant to be used later in a different procedure.
They'll be used further down the line in another procedure.
They are for using later in another procedure.
They are for being used later in another procedure.

cards.note:
[Later] or [Further down the line] indicate future use.

In the phrase 'for use', [use] is a **noun**. After a preposition like 'for', you must use either a noun or a [gerund] (-ing). If you use a verb, the structure is usually [to use].

cards.sideA: Bueno… porque funciona.

sideB.text: Well... because it works.
Well, simply because it works.
I mean, it works, that's why.

cards.note: A pragmatic response in development when logic is complex but effective.

cards.sideA: Hicimos esto para hacerlo funcionar.

sideB.text: We did this to make it work.
We implemented this in order to get it working.
This was done to ensure it works.

cards.note:
[To make it work] is the standard causative structure.

We did this.

~We made this to make it work~ is redundant and uses 'make' for an action; use [did this].

 ~To make it working~ is grammatically incorrect; the causative 'make' requires the [base verb] (work).

cards.sideA: Soy una persona ahorradora.

sideB.text: I am a thrifty person.
I'm a saver.
I'm very frugal with my money.
I don't spend too much money.

cards.note: [Thrifty] and [Frugal] are positive ways to describe someone who saves.

cards.sideA: No soy alguien gastador de dinero.

sideB.text: I'm not a big spender.
I don't spend much money.
I'm not the type of person who wastes money.
I don't like spending too much money.
I don't like to spend too much money.

cards.note:
[Big spender] is the idiomatic way to describe someone who spends a lot.

~I don't like spending to much money~ is incorrect because of the spelling of [too]. It should be [too much] to indicate an excessive amount.

cards.sideA: Perdón por el malentendido.

sideB.text: I apologize for the misunderstanding.
Sorry for the confusion.
My apologies for the mix-up.
Sorry for the misunderstanding.
Sorry for the mix-up.

cards.note: [Mix-up] is a very natural and slightly informal word for a small confusion.

cards.sideA: Oracle no te deja cambiar la password si tienes la misma anterior.

sideB.text: Oracle won't let you change the password if it's the same as the previous one.
Oracle doesn't allow you to reuse your old password.
You can't change the password in Oracle if you use the same one as before.
Oracle doesn't let you change the password if it's the same as the previous one.

cards.note: [Won't let you] is a natural way to describe system restrictions.

cards.sideA: Si tienes ‘Y’ significa ’S’, si no ‘H’.

sideB.text: If you have 'Y' it means 'S', otherwise it's 'H'.
If it's 'Y', then it stands for 'S', else it's 'H'.
'Y' means 'S'; if not, use 'H'.

cards.note:
**[179]**

[Otherwise] and [Else] are perfect for conditional logic.

cards.sideA: Una condición que no se cumpla nunca.

sideB.text: A condition that is never met.
A condition that is never fulfilled.
A condition that will never be true.

cards.note:
**[12]**

Technical term: [The condition is met] (se cumple).

~A condition that never meets~ is incorrect because 'meet' in this context is a transitive verb that requires a passive structure when the condition is the subject. Use [is never met].

cards.sideA: Eso lo usaremos más abajo.

sideB.text: We'll use that further down.
We're going to use that later on below.
That will be used further down in the code.
We'll use that below.

cards.note:
**[157]**

[Further down] is used for spatial position in a document or code file.

~We'll use it down~ is unnatural. For spatial location in files or lists, always use [below] or [further down].

cards.sideA: Eso lo usaremos abajo.

sideB.text: We'll use that below.
We will use that at the bottom.
That's for use below.

cards.note:
**[157]**

[Below] contrasts with [Above].

cards.sideA: Eso lo usaremos arriba.

sideB.text: We'll use that above.
We will use that at the top.
That's used above.

cards.note:
**[155]**

[Above] refers to preceding lines.

~We'll use that up~ is incorrect because 'up' implies direction or completion. To refer to a static position in a document or code, use [above] or [at the top].

cards.sideA: Limpié algunos comentarios.

sideB.text: I cleaned up some comments.
I've tidied up a few comments.
I removed some unnecessary comments.

cards.note: [Clean up] is the most common phrasal verb for refactoring or tidying code.

cards.sideA: Quisiera que fueran más.

sideB.text: I wish there were more.
I'd like for there to be more.
I want there to be more of them.
I'd want there to be more of them.
I'd like there to be more of them.

cards.note:
Subjunctive: [I wish there were] (not ~was~).

~I would like them to be more~ changes the meaning to 'I want them to be larger' or 'I want them to be something else'. To express existence (que hubieran), you must use the [there to be] structure.

~I would like them to be more~ is incorrect in this context because it translates to 'quisiera que fueran más [adjetivo]' (e.g., more professional) instead of referring to quantity.

~I would like them to be more of them~ is incorrect because it is redundant; the verb 'like' here requires the existential [there to be] structure to express 'que hubieran'.

cards.sideA: Me gustaría que ellos fueran mejor.

sideB.text: I'd like them to be better.
I wish they were better.
I'd want them to perform better.

cards.note: Structure: [I'd like] + [object] + [to be].

cards.sideA: La aplicación funciona inmediatamente.

sideB.text: The app works out of the box.
The application works immediately out of the box.
It works out of the box.
The application works immediately.

cards.note: In software, [out of the box] refers to features that work immediately without extra setup, configuration, or customization.

cards.sideA: El sistema ya trae seguridad integrada.

sideB.text: The system has security features out of the box.
The system provides built-in security out of the box.
Security is included out of the box.
The system has integrated security.

cards.note:
Use [out of the box] to describe products that are ready to use with all necessary components included.

~The system is out of the box security already~ is incorrect word order. You can say 'The system provides [security out of the box]' or has '[out-of-the-box security]'.

~The system includes already security features~ is incorrect because the adverb [already] should come before the verb [includes].

cards.sideA: Necesitamos una idea original.

sideB.text: We need an out of the box idea.
We need an unconventional idea.
We need an original, out of the box solution.

cards.note:
In creative contexts, [out of the box] refers to thinking in an unconventional or innovative way to solve a problem.

~We need an idea out of the box~ is unnatural. When used figuratively, [out-of-the-box] acts as a compound adjective and should precede the noun: 'an out-of-the-box idea'.

cards.sideA: Intenta pensar de forma diferente.

sideB.text: Try to think out of the box.
Try to think outside the box.
Try to think differently and out of the box.

cards.note: While [outside the box] is the literal idiom, [out of the box] is frequently used as an adjective for the same concept.

cards.sideA: En caso que no lo hagan a tiempo

sideB.text: In case they don't do it on time.
In case they fail to do it on time.
Should they fail to do it on time.

cards.note:
After [In case], we use the present simple to talk about future possibilities. [Fail to] is a professional way to say they didn't manage to do it.

~In case they won't do it on time~ is incorrect. In English, conditional or possibility connectors like [In case] or 'If' require the [Present Simple] for the future.

cards.sideA: No quiero dañar a nadie

sideB.text: I don't want to hurt anyone.
I don't want to harm anyone.
I don't want to cause any harm to anyone.

cards.note:
Use [Hurt] or [Harm] for people. 

~I don't want to damage anyone~ is incorrect because 'damage' is used for physical objects or abstract systems.

cards.sideA: No quiero dañar ninguna dependencia

sideB.text: I don't want to break any dependencies.
I don't want to damage any dependencies.
I don't want to mess up any dependencies.

cards.note:
In technical environments, we usually say [break] a dependency when a change causes it to stop working correctly.

~I don't want to break any dependence~ is incorrect in a technical context; we use the word [dependency] (plural [dependencies]) to refer to software components.

cards.sideA: Yo quisiera que ellos fueran más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I wish there were more of them.
I wish there were more.
I'd like there to be more of them.
I'd like there to be more.

cards.note:
**[182]**

**[40]**

When asking for a higher quantity (que hubieran más), use the existential [there were] after 'wish' or [there to be] after 'like'.

cards.sideA: Yo quisiera que fuera más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I wish there were more.
I'd like there to be more.
I wish there was more.
I'd like there to be more of them.

cards.note:
**[182]**

**[40]**

[I wish there were more] is the formal subjunctive for quantity. In casual speech, 'there was' is often heard but 'there were' remains the standard.

~I'd like them to be more~ is incorrect because it implies you want the people to change (be more professional or taller), not that you want a higher number of them to exist.

cards.sideA: Yo quiero que ellos sean más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I want there to be more of them.
I'd like there to be more of them.
I want more of them.
I want there to be more.

cards.note:
**[182]**

To express the desire for more items/people to exist, use [want there to be].

cards.sideA: Yo quiero que sea más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I want there to be more.
I'd like there to be more.
I want more.
I want there to be more of it.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[There to be] is the standard structure to express 'that there is/are' after verbs like 'want' or 'like'.

~I want it to be more~ is incorrect because 'it' refers to a specific object changing its state (e.g., being 'more' of something like 'more red'), not to the existence of a quantity. ~I want it to be more of it~ is clunky and redundant.

cards.sideA: Quiero que haya más claridad en los requirements.

sideB.text: I want there to be more clarity in the requirements.
I'd like there to be more clarity regarding the requirements.
I want more clarity in the requirements.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[Clarity] is the noun form of 'clear'. 

~I want that there is more clarity~ is a common mistake; in English, after 'want', we use the object + infinitive structure: [I want there to be].

~I want there is more clarity~ is incorrect because 'want' requires an object followed by an infinitive with 'to'. [I want there to be] is the correct structure.

cards.sideA: Me gustaría que hubiera menos ruido en la oficina.

sideB.text: I'd like there to be less noise in the office.
I wish there were less noise in the office.
I'd like for there to be less noise in the office.

cards.note:
**[182]**

After 'I wish', use the subjunctive [were] even for singular/uncountable nouns like 'noise'.

[Less] is used for uncountable nouns (noise), while ~fewer~ is for countable nouns.

cards.sideA: Ellos esperan que haya algunos delays debido a la migracion.

sideB.text: They expect there to be some delays due to the migration.
They are expecting some delays because of the migration.
They expect that there will be some delays due to the migration.
They are expecting some delays due to the migration.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[Expect there to be] follows the same pattern as 'want there to be'.

~They expect that there are delays~ is incorrect for future anticipation; use [there to be] or [there will be].

cards.sideA: El manager no quiere que haya ningún error en el reporte.

sideB.text: The manager doesn't want there to be any errors in the report.
The manager wants there to be zero errors in the report.
The manager doesn't want any errors in the report.

cards.note:
**[182]**

In negative sentences, use [any] instead of ~some~.

[Doesn't want there to be] is the correct negative structure.

cards.sideA: Nos encantaría que hubiera más recursos para este project.

sideB.text: We'd love there to be more resources for this project.
We would love for there to be more resources for this project.
We'd love to have more resources for this project.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[Would love there to be] is an emphatic way to express a wish.

~We would love that there are more resources~ is a literal translation error. Stick to the [there to be] infinitive structure.

cards.sideA: Hay problemas con acentos y signos en Frances

sideB.text: There are problems with accents and punctuation in French.
There are issues with French accents and signs.
French accents and punctuation marks are causing issues.

cards.note: [Punctuation marks] is the technical term for 'signos de puntuación'.

cards.sideA: Lo mas probable es que sea eso que dices

sideB.text: It's most likely what you're saying.
Most likely, it's what you said.
It's probably what you're talking about.
Most likely, it's what you are saying.

cards.note: [Most likely] indicates a high probability.

cards.sideA: Lo mas probable es que sea ese procedimiento

sideB.text: It's most likely that procedure.
That procedure is the most likely cause.
It's probably that procedure.

cards.note:
When talking about software logic, we often use [most likely] to diagnose bugs.

~Probably It's that procedure~ is awkward; the adverb 'probably' usually follows the verb 'to be'. Use [It is probably] or [It's probably].


~Most likely It's that procedure~ is awkward; the phrase [most likely] usually follows the verb 'to be' or requires a comma for proper flow.

cards.sideA: El no lo es, pero el otro lo es.

sideB.text: He isn't, but the other one is.
He's not, but the other one is.
He is not, but the other is.
He is not, but another one is.

cards.note:
We use [the other one is] to avoid repeating the adjective or noun.

~He is not, but the another one is~ is incorrect because 'another' cannot follow the definite article 'the'. Use [the other one] or simply [another one] without 'the'.

cards.sideA: El lo es, pero el otro no lo es.

sideB.text: He is, but the other one isn't.
He's the one, but the other isn't.
He is, while the other one is not.
He is, but another one isn't.

cards.note:
Observe the contrast using [but] or [while].


~He is, but the another one isn't~ is invalid because [another] (an + other) cannot follow the definite article [the].

cards.sideA: La razón por la que no se muestra es...

sideB.text: The reason it's not being displayed is...
The reason it's not getting displayed is...
The reason why it isn't showing up is...
The reason it's not showing up is...
The reason it's not displayed is...

cards.note: [Getting displayed] is a common passive structure in UI contexts.

cards.sideA: No esta funcionando bien en ISG de EBS

sideB.text: It's not working properly in EBS ISG.
It's not working in EBS ISG.
It is not functioning correctly within EBS ISG.

cards.note: [Properly] is the professional way to say 'bien' regarding functionality.

cards.sideA: Es mas directa esta manera.

sideB.text: This way is more direct.
This manner is more direct.
Doing it this way is more direct.
It is more direct this way.

cards.note:
[This way] refers to the method or approach.

~It's directly this way~ is incorrect because [directly] is an adverb. To describe a method, use the adjective [direct].

cards.sideA: Tenemos apodos para todo.

sideB.text: We have nicknames for everything.
We've got nicknames for everything.
Everything has a nickname here.
We have aliases for everything.

cards.note:
[Nicknames] (apodos) is common in dev teams for servers or complex components.

In Database contexts, the term [alias] is used instead of 'nickname' to provide temporary names to tables or columns.

cards.sideA: Se retorna un -1 como flag

sideB.text: A -1 is returned as a flag.
It returns a -1 as a flag.
The function returns -1 as a status flag.

cards.note:
[Flag] is a technical term for a variable that signals a specific condition.

~It is returned -1 as a flag~ is incorrect; use [A -1 is returned] (passive) or [It returns -1] (active) where 'it' represents the function.

cards.sideA: Retornamos un cursor vacio con un -1

sideB.text: We return an empty cursor with a -1.
It returns an empty cursor along with a -1.
An empty cursor with a -1 is returned.

cards.note: [Empty cursor] is the standard DB terminology.

cards.sideA: Es mejor prevenir que lamentar

sideB.text: Better safe than sorry.
It's better to be safe than sorry.
Prevention is better than cure.

cards.note: [Better safe than sorry] is the most common idiomatic version.

cards.sideA: Es solo una costumbre que tengo

sideB.text: It's just a habit of mine.
It is just a habit I have.
That's just a habit of mine.
It's just a habit that I have.

cards.note: [Habit of mine] is a natural way to describe personal routines.

cards.sideA: Los multiplicadores de cantidad van de 1 en 1

sideB.text: Quantity multipliers go by 1s.
Quantity multipliers increment by 1.
The quantity multipliers increase one by one.
Multipliers of quantity increment by 1.
Quantity multipliers go 1 by 1.

cards.note:
[Increment by] is the precise term for increasing a value by a specific amount.

~Quantity multipliers go 1 on 1~ is incorrect because '1 on 1' refers to personal interactions, not numerical increments.

cards.sideA: Cuando lo vea, te lo dire

sideB.text: When I see it, I'll tell you.
I will tell you when I see it.
Once I see it, I'll let you know.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[When I see it] uses the present simple for a future condition.

cards.sideA: Cuando yo este sin señal, podre usar un LLM local

sideB.text: When I'm without signal, I'll be able to use a local LLM.
When I have no signal, I can use a local LLM.
I'll use a local LLM when I am without signal.
When I'm without signal, I could use a local LLM.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[When I am without signal] corresponds to 'Cuando esté'.

cards.sideA: Cuando este en mi casa, voy a descansar

sideB.text: When I'm at home, I'm going to rest.
I will rest when I am at home.
When I get home, I'll rest.
When I'm at home, I'm going to take a rest.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[When I am at home] describes the state.

cards.sideA: Cuando tu estes dudando, solo preguntame.

sideB.text: When you're doubting, just ask me.
When you are in doubt, just ask me.
Just ask me when you are doubting.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[In doubt] is a very common idiom for 'dudando'.

cards.sideA: Cuando tu estes en casa, avisame.

sideB.text: When you're at home, let me know.
Let me know when you are at home.
When you get home, tell me.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[Let me know] is the standard way to say 'avísame'.

cards.sideA: Son solo importaciones y dependencias.

sideB.text: They are just imports and dependencies.
It's just imports and dependencies.
These are merely imports and dependencies.

cards.note: ~importacions~ is not an English word; the correct term is [imports].

cards.sideA: La importacion tiene dependencias.

sideB.text: The import has dependencies.
This import comes with dependencies.
The import implies dependencies.

cards.note: ~The importacion has dependencies~ is not valid because [importacion] is a Spanish word. In English, the correct term is [import].

cards.sideA: Es la dependencia de una importacion.

sideB.text: It's a dependency of an import.
It is an import dependency.
That's a dependency belonging to an import.
It's the dependency of an import.

cards.note: ~It's a dependency of an importacion~ is incorrect because [import] is the correct English term.

cards.sideA: No estamos ocultándo el mensaje.

sideB.text: We aren't hiding the message.
We are not suppressing the message.
We're not concealing the message.

cards.note: In logging contexts, [suppressing] is a common term for preventing a message from appearing.

cards.sideA: La cantidad de productos por paquete es diferente.

sideB.text: The quantity per pack is different for each item.
Pack sizes vary from product to product.
The item count per package is not the same for all products.
The quantity of products per pack is different.

cards.note:
[Item count] is a precise technical term for quantity.

~The amount of products~ is incorrect because 'amount' is used for uncountable nouns; use [number] or [quantity] for countable items like products.

~The quantity products per pack~ is not valid because it lacks the preposition [of] to connect the noun 'quantity' to 'products'.

cards.sideA: Las unidades por paquete varían según el producto.

sideB.text: Units per pack vary depending on the product.
Units per package change based on the SKU.
Each product has a different number of units per pack.
Units per pack are different depending on the product.

cards.note:
[SKU] (Stock Keeping Unit) is the standard acronym for a specific product code.

~Unit per pack are different~ is incorrect; use [Units per pack are] to maintain [subject-verb agreement].

~Units per pack are different depend on the product~ is incorrect because it requires the gerund [depending on] to function as a connector.

cards.sideA: Eso depende de la unidad de medida del producto.

sideB.text: That depends on the product's unit of measure.
It is based on the product's UOM.
That is determined by the specific unit of measure for each item.
That depends on the unit of measure of the product.

cards.note: [UOM] is the standard acronym for Unit of Measure.

cards.sideA: Estamos invirtiendo el signo.

sideB.text: We are flipping the sign.
We are inverting the sign.
We're reversing the sign.

cards.note: In programming, [flip] is very common for boolean toggles or sign reversals (+/-).

cards.sideA: Es necesario invertir el signo en esa condicion.

sideB.text: It's necessary to flip the sign in that condition.
We need to invert the sign in that condition.
The sign must be reversed in that condition.
It's necessary to flip the sign on that condition.

cards.sideA: Apuesto que en el futuro sera asi.

sideB.text: I bet it'll be like that in the future.
I bet in the future it will be like this.
I'm sure it's going to be that way in the future.

cards.note:
[I bet] is an informal but standard way to express strong confidence in a prediction.

~I bet on the future it will be like this~ is less natural; use [in the future] to describe when something will happen.

cards.sideA: Pero continuo no teniendo esa opción.

sideB.text: But I still don't have that option.
I still lack that option, though.
However, I continue to not have that option.
However, I continue not to have that option.

cards.note:
**[184]**

[Still don't have] is the most natural translation for 'continuo no teniendo'.

~But I'm still not having~ is incorrect because 'have' is a [state verb] and is rarely used in continuous forms. ~But I continue not having~ is grammatically possible but [less natural] than 'I still don't have'.

~However, I continue don't have that option~ is not valid because [continue] cannot be followed directly by the auxiliary [don't].

~However, I continue not to having that option~ is not valid because the [to-infinitive] structure requires the [base verb] 'have', not the gerund 'having'.

cards.sideA: Descarta los valores nulos.

sideB.text: Filter out null values.
Discard null values.
Exclude null values.

cards.note: [Filter out] explicitly means to remove unwanted items. [Filter] alone can sometimes be ambiguous (keep vs remove).

cards.sideA: Filtra el ruido de los datos.

sideB.text: Filter out the data noise.
Filter out the noise from the data.
Remove the noise from the data.
Filter out the noise of the data.

cards.sideA: Excluye los correos duplicados.

sideB.text: Filter out duplicate emails.
Exclude duplicate emails.
Remove duplicate emails.
Filter out the duplicated emails.

cards.note: ~It excludes duplicate emails~ changes the command into a [statement].

cards.sideA: Filtra los resultados viejos.

sideB.text: Filter out old results.
Filter out outdated results.
Exclude the old results.

cards.note:
[Outdated] refers to data that is no longer valid or relevant.

~It filters out old results~ and ~It filters old results~ change the [imperative] mood of the original sentence to a statement.

cards.sideA: El flujo de datos se interrumpió durante la actualización.

sideB.text: The data stream was interrupted during the update.
The flow of data stopped during the update.
The data stream got cut off during the update.
The data stream got interrupted during the update.

cards.note:
[Stream] is the technical term for a continuous flow of data.



~during the updating~ is incorrect; use the noun [update] to refer to the specific event or process.

cards.sideA: Debemos procesar este flujo de información de forma secuencial.

sideB.text: We must process this information stream sequentially.
We need to process this data flow sequentially.
This info stream has to be processed in sequence.
We must process this data stream sequentially.

cards.note: ~in a sequel way~ is incorrect; [sequentially] or [in sequence] are the correct terms for this context.

cards.sideA: El servidor no soporta una transmisión de audio tan pesada.

sideB.text: The server does not support such a heavy audio stream.
The server can't handle such a heavy audio stream.
The server doesn't support that heavy of an audio stream.
The server doesn't support an audio stream that is so heavy.
The server cannot handle an audio stream this heavy.
The server does not support an audio stream of that weight.

cards.note: ~The server does not support an audio stream so heavy~ is incorrect; use the [such a + adjective + noun] structure or place the adjective before the noun.

cards.sideA: ¿A quien se lo dijiste?

sideB.text: Who did you tell?
Who did you say that to?
To whom did you say it?

cards.note: [To whom] is very formal. [Who did you tell] is the standard daily/professional form.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién fue?

sideB.text: Who was it?
Who did it?
Who was the one?

cards.note: When asking about an action (who caused the bug?), [Who did it?] is usually the intended meaning.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién te lo dijo?

sideB.text: Who told you?
Who told you that?
Who said that to you?

cards.sideA: Probablemente fue un cambio indirecto.

sideB.text: It was probably an indirect change.
It was likely an indirect change.
That was probably a side effect.
Probably, it was an indirect change.

cards.sideA: No lo hare hoy, pero sí mañana.

sideB.text: I won't do it today, but I will tomorrow.
I'm not doing it today, but I definitely will tomorrow.
I won't do it today; however, I will tomorrow.

cards.sideA: No esta llegando el dato aun.

sideB.text: The data isn't arriving yet.
The data hasn't arrived yet.
We're not receiving the data yet.
The data isn't coming yet.

cards.sideA: ¿Ya ha llegado el dato?

sideB.text: Has the data arrived yet?
Did the data come in yet?
Is the data here yet?
Has the data arrived already?

cards.note: ~Has the data came in yet?~ is incorrect because the [past participle] of 'come' is 'come', not 'came'.

cards.sideA: El dato ya ha llegado!

sideB.text: The data has arrived!
The data is here!
The data has just come in!
The data has arrived already!

cards.note: Using [arrive] for data is correct and common in technical contexts to describe information reaching a destination.

cards.sideA: El servidor está teniendo una nueva dirección IP.

sideB.text: The server has a new IP address.
The server now has a different IP.
A new IP address belongs to the server.

cards.note:
**[184]**

~The server is having~ is a logic error. Ownership of an attribute is a [state], not an action.

~The server has a new IP direction~ is incorrect because [address] is the technical term for a network location, whereas 'direction' refers to an orientation or heading.

cards.sideA: El sistema está teniendo muchos errores de validación.

sideB.text: The system has many validation errors.
There are many validation errors in the system.
The system contains several validation errors.
The system has a lot of validation errors.

cards.note:
**[184]**

Avoid ~is having errors~ when describing a current state. Use [has] to denote the presence of these items in the system.

cards.sideA: Como el servidor falló, perdimos los logs.

sideB.text: Since the server failed, we lost the logs.
Since there was a server failure, the logs were lost.
Because the server crashed, the log data is gone.
As the server failed, we lost the logs.

cards.note:
**[186]**

[Since] here functions as a [conjunction of cause], providing the reason for the data loss.

~Like the server failed~ is incorrect because [like] is used for similarity or comparison, whereas [as] or [since] are required to express a cause or reason.

cards.sideA: Como ya terminaste, puedes revisar mi PR.

sideB.text: Since you've already finished, you can review my PR.
Since you are done, you can check my pull request.
Now that you are finished, feel free to review my code.
Since you finished, you can review my PR.
As you've already finished, you can review my PR.

cards.note:
**[186]**

Using [since] to translate 'Como...' at the beginning of a sentence is very common in professional requests.

cards.sideA: Ya sea que elijamos React o Vue, el tiempo de entrega es el mismo.

sideB.text: Whether we choose React or Vue, the delivery time is the same.
Whether we pick React or Vue, the lead time remains identical.
The delivery time is the same, regardless of whether we choose React or Vue.

cards.note:
**[185]**

[Whether] is used to present two alternatives (React vs. Vue) where the outcome remains constant.

~Whether we choose React or Vue, the deadline is the same~ is not accurate here because [delivery time] (the duration of the work) is different from a [deadline] (a specific date/time limit).



~Either we choose React or Vue, the delivery time is the same~ is incorrect because [either] is used for choices between two things, whereas [whether] is required to introduce a conditional clause where the result is independent of the choice.

cards.sideA: Ya sea que el servidor esté activo o no, la app debe funcionar offline.

sideB.text: Whether the server is active or not, the app must work offline.
Whether or not the server is up, the app should function offline.
The app needs to function offline, whether the server is online or offline.

cards.note:
**[101]**
**[185]**

The structure [Whether... or not] is the standard way to express 'Ya sea que... o no'.



~Either the server is active or not~ is not valid here; [either] implies a choice between two alternatives, while [whether] is used to indicate that the outcome (offline functionality) is the same regardless of the condition.

cards.sideA: No hay necesidad de reiniciar el servidor ahora.

sideB.text: There is no need to restart the server now.
We don't have a need to reboot the server at the moment.
There's no requirement to restart the server right now.

cards.note:
**[187]**

~There is no need of restarting~ is a common error. Although 'of' is a preposition, the noun [need] implies a [requirement for a future action], so it must be followed by [to + infinitive].

cards.sideA: Esta es nuestra oportunidad de corregir el error.

sideB.text: This is our opportunity to fix the error.
We have an opportunity to correct the bug now.
This represents our opening to fix the mistake.

cards.note:
**[187]**

~Our opportunity of fixing~ is incorrect. The noun [opportunity] describes [potential], and follows the semantic pattern that requires the [to + infinitive] structure.

cards.sideA: El plan de actualizar la base de datos ha cambiado.

sideB.text: The plan to update the database has changed.
Our plan to upgrade the database is different now.
The roadmap to update the DB was modified.

cards.note:
**[187]**

~The plan of updating~ or ~for updating~ sounds unnatural. Since a [plan] is an [intention for future action], you must use [to + infinitive] regardless of the 'de' in Spanish.

cards.sideA: No quise hacerlo porque …

sideB.text: I didn't want to do it because...
I didn't mean to do it because...
I didn't intend to do it because...

cards.sideA: Hay una jerarquía clara en estos procesos.

sideB.text: There is a clear hierarchy in these processes.
These processes have a clear hierarchy.
A clear hierarchy exists within these processes.

cards.sideA: Hay 4 niveles principales en EBS con una jerarquía clara.

sideB.text: There are 4 main levels in EBS with a clear hierarchy.
EBS has 4 primary levels with a clear hierarchy.
Within EBS, there are 4 main levels and a clear hierarchy.

cards.sideA: No puedo evitarlo.

sideB.text: I can't help it.
I can't avoid it.
I can't stop myself from doing it.

cards.sideA: No me interrumpas.

sideB.text: Don't interrupt me.
Stop interrupting me.
Do not cut me off.

cards.sideA: ¿Esta el error #50 cerrado también?

sideB.text: Is error #50 closed as well?
Is bug #50 also closed?
Has error #50 been closed too?

cards.sideA: El cliente arroja otro tipo de mensaje de error

sideB.text: The client throws a different type of error message.
The client is outputting another kind of error message.
A different error message is being triggered by the client.
The client throws another kind of error message.

cards.sideA: Hagamoslo!, prueba y error!

sideB.text: Let's do it! Trial and error!
Let's give it a shot! Trial and error!
Let's go for it! Trial and error!

cards.note: ~Test and error~ is not used; [trial and error] is a fixed [idiomatic expression] that cannot be changed.

cards.sideA: Lo logre haciendo prueba y error.

sideB.text: I achieved it through trial and error.
I got it done using trial and error.
I made it work by trial and error.

cards.note: ~I did it just doing trial and error~ is not valid because it sounds unnatural; using [by doing] or [through] provides the necessary grammatical link for a method.

cards.sideA: El sistema esta caído

sideB.text: The system is down.
The system is offline.
The server is down.

cards.sideA: El me esta pagando poco.

sideB.text: He is underpaying me.
He's paying me very little.
He's not paying me enough.

cards.note: ~He's paying me little~ is rarely used in natural speech. It is much more common to say [he's paying me very little] or [he isn't paying me much].

cards.sideA: No sé si la API está arriba o el token expiró.

sideB.text: I don't know whether the API is up or the token expired.
I'm not sure whether the API is online or if the token is dead.
It's unclear whether the API is running or the token has expired.
I don't know whether the API is active or the token has expired.
I don't know if the API is active or the token has expired.

cards.note:
**[189]**

[Whether] is used here to introduce an indirect question involving two uncertain possibilities.

cards.sideA: Funcione o no, necesitamos un reporte de errores.

sideB.text: Whether it works or not, we need a crash report.
Whether or not it's working, we require an error report.
Regardless of whether it works, a bug report is necessary.

cards.note:
**[189]**

[Whether or not] indicates that the outcome (needing a report) is independent of the condition (working or not).

cards.sideA: No quise llegar tan lejos.

sideB.text: I didn't mean to go that far.
I didn't intend to take it that far.
It wasn't my intention to go so far.
I didn't want to go that far.
I didn't want to go too far.
I didn't mean to go too far.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién está en la cima de la jerarquía?.

sideB.text: Who is at the top of the hierarchy?
Who stands at the hierarchy's summit?
Who is at the hierarchy peak?

cards.sideA: Necesitas respetar la jerarquía de la empresa.

sideB.text: You need to respect the company hierarchy.
You must respect the corporate hierarchy.
You have to respect the hierarchy of the company.

cards.sideA: Entran todos, a excepción del #45

sideB.text: Everything is included, except for #45.
All of them go in, with the exception of #45.
Every single one is coming in, excluding #45.

cards.note: [Everything] or [All of them] is used for objects. [Everyone] is strictly for people. Use [Every single one] when you want to emphasize each individual item in a set.

cards.sideA: Ya no estamos usando ese procedimiento.

sideB.text: We are no longer using that procedure.
We aren't using that procedure anymore.
That procedure is no longer in use.
We don't use that procedure any longer.
We no longer use that procedure.

cards.note:
**[24]**

cards.sideA: Decidí no actualizar el servidor esta noche.

sideB.text: I decided not to update the server tonight.
I chose to not update the server tonight.
I made the decision not to update the server tonight.

cards.note:
**[188]**

[Not to update] is the correct way to negate the secondary action 'update' after the main verb [decided].

cards.sideA: Él prefiere no recibir notificaciones por correo.

sideB.text: He prefers not to receive email notifications.
He prefers to not receive notifications by email.

cards.note:
**[188]**

In modern English, [to not receive] and [not to receive] are both perfectly acceptable and interchangeable.

~He doesn't prefers receiving email notifications~ is not valid because the auxiliary [doesn't] must be followed by the [base verb] 'prefer' (without the 's').

cards.sideA: Intenta no borrar los archivos temporales aún.

**[188]**

~Try don't delete~ is a common error; always use [not to] or [to not] when negating an infinitive.

~Order date or sysdate are like the same in this case~ is very informal and redundant. Use [practically the same] or [essentially the same] instead of 'like the same'.

~Order date or sysdate are the same~ contains a subject-verb agreement error. When using 'or' with singular nouns, the verb should be singular (is), or use 'and' to make it plural [Order date and sysdate are the same].
